nso: karolo ye kgolo ya tšhelete ye re e bolokago e tla tšwa go phokotšo ya kelo yeo tefelo ya meputso e golago ka yona.

eng: this will require focused discussions among all social partners, but particularly with public sector unions.
nso: se se tla nyaka gore go be le dipoledišano tšeo di nago le nepišo gareng ga badirišani ba rena ba setšhabeng, eupša kudukudu le mekgatlo ya bašomi ba mmušo.

eng: these engagements need to be conducted in a spirit of seeking solutions.
nso: ditherišano tše di swanetše go sepetšwa ka moya wa go nyaka ditharollo.

eng: i am heartened by the willingness of all parties to engage in serious negotiations aimed at finding a solution.
nso: ke hlohleletšwa ke go nyaka ga bakgathatema ka moka go tsenela ditherišano tše di tsene letšego tšeo di ikemišeditšego go hwetša tharollo.

eng: our approach is not to dramatically cut the size of the public service, but to examine the rate at which wages grow.
nso: maikemišetšo a rena ga se go fokotša bogolo bja tirelo ya mmušo, eupša ke go lekodišiša lebelo leo tefelo ya meputso e golago ka lona.

eng: public service wages have on average increased at a much higher rate than inflation over many years, and we need to fix this if we are to get public finances under control.
nso: meputso ya bašomi ba mmušo ka kakaretšo e oketšegile ka kelo ya godimo go feta infoleišene mo me ngwageng ye mentši, gomme re swanetše go lokiša se ge e le gore re tlo dira gore ditšhe lete tš a mmušo di be ka fase ga taolo.

eng: this also applies to the management of people’s personal finances, where if any expenditure item that rises at a rate more than inflation – be it electricity tariffs, mobile tariffs or food – will always put any individual person’s budget and finances under strain and out of kilter.
nso: se gape se ama le taolo tša ditšhelete tša batho, fao e lego gore ge selo seo tšhelete e šomišwago go sona gomme tefelo ya sona e hlatlogago ka kelo ya go feta infoleišene – e ka ba tefelo ya mohlagase, ditefelo tša tšhomišo ya sellathekeng tša go swana le go reka metsotso le data goba ya dijo – se tla dula se bea ditekanyetšo le ditšhelete tša motho ka fase ga kgatelelo ebile di etšwa taolong.

eng: the wage bill remains the largest component of spending by economic classification.
nso: tefelo ya meputso e tšwela pele go ba karolo ye kgolo kudu yeo tšhelete e šomišwago go yona ge e hlopša go tša ekonomi.

eng: growth in the wage bill has begun crowding out spending on capital projects for future growth and items that are critical for service delivery.
nso: kgolo ka go tefelo ya meputso e thomile go šitiša tšhomišo ya tšhelete ka go diprotšeke tše kgolo tšeo di tlišago kgolo ya ekonomi ka moso le ka go dilo tšeo di lego bohlokwa go kabo ya ditirelo.

eng: the public service wage bill is by no means the only area where we are cutting costs.
nso: tefelo ya meputso ya bašomi ba mmušo ga se fela lekala leo re fokotšago tshenyegelo ka go lona.

eng: i have decided that there will be no increase in the salaries of senior public office bearers this year.
nso: ke tšere sephetho sa gore go ka se be le tlhatlošo ya meputso ya bahlankedibago lwane ba mmušo mo ngwageng wo.

eng: this follows a reduction in benefits stemming from changes to the ministerial handbook.
nso: se se latela phokotšo ya diputseletšo tšeo di bakilwego ke diphetogo ka go ministerial handbook.

eng: we will publish a new law this year introducing a remuneration framework for public entities and state owned companies to prevent excessive pay for board members and executives.
nso: re tla phatlalatša mo lao o moswa mo ngwageng wo fao re tla tsebagatšago tlhako ya ditefelo go dihlongwa tša mmušo le go dikhamphani tša mmušo ka nepo ya go thibela tefelo ya go fetišiša go maloko a makgotlataolo le go balaodi phethiši.

eng: our trade union compatriots are right in saying that we should in a demonstrable way prevent leakages of public funds by addressing corruption, ending irregular, fruitless and wasteful expenditure.
nso: badirišani ka rena ba mekga tlo ya bašomi ba nepile ge ba re re swanetše go thibela go dutla ga ditšhelete tša mmušo ka go tšea magato a go rarolla bome netša, go fediša tšhomišobošae di ya ditšhelete yeo e seg o molaong, yeo e sa kwagalego le ya go senya tšhelete.

eng: we will do this and much more.
nso: re tla dira se kudu le go fetišiša.

eng: as much as containing the public wage bill is critical to stabilising public finances, improving public sector performance is imperative if we want to build a more capable, efficient state.
nso: go swana le ge go laola tefelo ya meputso ya bašomi ba mmušo go le bohlokwa ka nepo ya go bea sekeng ditšhe lete tša setšhaba, go kaonafatša go šoma gabotse ga lekala la mmušo go bohlokwa ge e le gore re nyaka go aga mmušo wo o nago le bokgoni kudu, le wa go šoma ntle le mathata.

eng: we need more of the right people in the right positions.
nso: re hloka kudu batho ba male ba maemong a maleba.

eng: as we contain public spending, we are pursuing growth.
nso: ge re laola tšhomišo ya tšhe lete ya mmušo, re nyaka kgolo.

eng: it is for this reason that, despite the fiscal gap, there are no major tax increases.
nso: ke ka lebaka leo fao, ka ntle le sekgoba sa tlhokego ya ditšhe lete, go se na le dikoketšego tše kgolo tša metšhelo.

eng: instead, there is some relief for individual tax payers and several measures to broaden the corporate tax base.
nso: se bakeng seo, go na le kimollo go balefametšhelo le magato a mmalwa a go katološa mothamo wa metšhelo ya dikhamphani.

eng: we are also pushing ahead with farreaching reforms in areas like electricity provision, ports and rail and telecommunications to reduce the cost of doing business.
nso: gape re tšwela pele ka dipeakanyoleswa tšeo di nago le dipoelo tše kgolo tša go swana le kabo ya mo hlagase, kabo ya maemakepe le diporo le dikgokagano tša megala ka nepo ya go fokotša tshenyegelo ya go dira kgwe bo.

eng: through the infrastructure fund we aim to mobilise financing from a range of sources to invest in a massive build programme.
nso: ka go diriša sekhwama sa kabo ya mananeokgoparara re ikemišeditše go nyaka the kgo ya mašeleng go tšwa go methopo ye e fapafapanego ka nepo ya go beeletša ka go lenaneo le legolo la kago ya mananeokgoparara.

eng: through our industrial strategy and investment drive we are unlocking vital areas of growth.
nso: ka leano la rena la diintasteri le lesolo la dipeeletšo re lokolla makala a bohlokwa a kgolo ya ekonomi.

eng: we are fixing our public finances to make inclusive growth and job creation possible.
nso: re lokiša maemo a ditšhelete tša rena tša setšhaba ka nepo ya gore kgolo ye e akaretšago bohle le tlhomo ya mešomo di kgonagale.

eng: such times call for us to be realistic, not dogmatic.
nso: dinako tše bjalo di ipiletša go rena gore re go polele ba bangwe, re se tšeye lehlakore.

eng: they call for cooperation, not conflict.
nso: di ipiletša gore re be le tirišano, re se be le dithulano.

eng: patient support crucial for fighting tb dale hes the usaid tuberculosis south africa project is proving to be a perfect example of how government, communities and ngos can partner together to combat tuberculosis (tb) by providing proper support to patients.
nso: thekgo ya balwetši e bohlokwa go lwantšha tb dale hes protšeke ya afrika borwa ya bolwetši bja mafahla (tb) yeo e šomago mmogo le etšensi ya amerika ya tlhabollo ya boditšhabatšhaba (usaid) e laeditše bohlatse bja go ba mohlala wo mokaonekaone wa ka fao mmušo, batho setšhabeng le mekgatlo yeo e sego ya mmušo (dingo) di ka šomago mmogo go lwantšha tb ka go abela balwetši thekgo ye maleba.

eng: south africa has taken a position of leadership in the global fight against tb, and the united states agency for international development (usaid) has stepped in to provide assistance.
nso: afrika borwa e tšeere maemo a boetapele twantšhong ya tb lefaseng ka bophara, ebile us aid e tšeere kgato ya go fana ka thušo.

eng: the fiveyear project, which started in 2016, is being carried out in partnership with the national department of health in eight of south africa’s provinces.
nso: protšeke ye ya mengwaga ye mehlano, yeo e thomilwego ka 2016, e gare e phethagatšwa ka tšhomišano le kgoro ya bosetšhaba ya maphelo mo diprofenseng tše seswai tša afrika borwa.

eng: one of the most important parts of the project is to support communitybased ngos.
nso: tše dingwe tša dikarolo tše bohlokwahlokwa tša protšeke ye ke go thekga dingo tšeo di ikagilego setšhabeng.

eng: the project provides funding to 21 ngos who have supported more than 3 500 patients, the majority based in rural areas.
nso: protšeke ye e fana ka thekgo ya tšhe lete go dingo tše 21 tšeo di thekgilego balwetši ba go feta 3 500, ba bantši ba bona ba tšwa dinagamagaeng.

eng: free state progressbased in mangaung, mosamoria is one of the ngos which has received funding from the project.
nso: mosamaria profenseng ya foreisetatakua mangaung, mosamaria ke ye nngwe ya dingo tšeo di amogetšego thekgo ya tšhelete go tšwa protšekeng ye.

eng: the organisation has a team of community health workers, a project manager and a data capturer who all work towards ensuring that patients stay on treatment so that they can be cured in a six month period.
nso: mokgatlo wo o nale sehlopha sa badiredi ba maphelo go tšwa setšhabeng, molaodi wa pro tšeke le motlanyatshedimošo bao ka moka ba šomago ka thata go netefatša gore balwetši ba latela dikalafo tša bona gore ba kgone go fola mo lebakeng la dikgwedi tše tshela.

eng: "we employ 74 care givers for this project.
nso: "re thwetše bahlokomedi ba go fihla 74 mo protšekeng ye.

eng: initially we worked with 200 patients, then 400 patients, and in our current contract we have 500 patients who we work with on a daily basis.
nso: mathomong re be re šoma ka balwetši ba 200, ke moka ra hlatlogela go balwetši ba 400, ebile mo kontrakeng ya rena ya bjale re nale balwetši ba 500 bao re šomago le bona tšatši ka tšatši.

eng: the patients are referred to us when they have been diagnosed as having tb from nine different clinics in the mangaung metro," says mosamaria coordinator trudie harrison.
nso: balwetši ba ba fetišetšwa go rena ge go kgonthišišitšwe gore ba swerwe ke tb go tšwa dikliniking tše senyane tša go fapafapana mo mmasepaleng wa metsesetoropo wa mangaung," a realo motsamaiši wa mosamaria e bago trudie harrison.

eng: mosamaria conducts monthly doortodoor screening campaigns to find new tb patients and get them on treatment immediately.
nso: mosamaria e swara masolo a diteko a go tsena motse ka motse go hwetša balwetši ba tb le go netefatša gore ba hwetša kalafo ka yona nako yeo.

eng: harrison says that mosamoria’s work has reduced the stigma around tb, built close relationships with the community and also led to much better rates of successful treatment.
nso: harrison o bolela gore mošo mo wo botse wa mosamaria o fokoditše mahlabišadihlong ao batho ba nago le ona mabapi le tb, o agile dikamano tšeo di tiilego setšhabeng ebile gape o hlatlošitše kelo yeo e kao nafetšego ya dikalafo tšeo di atlegilego tša bolwetši bjo.

eng: "for example, in 2018, 514 of our patients were cured," harrison says.
nso: "go fa mohlala, ka baka la lesolo le, ka 2018 balwetši ba rena ba 514 ba thušegile gore ba fole," a realo harrison.

eng: harrison shares the story of one of mosamaria’s patients.
nso: harrison o boditše batho ka semaka sa yo mongwe wa balwetši ba mosamaria.

eng: he was given daily support by a mosamaria caregiver, who ensured that he swallowed his tablets every day and also assisted with maize meal and new clothes.
nso: o filwe thekgo ya tšatši ka tšatši ke mohlokomedi wa mosamaria, yo a bego a netefatša gore o nwa diphilisi tša gagwe tšatši ka tšatši le go thuša gape ka maupi le diaparo tše diswa.

eng: vulekamali empowers south africans more matshediso with a click of a button, people are able to easily get to grips with the country’s budgets, thanks to an online system called vulekamali.
nso: vulekamali e maatlafatša maafrika borwa more matshediso ka ponyo ya leihlo, batho ba kgona go longwa tsebe gabonolo ka ditekanyetšokabo tša naga ye, tše ka moka di kgonagala ka baka la sistemo ya inthaneteng ya go bitšwa vulekamali.

eng: the portal was established two years ago by national treasury in collaboration with a number of civil society organisations.
nso: phothale ye e hlomilwe ke ba matlotlo a bosetšhaba mengwageng ye mebedi ye fetilego ka tšhomišano le mekgatlo ye bonagalago ye tšwago setšhabeng.

eng: this innovative project won an award during the 17th public sector innovation awards 2019, under the innovations harnessing 4ir solutions category.
nso: protšeke ye ya boikgopolelo e thopile sefoka nakong ya difo ka tša bo17 tša boikgopolelo le fapheng la mmušo ngwageng wa 2019, ka fase ga legoro la boikgopolelo bjo bo kgokaga nyago ditharollo tše ikadilego ka theknolotši ya sebjalebjale.

eng: national treasury director andile best, who leads the vulekamali portal initiative, says its main aim is to increase public interest, participation and knowledge of government’s financial programmes.
nso: molaodi wa matlotlo a bosetšhaba andile best, yo a eteletšego pele lesolo la phothale ya vulekamali , o bo letše gore nepokgolo ya yona ke go hlatloša kgahlego ya batho, kamego ya bona le tsebo ya mananeo a ditšhelete a mmušo.

eng: "this is national treasury’s commitment to be more transparent about public finances.
nso: "a ke maikgafo a matlotlo a bosetšhaba a go se fihle selo mabapi le matlotlo a mmušo.

eng: budgetary information is already published on treasury’s website, but the portal contains easily accessible data in a userfriendly format, to enable more effective information sharing, analyses and research," he explaines.
nso: tshedimošo ka ga diteka nyetšokabo e šetše e phatlala ditšwe wepsaeteng ya matlotlo a bosetšhaba, eupša phothale ye e nale tshedimošo yeo e ka hwetšagalago gabonolo ka fomate ya go se fediše pelo, go kgontšha gore tshedimošo bathong e phatlalatšwe ka katlego, gomme go be le ditshekatsheko le dinyakollo," a hlaloša ka gorealo.

eng: according to best, vulekamali supports involvement by civil society and the public in budget processes and enables citizens to have informed discussions about government policies.
nso: goya ka best, vulekamali e thekga kamego ye tšwago mekgatlong ye ikadilego setšhabeng le setšhaba ka kaka retšo ditshepedišong tša teka nyetšokabo ebile e kgontšha badudi go ba le ditherišano tše nago le tsebo ka gare mabapi le dipholisi tša mmušo.

eng: "if we ask the public to participate in budgetary processes and they come from a position of not knowing, they cannot make quality inputs.
nso: "ge re ka kgopela batho gore ba kgathe tema ditshepedišong tša tekanyetšokabo ke moka bona batho bao ba sa tsebe selo, ba ka se kgone go hlagiša dintlha tša go kwagala.

eng: secondly, we want the public to know how government spends money from the public purse," best says.
nso: sa bobedi, re nyaka batho ka moka setšhabeng ba tsebe ka fao mmušo o šomišago tšhelete go tšwa sekhwameng sa ona," a realo best.

eng: for example, civil society organisations often want to know how government renders services, how services are connected to the budget and whether national, provincial or local government is responsible for specific services.
nso: go fa mohlala, mekgatlo ye lego setšhabeng e fela e nyaka go tseba ka fao mmušo o abago ditirelo, ka fao ditirelo di kgokaganago le tekanyetšokabo le gore gare ga mmušo wa bo setšhaba, mmušo wa profense goba pušoselegae ke ofe mmušo wo o rwelego maikarabelo a ditirelo tše itšego.

eng: together we can fight the impact of covid 19 vukuzenzele unnamed the world is in the throes of a public health emergency on a scale not witnessed in over a century.
nso: vmmogo re ka lwantšhana le leuba la covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed lefase le bohlokong bja tšhoganetšo ya tša maphelo a setšhaba mo seemong seo elego gore ga sa ka sa bonwa mo nakong ya go feta ngwagakgolo.

eng: the spread of the coronavirus, which causes the disease known as covid19, has been alarmingly swift and widescale, and is now defined as a global pandemic.
nso: go keka ga twatši ya corona, yeo e hlolago bolwetši bjoo bo tsebegago ka la covid19, go tloga go diragetše le go phatlalala ka bjako, gomme gabjale bo goeleditšwe bjalo ka bolwetši bja lefase.

eng: it knows no geographical or territorial boundaries, has infected both young and old, and is on the rise in developed and developing countries alike.
nso: twatši ye ga e tsebe lefelo goba mellwane, e fetetše bana le bagolo, gomme e golela pele ka go swana ka dinageng tšeo di hlabologilego le tšeo di hlabologago.

eng: as screening and testing is scaled up, the number of infections in south africa is expected to rise.
nso: bjale ka ge tekolo le teko di dirwa go tsenelela, palo ya diphetetšo e letetšwe go golela godimo.

eng: i recently declared a national state of disaster, a measure proportionate to the severity of the threat to our people, to our society and to our economy.
nso: ke sa tšwa go goeletša seemo sa masetlapelo sa bosetšhaba, elego mokgwa woo o tlo lwantšhanago le bošoro bja kotsi ye go batho ba borena, go setšhaba sa borena le go ikonomi ya rena.

eng: this will enable us to have an integrated and coordinated disaster management mechanism and to set up emergency, rapid and effective response systems.
nso: se se tla re kgontšha go ba le mokgwataolo wa masetlapelo woo o logagantšwego ebile o kgokaganego gape le go hlama ditsela tša ka pejana ebile tšeo di phethagetšego tša tšhoganetšo.

eng: this virus will be extremely disruptive, and our priority is to safeguard the health and wellbeing of all south africans.
nso: twatši ye e tlo tshwenya kudu, gomme moreromogolo wa rena ke go hlokomela maphelo le boitekanelo bja maafrika borwa kamoka.

eng: we also have to address the inevitable economic fallout.
nso: re swanetše gape re bolele le ka go wa ga ikonomi, elego selo seo re ka se se efogego.

eng: we must expect a decline in exports, a drop in tourist arrivals and a severe impact on production, business viability and job creation and retention.
nso: re swanetše re letele go fokotšega ga diromelwantle, go fokotšega ga baeng ka nageng gape le seemo se mpe tšweletšong, tshepedišong ya dikgwebo le tlhamong ya mešomo.

eng: cabinet is in the process of finalising a comprehensive package of interventions to mitigate the expected impact of covid19 on our economy.
nso: kabinete e gare e feleletša lenaneo la ditharollo go fokotša seabe seo se letetšwego sa covid19 go ikonomi ya rena.

eng: this is being done in consultation with business, labour and other relevant institutions.
nso: se se dirwa ka dipoledišano le ditheo tša kgwebo, tša mešomo mmogo le tše dingwe tšeo di amegago.

eng: it was louis pasteur who said that fortune favours the prepared mind.
nso: louis pasteur o kile a re lehumo le tšwela mohola mogopolo woo o itokišitšego.

eng: south africa is prepared, and has been so for some time.
nso: afrika borwa e itokišitše, gomme e bile bjalo nako e teletšana.

eng: since the outbreak was first reported we have acted to put screening and containment measures in place.
nso: e sa le mola go phulega ga bolwetši go begwago la mathomo, re ile ra tla ka mekgwa ya go lekola le go laola.

eng: our national response has been driven by an interministerial committee (imc) chaired and ably led by the minister of health, dr zweli mkhize.
nso: karabelo ya rena ya bosetšhaba e sepetšwa ke komiti ya ditona (imc) yeo e etilwego pele ka bokgwari ke tona ya tša maphelo, ngaka zweli mkhize.

eng: the manner in which the imc and the support teams have responded to this emergency has been both exemplary and reassuring, particularly in helping to quell public panic.
nso: mokgwa woo ka wona imc le dihlopha tša thekgo di arabetšego tšhoganetšo ye, e bile wa bokgwari gape woo o thobago pelo, kudu mo go thušeng go fokotša letšhogo setšhabeng.

eng: i will be chairing a national command council to coordinate all aspects of our national response.
nso: ke tla be ke le bodulasetulong bja lekgotla la ditaelo la bosetšhaba go kgokaganya makala kamoka a dikarabelo tša bosetšhaba.

eng: south africa has a positive track record in managing public health emergencies.
nso: afrika borwa e na le rekoto e botse ya go kgona go laola ditšhoganetšo tša maphelo a setšhaba.

eng: we have the knowledge, the means and the expertise.
nso: re na le tsebo, didirišwa le bokgoni.

eng: our scientists and epidemiologists are worldclass.
nso: boramahlale le ditsebi tša malwetši tša borena ke ba maemo a godimo.

eng: we have put a raft of emergency measures in place, and will make funding available to support their implementation.
nso: re tlile ka setlamo sa mekgwa ya tšhoganetšo, gomme re tlo fana ka mašeleng go thekga phethagatšo ya yona.

eng: they include travel bans on visitors from highrisk countries; mandatory testing, selfisolation or quarantine for south african nationals returning from these countries; and strengthening surveillance, screening and testing at ports of entry into the republic.
nso: yona e akaretša dikiletšo tša baeng ba go tšwa dinageng tšeo di amilwego kudu; diteko tša kgapeletšo, go ipeela kgakala goba go beelwa kgakala ga maafrika borwa ao a tšwago dinageng tšeo; gape le go matlafatša tlhokomelo, tekolo le diteko mo mafelong ao go tsenwago ka ona ka repabliki.

eng: social distancing is critical if we are to contain the spread of covid19.
nso: go ipeela kgole le batho go bohlokwa ge eba re nyaka go kgona go laola go keka ga covid19.

eng: gatherings of more than 100 people are prohibited and mass celebrations of national days are cancelled.
nso: dikopano tša batho ba go feta 100 di ileditšwe, gomme le meketeko ya matšatši a bosetšhaba e phumotšwe.

eng: visits to all correctional centres are being suspended for 30 days with immediate effect.
nso: go etela dikgolego go kgaoditšwe matšatši a 30 go tloga gonabjale.

eng: nonessential international travel for government officials has been proscribed and nonessential domestic travel discouraged.
nso: maeto a boditšhabatšhaba ao esego a bohlokwa a bahlankedi ba mmušo a ileditšwe gomme maeto ao esego a bohlokwa a ka gare ga naga a hloka go fokotšwa.

eng: a total of 35 land ports and two sea ports will be closed, as will schools from the 18th of march until after the easter weekend.
nso: mafelo a go tsena ka nageng a 35 a naga mmogo le a mabedi a lewatleng a tla tswalelwa, gomme le dikolo di tla tswalelwa ka di 18 hlakola go fihla ka morago ga paseka.

eng: we will soon be announcing measures with regards to universities and colleges.
nso: e se kgale re tla tla ka ditharollo tša mabapi le diyunibesithi le dikholetšhe.

eng: next month will be easter, a sacred period for a number of faiths and a time in which mass services and gatherings will take place.
nso: kgwedi yeo e tlago e tla be e le paseka, e lego lebaka leo le kgethegilego go ditumelo tša go fapana, gape ebile e le nako yeo ka yona ditirelo le dikopano tše dikgolo di diragalago.

eng: the faith community should take decisions in this regard in the best interests of the health of their congregants and the country as a whole.
nso: batho ba ditumelo tšeo di fapanego ba swanetše ba tšee sephetho go lebeletšwe dikgahlegelo tša maphelo a diphuthego tša bona le a naga ka bophara.

eng: hygiene control should be intensified in all sectors.
nso: taolo ya bohlweki e swanetše go matlafatšwa makaleng ka moka.

eng: every citizen should take charge of their own safety by observing measures such as frequent handwashing with soap or handsanitizers and covering their nose or mouth with a tissue or flexed elbow when coughing or sneezing.
nso: modudi yo mongwe le yo mongwe o swanetše a rwale maikarabelo a polokego ya gagwe ka go latela mekgwa ye bjalo ka go hlapa diatla ka sesepe goba go šomiša sebolayaditwatši sa diatla gape le go khupetša nko goba molomo ka thišu goba ka go koba sejabana ge a gohlola goba a ethimola.

eng: as part of our national effort the department of health will continue with an intensive and ongoing campaign to raise awareness about prevention, transmission and infection symptoms.
nso: bjalo ka karolo ya maitekelo a rena a bosetšhaba, lefapha la tša maphelo le tla tšwela pele ka lesolo leo le tseneletšego la go kwalakwatša temošo ka ga thibelo, phetetšo le dika tša phetetšo.

eng: i encourage all south africans to acquaint themselves with the relevant preventative material.
nso: ke hlohleletša maafrika borwa ka moka go itlwaetša tšhomišo ya didirišwa tša maleba tša thibelo.

eng: one of the greatest dangers at this time is ignorance and misinformation.
nso: ye nngwe ya dikotsi tše dikgolo mo nakong ye ke go ihlokomološa gape le go phatlalala ga tshedimošo yeo esego ya nnete.

eng: we should stop spreading fake and unverified news, especially on social media.
nso: re swanetše re emiše go phatlalatša ditaba tšeo e sego tša nnete ebile le tšeo di sa netefatšwago, kudu mararankoding a leago.

eng: this can exacerbate an already tense national mood and damage the national effort.
nso: se se ka feteletša maikutlo ao a šetšego a le godimo a setšhaba gwa ba gwa senya le maitekelo a bosetšhaba.

eng: we must also not give in to the expressions of bigotry that we have seen in other countries directed at nationals of countries from where the outbreak began or the current epicenter in europe.
nso: se sengwe gape ke gore re se ke ra gokwa ke mekgwa ya kgethollo yeo re e bonego ka dinageng tše dingwe ye e lebišitšwego go badudi ba dinaga tšeo phulego ya bolwetši e thomilego gona goba moo bo atilego ka yuropa.

eng: this is clearly a virus that affects people of all nationalities.
nso: ye ke twatši yeo e amago batho ba lefase kamoka.

eng: let us lower the wing of compassion to those who are infected, and to those who have returned home from highrisk countries.
nso: a re bontšheng kwelobohloko go bao ba fetetšwego, mmogo le go bao ba boilego gae go tšwa dinageng tšeo di amilwego kudu.

eng: let us assist those in need and those more vulnerable, instead of shunning them.
nso: a re thušeng bao ba re hlokago ebile ba leng kotsing ya go fetelwa, esego go ba hlokomologa.

eng: we will remain faithful to the values of tolerance and respect that define us as a people.
nso: re tla dula re tshepa galetše mekgwa ya kgotlelelo le tlhompho tšeo di re hlalošago bjalo ka batho.

eng: on behalf of all the people of south africa i thank the team who repatriated our compatriots from wuhan, china, as well as the leadership and people of limpopo who are assisting with the quarantine process.
nso: legatong la batho ka moka ba afrika borwa, ke leboga sehlopha seo se bušitšego magagaborena go tšwa wuhan, chi na, gape le boetapele le batho ba limpopo bao ba thušago tshepedišong ya peelothoko.

eng: this is a difficult time.
nso: ye ke nako e boima.

eng: and yet it is in times of adversity that our strength is revealed.
nso: le ge go le bjalo, ke dinakong tše boima fao maatla a rena a bonalago.

eng: we will act decisively, with determination and with purpose.
nso: re tla ema ka maoto le go tla ka diphetho ka bjako, ka maikemišetšo le ka morero.

eng: we will act as a collective, for it is upon the actions of every south african that the success of our efforts depend.
nso: re tla ba ngata e tee ka ge e le boikarabelo bja moafrika borwa yo mongwe le yo mongwe go kgontšha katlego ya maitekelo a rena.

eng: the thuma mina moment is upon us, perhaps as never before.
nso: nako ya thuma mina e fihlile, mohlomongwe ebile e tlile kudu go feta peleng.

eng: this too shall pass.
nso: se le sona se tla feta.

eng: together we can overcome covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed during the first full week of the nationwide lockdown to combat the coronavirus pandemic that is devastating the world, we were grateful for good news that brought us joy and hope at this difficult and uncertain time.
nso: mmogo re ka fenya covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed ka beke ya mathomo yeo e feletšego ka botlalo ya tswalelo ya naga ka bophara go lwantšha leuba la coronavi rus leo le hlasetšego lefase, re ile ra leboga ditaba tše botse tšeo di re tlišeditšego lethabo le tshepho mo nakong ye ye boima yeo re se nago le bonnete ka ga yona.

eng: the 114 south africans who were evacuated from wuhan in china some weeks ago ended their quarantine and were reunited with their families.
nso: maafrika borwa a 114 ao a hlakodišitšwego go tšwa wuhan ka china dibekeng tše mmalwa tša go feta ba feditše nako ya bona ya go tswalelelwa gore ba se kopane le batho gomme ba kopantšwe le ba malapa a bona.

eng: they have all tested negative for the virus and are in good health and good spirits.
nso: dipoelo tša diteko di laeditše gore ka moka ga bona ga ba na baerase ye ebile ba phetše gabotse le meboya ya bona ke ye e lokologilego.

eng: for months, they had been in lockdown, first in wuhan for some 51 days and then in polokwane for 14 days.
nso: mo dikgweding tše mmalwa, ba be ba tswaleletšwe, ba thomile go tswalelelwa kua wuhan matšatši a 51 gomme ka morago ga fao ba tswalelelwa ka polokwane matšatši a 14. ba be ba sa kgone go kopana le bao ba ba ratago, ba sa kgone go tloga fao ba bego ba beilwe gona ebile ba se na le bonnete bja gore seemo sa bona sa tlalelo se tlo fela neng.

eng: when we add the remaining 17 days that south africa will be under lockdown they will have been under lockdown for 82 days.
nso: ge re tlaleletša ka matšatši ao a šetšego a 17 ao ka ona afrika borwa e tla bego e tswaletšwe, ba tlo ba ba tswaleletšwe matšatši a 82. ke ipshinne ka go tšea nako ke na le sehlopha se se farologanego sa maafrika borwa seo se bego se bopilwe ke batho ba mengwaga ye e fapafapanego, dipolelo tše di fapafapanego le botšo bja go fapafapana.

eng: i was impressed by their resilience and courage and by their determination to remain healthy.
nso: ke kgahlilwe ke go se fele pelo le kgotlelelo ya bona le boikgafo bja bona ya gore ba dule ba phetše gabotse.

eng: they have come from the epicentre of the coronavirus in wuhan in china and have seen the devastating impact this virus is wreaking on human life.
nso: ba tšwa lefelong leo le tletšego ka diphetetšo tša coronavirus ka wuhan go la china, gomme ba bone seabe seo se šiišago seo baerase ye e nago le sona go maphelo a batho.

eng: it is not surprising to hear them say that they are on a mission to safeguard the health of those around them.
nso: ga go makatše go kwa ba re ba mo morerong wa go šireletša maphelo a bao ba lego kgauswi le bona.

eng: now their patience and fortitude has been rewarded, because they are returning to their families.
nso: gabjale, go se fele pelo le maikemišetšo a bona a putsitšwe, ka ge bjale ba boela go ba malapa a bona.

eng: their return home was made possible by a great many people who went to great lengths to make this repatriation operation a success.
nso: go boa gae ga bona go kgontšhitšwe ke batho ba bantši kudu bao ba šomilego go feta tekano go dira gore go bušetšwa ga bona gae go atlege.

eng: as a nation, we are extremely grateful to the government and the people of china for taking such good care of our citizens, and for their assistance in organising their repatriation.
nso: bjalo ka setšhaba, re tloga re leboga mmušo kudu gotee le batho ba china ge ba ile ba hlokomela badudi ba rena gabotse, le ge ba re thušitše go beakanya go bušetšwa gae ga bona.

eng: it is significant that several of the south africans in wuhan were on study scholarships from the chinese government; an act of generosity that is deeply appreciated.
nso: ke taba ye bohlokwa gore ba bantši ba maafrika borwa bao ba bego ba le wuhan ba be ba hweditše thušo ya ditšhelete tša go ithuta go tšwa mmušong wa china, e lego kgato ya go fana yeo e lebogwago kudu.

eng: we are grateful too to all the people who were involved in the operation, from the saa flight crew to the medical team to the police and soldiers who brought them home.
nso: re tloga re leboga gape batho ka moka bao ba kgathilego tema mošomong wo, go thoma ka sehlopha sa bašomi ba ka sefofaneng ba tirelo ya difofane ya afrika borwa (saa) go fihla ka sehlopha sa ba kalafo, maphodisa le mašole ao a ba gorošitšego ka mo nageng.

eng: each and every one of them stepped forward to take responsibility for the safety and wellbeing of others.
nso: o mongwe le o mongwe wa bona o tšere kgato ya go tšea maikarabelo go lebeletšwe polokego le go phela gabotse ga batho ba bangwe.

eng: they were prepared to undertake a difficult and dangerous mission and to subject themselves to quarantine.
nso: ba be ba ikemišeditše go tsenela morero wo boima le wo kotsi le go dumela gore ba tswalelelwe ba se kopane le batho.

eng: and now, they all tell me, they are ready for their next mission.
nso: gomme mo lebakeng le, ka moka ga bona ba mpotša gore ba itokišeditše morero wa bona wo o latelago.

eng: i wish to thank the staff and management of the ranch hotel in polokwane, who took great care of the returnees.
nso: ke rata go leboga bašomedi le balaodi ba hotele ya the ranch ka polokwane, bao ba hlokometšego batho bao ba bušitšwego ka mo nageng go tšwa china.

eng: they were prepared to play their part in our national effort to overcome this disease.
nso: ba be ba ikemišeditše go kgatha tema ya bona mo lesolong la bosetšhaba la go fenya bolwetši bjo.

eng: everyone involved in this operation has done south africa proud.
nso: batho ka moka bao ba kgathilego tema mo morerong wo ba dirile gore afrika borwa e ikgantšhe ka bona.

eng: the experience of the south africans in wuhan demonstrates the effectiveness – and the necessity – of a state of lockdown.
nso: maitemogelo a maafrika borwa go la wuhan a laetša go šoma gabotse – le go hlokagala – ga go tswalelwa ga naga.

eng: it was due to the drastic actions that the chinese government took to con tain the disease in the city of wuhan, that all of our people were able to return uninfected and healthy.
nso: ke ka lebaka la magato a boima ao mmušo wa china o ilego wa a tšea ka nepo ya go laola bolwetši bjo ka toropokgolong ya wuhan, fao e lego gore batho ka moka ba gaborena ba kgonnego go boela gae ba sa fetelwa ebile ba phetše gabotse.

eng: wuhan, a city of 11 million people in the province of hubei, had more than 50,000 infections.
nso: wuhan, toropokgolo ya batho ba dimilione tše 11 ka pro fenseng ya hubei, e bile le batho bao ba feteditšwego ba go feta ba 50 000. gabjale, ka morago ga dikgwedi tša go feta tše pedi ka morago ga magato a boima a go tswalelela batho mo, profense ye ebile le diphetetšo tše diswa tša ka fase ga tše 20 mo dibekeng tše pedi tša go feta.

eng: the containment of the disease in wuhan city, in hubei province and in other places across china required a massive and extraordinary effort.
nso: go laolwa ga bolwetši bjo ka toropokgolong ya wuhan ka profenseng ya hubei le ka mafelong a mangwe go ralala le china go nyakile maitapišo a magolo le ao a sego a tlwaelega.

eng: it involved drastic restrictions on daily life and is having a severe impact on the chinese economy.
nso: go ile gwa amana le dikeletšo tše boima maphelong a batho a ka mehla gomme se sa ba le seabe se segolo sa go se kgahliše go ekonomi ya china.

eng: other countries that have taken similar measures are having greater success in managing the spread of the disease than countries that have been slower to respond.
nso: dinaga tše dingwe tšeo di tšerego magato a go swana le a di na le katlego ye kgolo go laola go phatlalala ga bolwetši bjo go feta dinaga tšeo di diegilego go tšea magato.

eng: as the total number of confirmed covid19 cases worldwide grows to over 700,000 and the number of deaths exceeds 33,000, we can draw lessons from these countries.
nso: le ge e le gore palomoka ya batho bao ba fetetšwego ke covid19 lefaseng ka bophara e gotše go fihla go ba go feta ba 700 000 mola palo ya mahu e feta ba 33 000, re ka ithuta tše ntši go tšwa dinageng tše.

eng: it is now abundantly clear that the most effective way for a society to contain the spread of the disease is for the population to remain at home and physically isolated from each other for at least several weeks.
nso: gabjale go tloga go le molaleng gore tsela yeo e šomago bokaone gore setšhaba se kgone go bea bolwetši bjo ka fase ga taolo ke gore batho ka moka setšhabeng ba itulele ka magaeng a bona le gore ba katologane ka bobona bonyane tekano ya dibeke tše mmalwa.

eng: and it is important that this lockdown and all other emergency measures are both strictly adhered to and consistently enforced.
nso: gomme go bohlokwa gore tswalelo ye ya naga le magato a mangwe a tšhoganyetšo a latelwe kudu le gore a phethagatšwe ka fao go swanago.

eng: as the south africans from wuhan can testify, such restrictions on daily life, on movement and on ordinary human contact are extremely difficult to endure.
nso: maafrika borwa ba go tšwa wuhan ba ka hlatsela gore, dikiletšo tše bjalo maphe long a tšatši ka tšatši, go mese pelo ya batho le go phedišana ka fao batho ba tlwaetšego ka gona di tloga di le boima kudu go di kgotlelela.

eng: in the south african context, a lockdown brings additional hardship and strain, and we are doing everything within our means to lessen the impact on our people.
nso: go lebeletšwe seemo sa afrika borwa, tswalelo ya naga e tliša bophelo bjo boima le kgatelelo, gomme re leka ka botšohle bja rena ka fao re ka kgonago go fokotša seabe se bathong ba gaborena.

eng: but the lesson from the south africans in wuhan is that a lockdown works.
nso: eupša seo re ka ithutago sona go tšwa go maafrika borwa ao a bego a le ka wuhan ke gore go tswalelwa ga naga go a šoma.

eng: it shows that if we strictly observe the rules in place to stop the virus spreading, we will be able to bring infection rates down.
nso: go tloga go laetša gore ge re ka latela gabotse melawana yeo e lego gona go fediša phatlalalo ya baerase ye, re ka kgona go theoša palo ya batho bao ba fetelwago.

eng: help for our vulnerable citizens vukuzenzele unnamed many countries around the world have imposed coronavirus lockdowns with a view to saving the lives of their citizens.
nso: thušo go badudi ba gešo bao ba lego kotsing vukuzenzele unnamed dinaga tše ntši lefase ka bophara di tsentše tirišong go tswalela ga naga ka lebaka la coronavirus ka nepo ya go boloka maphelo a badudi ba tšona.

eng: we have done the same in our country, but our lockdown has revealed a very sad fault line in our society that reveals how grinding poverty, inequality and unemployment is tearing the fabric of our communities apart.
nso: re dirile seo le ka nageng ya rena, eupša go tswalela ga naga ga rena go utollotše maswabi a magolo kudu ka setšhabeng sa rena ao a laetšago ka fao bohloki bjo bogolo, tlhokego ya tekatekano le tlhokego ya mešomo di senyago seemo sa ditšhaba tša rena.

eng: there can be no greater anguish than that of a parent whose children cry out to them for food, but they have none to give.
nso: ga gona tlalelo ya go feta ya motswadi yo bana ba gagwe ba mo llelago ba nyaka dijo, eupša a hloka dijo tšeo a ka ba fago tšona.

eng: there can be no greater injustice than a society where some live in comfort and plenty, while others struggle at the margins to survive with little or nothing at all.
nso: ga gona tlhokego ye kgolo ya toka ya go feta ge setšhaba seo batho ba bangwe ba phelago ka boiketlo le katlego go sona, mola ba bangwe ba hlophega go fetišiša gore ba phele ka se sennyane seo ba nago le sona goba ba hloka seo ba ka iphedišago ka sona.

eng: yes, these are the residual effects of a fractured and unequal past.
nso: ee, tše ke diabe tša mašaledi a nako ye e fetilego yeo e bego e na le mathata le tlhokego ya tekatekano.

eng: but they are also a symp tom of a fundamental failing in our postapartheid society.
nso: eupša gape ke maswao ao a laetšago go palelwa kudu ga setšhaba sa ka morago ga kgethologanyo.

eng: the nationwide lockdown in response to the coronavirus has gravely exarcerbated a longstanding problem.
nso: go tswalela ga naga ka bophara bjale ka ge e le phetolo ya coronavirus go mpefaditše kudu bothata bjo e bego e le kgale bo le gona.

eng: over the past few weeks, we have been confronted with distressing images of desperate people clamouring for food parcels at distribution centres and of community protests against food shortages.
nso: mo dibekeng tše mmalwa tšeo di fetilego, re itemogetše diswantšho tšeo di bego di kweša bohloko tša batho bao ba lego kgakanegong ba baka diphuthelwana tša dijo mafelong ao di bego di abja gona le ditšhupetšo tšeo di bego di dirwa ke setšhaba kgahlanong le tlhaelelo ya dijo.

eng: we have also had to contend with allegations both disturbing and disgusting.
nso: gape re ile ra swanela ke go go šogana le ditatofatšo tše ka bobedi tše di kwešago bohloko ebile di re tsentšha mahlo a batho.

eng: a number of provinces have received reports that callous individuals, some of them allegedly government officials, are hoarding or selling food parcels earmarked for the needy and destitute, or diverting them to their friends and families.
nso: diprofense tše mmalwa di amogetše dipego tša gore go na le batho bao ba sa kgathalelego ba bangwe, bao go bona go nago le bahlankedi ba mmušo, ba fihlago goba ba rekišago diphuthelwana tša dijo tšeo di swanetšego go ﬁ wa bahloki le badikobjanamagetleng, goba ba di lebiša go bagwera ba bona le ba lapa.

eng: if there is found to be substance to these allegations we will deal with the individuals concerned harshly.
nso: ge e le gore dipolelo tše ke nnete, re tla otla batho bao ba dirago tše gabohloko.

eng: with the declaration of a national state of disaster and the imposition of a nationwide lockdown we entered uncharted waters.
nso: ka go tsebišwa ga seemo sa masetlapelo sa bosetšhaba le go tswalela naga ka bophara re tsene seemong seo re sego ra ka ra ba ka go sona mo nakong ye e fetilego.

eng: south africa has never had to deal with a public health emergency of this magnitude.
nso: afrika borwa ga se ya ka ya swanela ke go lebana le seemo sa maphelo a setšhaba se segolo ka tsela ye.

eng: we had to act quickly to save lives.
nso: re ile ra swanela ke go tšea kgato ka pela gore re phološe maphelo.

eng: and we must acknowledge that in the days and weeks that have followed, the provision of support to our country’s most vulnerable citizens has been slower than required, and that lapses have occurred.
nso: gomme re swanetše go dumela gore ka matšatši le dibeke tšeo di latetšego, kabo ya thekgo go badudi ba naga ya rena bao ba lego kotsing kudu e ile ya nanya go feta ka fao go nyakegago ka gona, gomme le go palelwa go ile gwa hlaga.

eng: however, the payment of social grants has proceeded relatively smoothly, and after a number of technical challenges, the food distribution system is being streamlined.
nso: le ge go le bjale, tefelo ya tšhelete ya thušo ya leago e ile ya tšwela pele ntle le mathata, gomme ka morago ga mathata a sethekniki, lenaneo la kabo ya dijo le a phethagatšwa.

eng: imposing a nationwide lockdown at very short notice presented several challenges.
nso: go tsenya tirišong go tswalela naga ka bophara ka tsebišo ye e dirilwego ka pejana kudu go tlišitše mathata a mmalwa.

eng: we have had to weigh up the proportionality of the national response and the extent of restrictions we would need to impose.
nso: re ile ra swanela ke go lekodišiša tekanelo ya phetolo ya bosetšhaba le bogolo bja dikiletšo tšeo re ilego ra swanela ke go di phethagatša.

eng: we ultimately chose to err on the side of caution.
nso: mafelelong re ile ra kgetha go obamela keletšo yeo re ilego ra ﬁ wa yona.

eng: and as the presentation by the ministry of health indicated recently, enforcing a lockdown at the time we did has slowed down the rate of infection and, more importantly, bought us time to prepare for a probable surge in infections in the coming weeks and months.
nso: gomme ka ge tlhagišo yeo e dirilwego ke tona ya maphelo e laeditše mo nakong ye e sa tšwago go feta, go tsenya tirišong go tswalela ga naga ka nako ye re e dirilego ka yona go dirile gore dipalopalo tša batho bao ba fetelwago ke baerase di nanye, gomme se bohlokwa kudu ke gore se se ile sa re fa nako ya go itokišetša kgonagalo ya koketšego ye kgolo ya batho bao ba fetelwago ke baerase mo dibekeng le dikgweding tše di tlago.

eng: we had to consider the impact on an already floundering economy in both the long and short term, and the impact of this substantial disruption on the livelihoods of millions of people.
nso: re ile ra swanela ke go gopodišiša ka ga seabe sa seemo se go ekonomi ye e šetšego e fokola ka go bobedi lebaka le letelele le le lekopana, le seabe sa tšhitišo ye kgolo ye go maphelo a dimilione tša batho.

eng: we had to consider what weeks of confinement to the home would mean for the employed not paid regular salaries, for the unemployed and those seeking work, for those in casual or seasonal employment, for those in the informal sector, for the indigent and for the vulnerable.
nso: re ile ra swanela ke go gopodišiša mabapi le gore dibeke tša go dula ka magae ga batho go tla ra eng go bašomi gomme ba sa tle go hwetša meputso ya bona ya tlwaelo ka lebaka la se, go bao ba hlokago mešomo le go bao ba nyakago mešomo, go bao ba šomago mešomo ya lebakanyana goba bao ba šomago dinako tše itšego, go bao ba šomago ka lekaleng leo e sego la mmušo, go bahloki le go bao ba lego kotsing.

eng: cabinet will finalise a set of measures to respond to the impact of the lockdown on the livelihoods of our people.
nso: kabinete e tla feleletša magato a mmalwa a go arabela seabe sa go tswalela naga go maphelo a batho ba rena.

eng: this has been preceded by a range of engagements with a number of stakeholders including business, labour, religious organisations, civil society and the presidential economic advisory council.
nso: se se direga ka morago ga ge re bile le ditherišano tša mehutahuta le bakgathatema ba mmalwa go akaretšwa ba kgwebo, bašomi, mekgatlo ya sedumedi, setšhaba sa badudi le lekgotlakeletšo la mopresidente ka ga ekonomi.

eng: the social partners have put forward a number of proposals on interventions that could address the immediate vulnerability of the poorest of the poor, most of whom rely on social assistance to survive.
nso: badirišani ba setšhabeng ba tlišitše ditšhišinyo tše mmalwa ka ga magato ao a ka rarollago go ba kotsing ga ka pela ga bao ba hlokago kudu, bao bontši bja bona ba botilego tšhelete ya thušo ya leago gore ba phele.

eng: we will scale up welfare provision during this period to help households living below the poverty line.
nso: re tla oketša kabo ya thušo ya leago mo nakong ye go thuša ba malapa ao a phelago ka tšhelete ya ka fase go ya go iphediša.

eng: even when the nationwide lockdown is lifted, its effects will continue to be felt for some time to come.
nso: le ka nako yeo go tswalela ga naga go fedišwago, batho ba tlo tšwela pele go itemogela seabe sa yona mo nako ye e tlago.

eng: those fortunate to have a steady income will be able to return to their jobs; but for millions of others this will be a lost month where they would otherwise have found temporary work, done business in the informal sector or saved money earned to meet their family responsibilities.
nso: bao ba nago le mahlatse a go ba le letseno la go se tekateke ba tlo kgona go boela mešomong ya bona; eupša go ba bangwe ba dimilione se e tlo ba kgwedi ye e ba lahlegetšego fao ba ka bego ba ile ba hwetša mošomo wa lebakanyana, ka ge ba ka be ba ile ba dira kgwebo ka lekaleng leo e sego la semmušo goba ba bolokile tšhelete yeo ba e hweditšego go hlokomela ba malapa a bona.

eng: food support is a shortterm emergency measure.
nso: thekgo ya dijo ke kgato ya tšhoganyetšo ya lebakanyana.

eng: it will need to be matched by sustainable solutions that help our most vulnerable citizens weather the difficult times that are still to come.
nso: e tla swanela ke go nyalantšhwa le ditharollo tša go ya go ile tšeo di thušago batho ba rena bao ba lego kotsing kudu le ka dinakong tše boima tšeo di sa tlago.

eng: i wish to thank the many ngos, religious groups and ordinary citizens who are donating money and volunteer ing to help feed the hungry and destitute.
nso: ke rata go leboga mekgatlo ye e sego ya mmušo ye mentši (dingo), dihlopha tša sedumedi le badudi ba rena bao ba neelago tšhelete le go ithaopa go thuša go fepa bao ba hlokago dijo le badikobjanamagetleng.

eng: alleviating hunger is not an act of charity.
nso: go fediša bohloki ga se tiro ya kwelobohloko.

eng: it is an imperative for any society that is founded on respect for human rights.
nso: ke selo se bohlokwa go setšhaba sefe goba sefe seo se theilwego go ditokelo tša botho.

eng: we are at a point in our battle with the pandemic where complacency could prove disastrous.
nso: re mo nakong ya ntwa ya rena kgahlanong le leuba le fao go goga maoto go ka re tlišetšago masetlapelo.

eng: i call on each and every one to remain vigilant, to continue to abide by the regulations, and to keep safe and keep others safe.
nso: ke ipiletša go yo mongwe le yo mongwe gore a dule a ntšhitše mahlo dinameng, go tšwela pele go obamela melawana, le go dula a bolokegile ebile a bolokile ba bangwe.

eng: small business support during covid19 dale hes the uncertainty and financial strain placed on entrepreneurs and small business owners by the global coronavirus pandemic is being alleviated by a host of public and private support schemes.
nso: dikgwebopotlana di fiwa thekgo nakong ya covid19 dale hes go se be le bonnete bja gore go tla direga eng le kgatelelo ya ditšhelete tšeo di lego go borakgwebo le beng ba dikgwebopotlana ka lebaka la leuba la baerase ya corona lefaseng ka moka go fokoditšwe ke bontši bja ditlamo tša mmušo le tša praebete thekgong ya dikgwebo.

eng: small business owners and informal traders are amongst the south africans who are most heavily impacted by the lockdown.
nso: beng ba dikgwebopotlana le barekiši ba mebileng ba gare ga maafrika borwa bao ba amilwego kudu ke go dula ka gae.

eng: in order to get through this difficult time, these business owners can take advantage of a number of in terventions that govern ment has put in place to assist them.
nso: gore ba fenye nako ye ye bothata, beng ba dikgwebo tše ba ka holega go tšwa magatong a mmalwa ao mmušo o wa hlomilego go ba thuša.

eng: smme debt relief fundfollowing the announce ment of the lockdown, the department of small business development immediately made a debt relief fund available for small businesses negatively affected by the covid19 pandemic.
nso: sekhwama sa kimollo ya dikoloto tša dikgwebopotlana le tša magareng (dismme)morago ga tsebišo ya go dula ka gae, kgoro ya tlha bollo ya dikgwebopotlana e dirile gore sekhwama sa kimollo ya dikoloto se be gona ka bjako go borakgwebopotlana bao ba amilwego gampe ke leuba la covid19 .

eng: more than r500 million has been made available through the fund, which small and medium enterprises must apply for through an online application process.
nso: go beetšwe thoko tšhelete ya go feta r500 milione ka sona sekhwama se, moo dikgwebopotlana le dikgwebo tša magareng di swanetšego go dira dikgopelo ka inthanete.

eng: here are the steps that need to be followed:1. your business must be registered on the smme south africa portal.
nso: a ke magato ao a swanetšwego go latelwa:1. kgwebo ya gago e swanetše go ba e ngwa dišitšwe mo phothaleng ya dismme ya afrika borwa.

eng: if you are not yet registered, you need to go to www.
nso: ge o se wa hlwa o ngwadišwa, o swanetše go ya go www.

eng: smmesa.
nso: smmesa.

eng: gov.
nso: gov.

eng: 2. once your registration is complete, you can apply for the covid19 smme debt relief fund.
nso: ge ngwadišo ya gago e phethilwe, o ka dira kgopelo go sekhwama sa kimollo ya dikoloto.

eng: you can find the application form on the department of small business development’s website.
nso: o ka hwetša foromo ya dikgopelo mo wepsaeteng ya kgoro ya tlhabollo ya dikgwebopotlana.

eng: 3. if you meet all the criteria (such as your business being tax compliant and 100 percent owned by south africans), relief funding will be paid out to approved applicants within 12 working days.
nso: 3. ge o fihlelela dinyakwa ka moka (go swana le ge kgwebo ya gago e sa kolote motšhelo gomme 100% ya yona e le ya maafrika borwa), tšhelete ya kimollo e tla lefelwa modirakgopelo yo a dumeletšwego mo matšatšing a mošomo a 12. ge o na le kgwebo ye nnyane, gona moemedi wa setheo sa tlhabollo ya dikgwebopotlana o gona go go thuša go dira dikgopelo setlamong sa kimollo ya dikoloto.

eng: if you own a microenterprise, then the small enterprise development agency is available to help you to apply to the debt relief scheme.
nso: dikgopelo tša thušo di swanetšwe go romelwa ka imeile go debtrelief@seda.

eng: org.
nso: org.

eng: za.
nso: za .

eng: solidarity response fundpresident cyril ramaphosa also announced the launch of the solidarity response fund, which received a r150 million kickstart from government.
nso: mopresidente cyril ramaphosa o tšebišitše gape thakgolo ya sekhwama sa thekgo ya naga, seo se amogetšego r150 milione ya go thoma go tšwa go mmušo.

eng: the fund allows organisations and individuals to donate to the nationwide effort to support small businesses and covid19 response efforts.
nso: sekhwama se se dumelela mekgatlo le batho go neelana maitapišong a naga ka bophara go thekga dikgwebopotlana le maitapišo a go arabela go covid19 .

eng: in the first two weeks of the fund, over r2 billion was donated, which will be channelled into relief efforts.
nso: mo dibekeng tše pedi tša mathomo, go neelanwe ka tšhelete ya go fetar2 bilione, yeo e tla išwago go maitapišo a kimollo.

eng: support for spaza shopsgovernment has recognised the unique challenges that the pandemic poses to those working in the informal sector.
nso: thekgo ya mabenkele a dispaza mmušo o lemogile ditlhohlo tša moswananoši tšeo leuba le le di tlišago go bao ba šomago dikgwebong tšeo di sego tša ngwadišwa semmušo.

eng: in this respect, minister for small business development khumbudzo ntshavheni has also released support packages for people working in this sector.
nso: ka tsela yeo, tona ya tlhabollo ya dikgwebopotlana khumbudzo ntshavheni le yena o lokololotše diphuthelwana tša thekgo go batho bao ba šomago lekaleng le.

eng: this includes a dedicated support scheme for spaza shops.
nso: se se akaretša setlamo sa thekgo seo se lebišitšwego go mabenkele a dispaza .

eng: "the spaza shop support will include dedicated networking, purchasing power and bulk purchasing through preselected and preapproved wholesalers," explains the minister.
nso: "thekgo ya mabenkele a dispaza e tla akaretša kopano ya kabo, maatla a go reka le go reka ka bontši barekišing ba dilo tša go fapafapana bao ba kgethilwego le go dumelelwa pele gore ba rekiše," gwa hlaloša tona.

eng: this support will allow spaza shops to gain access to goods which they can sell.
nso: thekgo ye e tla dumelela mabenkele a dispaza go fihlelela dithoto tšeo a ka di rekišago.

eng: let us unite in our fight against covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed the entire world is in the unrelenting grip of the coronavirus pandemic, whose spread has been rapid.
nso: a re beng ngatana e tee re lwe le covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed lefase ka moka le aparetšwe ke leuba la coronavirus , yeo e phatlalalago ka lebelo.

eng: a vaccine has yet to be found.
nso: moriana wa go e thibela ga sešo o eba gona.

eng: across the world, over 3.4 million people are known to be infected and more than 240,000 have died.
nso: lefaseng ka bophara go na le batho ba go feta 3.4 milione bao ba fetetšwego ke leuba le, mola ba go feta 240 000 ba šetše ba hlokofetše.

eng: when the national state of disaster was declared six weeks ago, south africa only had 61 confirmed coronavirus infections.
nso: ge maemo a masetlapelo a se no goeletšwa dibeke tše tshela tšeo di fetilego, afrika borwa e be e na le feela diphetetšo tše 61 tše netefaditšwego tša coronavirus .

eng: despite the relatively low number, expert opinion and international experience indicated that infec tions would rise exponentially.
nso: le ge palo yeo ya diphetetšo e be e le fase, ditsebi, gape le ge go lebelelwa maemo ao a bonalago dinageng tša boditšhabatšhaba, di boletše gore diphetetšo di tlo golela godimo kudu.

eng: i said that urgent and drastic measures would need to be taken.
nso: ke ka fao ke boletšego gore diphetho tše thata di hloka go tšewa.

eng: those measures – which included a nationwide lockdown and the closure of our borders – have proved to be effective in delaying the spread of the disease.
nso: diphetho tšeo – tšeo di akaretšago go tswalelwa ga naga ka bophara, gape le go tswalelwa ga mellwane – di bontšhitše di šoma gabotse go dira gore bolwetši bjo bo phatlalale ka go nanya.

eng: this has been possible because most south africans have adhered to the lockdown provisions, practising social distancing and wearing face masks.
nso: se se kgonegile ka ge bontši bja maafrika borwa ba latetše melao ya go tswalelwa ga naga, ba phethagaditše boipeelothoko ebile ba apara dimaseke.

eng: at this stage in the progress of the pandemic, other countries had far more infections than we do.
nso: go fihla ka wo motsotso go lebeletšwe bolwetši bjo, dinaga tše dingwe di bile le diphetetšo tše ntši go feta rena.

eng: as of now – which is 46 days since we recorded our 100th coronavirus case – we have 6,783 confirmed cases.
nso: gabjale – elego matšatši a 46 esale go tloga mola go bago le phetetšo ya bo100, re na le diphetetšo tše 6,783 tšeo di netefaditšwego.

eng: italy, which has a similar size population to ours, had more than 140,000 cases and the united states had around 700,000 confirmed cases at the 46day mark.
nso: italy, yeo e nago le palo ya batho ya go lekana le ya rena, e be e šetše e na le diphetetšo tša go feta 140 000, mola united states yona e be e šetše e na le tšeo di ka bago 700 000 tšeo di netefaditšwego ge e fihla letšatšing la bo46.

eng: but this does not mean that the danger has passed.
nso: eupša se ga se re gore kotsi e fetile.

eng: we have not nearly reached the peak of infections in south africa.
nso: ga sešo re fihla nhlorwaneng ya diphetetšo ka afrika borwa.

eng: all the scientific models show that the infection rate will continue to rise at a much faster rate in the next few months.
nso: tša mahlale di bontšha gore diphetetšo di tlo tšwela pele go oketšega ka lebelo mo dikgweding di se kae tše di tlago.

eng: however, the speed with which the virus spreads and the number of people who are ultimately infected will be determined by what we do now.
nso: le ge go le bjalo, lebelo la ka fao leuba le le kekago ka gona, gape le palo ya batho bao ba feleletšago ba fetetšwe, di tla laolwa ke seo re se dirago gonabjale.

eng: that is why the easing of the lockdown needs to be gradual and cautious.
nso: ke ka fao go fefolwa ga go tswalelwa ga naga go swanetše go dirwa gannyanegannyane le gona ka tlhokomelo.

eng: it is for this reason that many regulations need to remain in place and why it is absolutely essential that people observe them.
nso: ke ka lona lebaka melawana e mentši e hlokago go tšwetšwa pele le gore go bohlokwa kudu gore batho ba e latele.

eng: i know how difficult this is and i understand the concern that many of our compatriots have about how these regulations are interfering and limiting their rights.
nso: ke tloga ke kwešiša gabotse dipelaelo tšeo bontši bja batho ba gaborena ba nago le tšona mabapi le ka fao melawana ye e tshwenyanago le go gatakela ditokelo tša bona.

eng: but all this is necessary.
nso: empa se se se hloka go dirwa.

eng: our overriding objective is the preservation of life.
nso: nepokgolo ya rena ke go boloka maphelo.

eng: social distancing and proper hygiene are still our best and only defences in this struggle.
nso: boipeelothoko le tlhokomelo ye maleba ya tša maphelo e sa le magato a rena a boitšhireletšo mo bothateng bjo.

eng: our considerations are based on empirical evidence, scientific and economic data and international best practice.
nso: diphetho tša rena di ithekgile ka bohlatse bjoo bo bonalago, tshedimošo go tšwa go tša mahlale le ikonomi gape le ka fao go šongwago ka gona maemong a boditšhabatšhaba.

eng: in the 1995 judgment of the constitutional court that outlawed capital punishment, jus tice arthur chaskalson wrote: "the rights to life and dignity are the most important of all human rights and the source of all other personal rights.
nso: ka kahlolong ya 1995 ya kgorotsheko ya molaotheo, yeo e fedišitšego kotlo ya lehu, moahlodimogolo arthur chaskalson o ngwadile gore: "ditokelo tša go phela le go ba le seriti ke tšona tše bohlokwahlokwa go feta ditokelo ka moka tša botho, gomme ebile ke mothopo wa ditokelo ka moka tša batho.

eng: by committing ourselves to a society founded on the recognition of human rights we are required to value these two rights above all others.
nso: ka go ikgafela go ba setšhaba seo se theilwego kamogelong ya ditokelo tša botho, re hloka go phagamiša ditokelo tše tše pedi go feta tše dingwe.

eng: "the regulations we have put in place are founded on that commitment to life and dignity, and which justify – in these extreme circumstances – temporary restrictions on other rights, like freedom of movement and association.
nso: "melawana yeo re tlilego ka yona e hlamilwe boikgafong bja go bea bophelo le seriti sa batho pele, elego tšeo di hlalošago – mo mabakeng a boimaima – dikiletšo tša nakwana ditokelong tše dingwe tše bjalo ka ditokelo tša mosepelo le tša dikamano.

eng: in doing this, south africa is not unlike many other countries.
nso: afrika borwa e dira se go no swana le dinaga tše dingwe tše ntši.

eng: an estimated onefifth of the world’s population is under quarantine or nationwide lockdown, with this number growing rapidly in response to rising infections.
nso: palo yeo e ka bago teehlanong ya batho lefaseng e phethagatša boipeelothoko goba go tswalelwa ga naga ka bophara, gomme palo ye e gola ka lebelo ka baka la diphetetšo tšeo di golelago godimo.

eng: this includes countries with substantially larger populations than ours, like india with its 1.5 billion people.
nso: se se akaretša dinaga tšeo di nago le batho ba bantši kudu go feta ya gaborena, tše bjalo ka india yeo e nago le batho ba 1.5 bilione.

eng: dozens of countries have imposed curfews such as the one that is now in place here.
nso: dinaga tše ntšinyana di tlile ka dinako tša kgaotšo ya mosepelo tše bjalo ka tšeo di phethagatšwago ka mo gae.

eng: limitations on movement are in place in a number of countries.
nso: dikgaotšo tša mosepelo di a dirwa ka dinageng tše ntšinyana.

eng: in the uk and the french capital, paris, public exercise is limited to certain hours and within a certain distance of one’s home.
nso: ka uk le ka motsemošate wa france , elego paris , go itšhidullela ka ntle ga legae go beetšwe diiri tše itseng gape le mellwane ya gore motho a itšhidullele bokgole bjo bokaakang.

eng: containment and prevention measures similar to ours are in place in a number of countries.
nso: mekgwa ya taolo le thibelo ya go swana le ya gaborena e a direga ka dinageng tše ntšinyana.

eng: for example, alcohol sales during lockdown have been either restricted or banned in a number of territories and by local governments, including parts of mexico, hong kong and greenland, which last month imposed a ban on alcohol sales during lockdown to limit infection but also ‘to curb violence against women and children.’there has been much public comment on government’s decision to extend the prohibition on the sale of tobacco products into level 4. a decision like this is bound to be controversial, but it is wrong to suggest that there are ministers or a president doing and saying whatever they want on this matter.
nso: go fa mohlala, go rekišwa ga bjala nakong ya go tswalelwa ga naga go fokoditšwe goba go ileditšwe ka ditikologong tše ntšinyana, ebile go gongwe di dirwa ke mebušo ya selegae, go swana le dikarolo tše dingwe tša mexico , hong kong le greenland , tšeo kgweding yeo e fetilego di tlilego ka kiletšo ya thekišo ya bjala nakong ya go tswalelwa ga naga go fokotša phetetšo gape le ‘go thibela dikgaruru kgahlanong le basadi le bana.’go bile le ditšhišinyo tše ntši tša setšhaba mabapi le sephetho sa mmušo sa go oketša kiletšo ya thekišo ya motšoko ge go tsenwa legatong la bone.

eng: on 23 april, i announced that cigarette sales would be permitted during level 4. this was based on the view of the national coronavirus command council (nccc), and which was contained in the draft framework that was published for consulation.
nso: sephetho sa go swana le se se swanetše go no tsoša lešata, empa taba ya gore batho ba nagane gore ditona, goba mopresidente, ba dira le go bolela seo ba se ratago mo tabeng ye, ga se yona.

eng: after careful consideration and discussion, the nccc reconsidered its position on tobacco.
nso: morago ga tekolo le dipoledišano, nccc e ile ya bušetša sephetho sa yona sa mabapi le motšoko morago.

eng: as a result, the regulations ratified by cabinet and announced by minister nkosazana dlaminizuma on 29 april extended the prohibition.
nso: ka fao, melawana yeo e tsebagaditšwego ke kabinete gomme ya begwa ke tona nkosazana dlaminizuma ka la 29 mopitlo e ile ya oketša nako ya kiletšo ya motšoko.

eng: this was a collective decision and the public statements by both myself and the minister were done on behalf of, and mandated by, the collective i lead.
nso: se e bile sephetho seo se tlilego ka sehlopha, gomme bobedi pego ya ka le ya tona di dirilwe legatong la, ebile di laetšwe ke, sehlopha seo ke se etilego pele.

eng: every regulation we have put in place has been carefully considered.
nso: molawana wo mongwe le wo mongwe woo re tlilego ka wona o lekotšwe ka tlhokomelo.

eng: along the way there has been consultation with medical experts, various constituencies and different industries.
nso: ge re le gare re lekola melawana ye, re be re boledišana le ditsebi tša maphelo, batho go tšwa mafelong a go fapafapana, gape le go tšwa diintasetering tša go fapafapana.

eng: we have been guided by international bodies and the experience of other countries.
nso: re hlahlwa ke mekgatlo ya boditšhabatšhaba le maitemogelo a dinaga tše dingwe.

eng: the reality is that we are sailing in unchartered waters.
nso: nnete ke gore re phela mabakeng ao re sa a tlwaelago.

eng: there is still a great deal about the epidemiology of the virus that is unknown.
nso: go sa na le pelaelo e kgolo mabapi le tlholego ya leuba le yeo botšwelo bja yona bo sa tsebego ke motho.

eng: it is better to err on the side of caution than to pay the devastating price of a lapse in judgment in future.
nso: go kaone go dira diphošo re hlokometše go na le gore re tle re itshole ka moso ka baka la diphetho tša bjale.

eng: while there are differing views on some of the decisions we have taken – and in some instances these have polarised opinion – government is making every effort to act in a way that advances the rights to life and dignity of all our people.
nso: le ge go na le dikakanyo tša go fapafapana mabapi le diphetho tše dingwe tšeo re di tšeerego – gomme mo mabakeng a mangwe di ena gape le dikgopolo tša go fapafapana – mmušo o leka ka maatla go šoma ka mokgwa woo o tšwetšago pele ditokelo tša go phela tša batho ka moka ba gaborena.

eng: listening to our people and their concerns during this period has been one of the distinguishing features of how we as government have managed this pandemic.
nso: go theeletša batho ba gaborena le dipelaelo tša bona mo nakong ye go bile ntlha ye bohlokwahlokwa ya ka fao rena re le mmušo re kgonnego go laola leuba le.

eng: we continue to listen to the concerns of our people and are prepared to make adjustments that balance people’s concerns about the challenges they face with the need to save lives.
nso: re tšwela pele go theeletša dipelaelo tša batho ba gaborena gomme re ikemišeditše go dira ditokišo tšeo di dirago gore dipelaelo tša batho mabapi le dihlotlo tšeo ba lebaganego natšo di sepelelane le go boloka maphelo.

eng: at this difficult time, our collective energies must be focused on ensuring that health and life is preserved, that the delivery of food, water, health care, social security and social support is not disrupted.
nso: mo nakong ye ye boima, maatla a rena ka seboka a swanetše a lebišwe polokegong ya tša maphelo le bophelo, le gore kabo ya dijo, meetse, tlhokomelo ya tša maphelo, tšhireletšego ya tša leago le thekgo ya tša leago di se šitišwe.

eng: under these extraordinary circumstances, as government, as individuals and as society we will at times make mistakes.
nso: mo mabakeng a a moswananoši, re le mmušo, re le batho ebile re le setšhaba, ka nako tše dingwe re tlo fela re dira diphošo.

eng: when these occur, we will correct them.
nso: ge diphošo tše di ka direga, re tla di lokiša.

eng: step by step guide on using a facemask vukuzenzele unnamed the national department of health recommends that everyone in south africa should wear a cloth facemask (also known as a nonmedical mask) when in public.
nso: tlhahlo ya kgato ka kgato mabapi le go šomiša maseke wa sefahlego vukuzenzele unnamed kgoro ya bosetšhaba ya maphelo e eletša motho mang le mang mo afrika borwa go apara maseke wa go dirwa ka lešela (woo gape o tsebegago ka gore ke maseke woo esego wa kalafo) ge a le gare ga batho.

eng: commuters travelling in taxis and other forms of public transport, as well as people spending time in spaces where physical distancing is difficult to practice, are mustwear cloth facemasks.
nso: banamedi ba dithekisi le ba dinamelwa tše dingwe tša bohle, gape le batho bao ba fetšago nako ye ntši ba le mafelong ao eleng gore go boima go emela kgole le batho ba bangwe, ba swanetše go apara dimaseke tša lešela.

eng: the main benefit of everyone wearing a facemask is to reduce the amount of coronavirus (covid19) being coughed up by those with the infection thereby reducing its spread through droplets.
nso: mohola wo mogolo go bohle ba aparago maseke wo ke go fokotša bontši bja coronavirus (covid19) yeo e gohlolwago ke bao e ba fetetšego, gomme seo se napa se fokotša go phatlalala ga gona ka marothinyana a ge motho a gohlola.

eng: since some people with the coronavirus may not have symptoms or may not know they are infected, everyone should wear a facemask.
nso: bjale ka ge batho ba bangwe bao ba nago le coronavirus ba se na dika goba ba sa tsebe gore ba fetetšwe, motho yo mongwe le yo mongwe o swanetše go apara maseke wa sefahlego.

eng: cloth facemask respiratory hygienecloth facemasks are recommended as part of respiratory hygiene or etiquette which also includes coughing and sneezing into a bent elbow or a tissue.
nso: bohlokwa bja maseke wa lešela mabapi le go hema moya wa go hlweka dimaseke tša lešela go eletšwa gore di aparwe bjalo ka karolo ya go hema moya wa go hlweka goba bjalo ka setlwaedi se akaretšago go gohlolela le go ethimolela ka sejabaneng seo se kobilwego goba ka gare ga thišu.

eng: the facemask must cover the nose and mouth completely.
nso: maseke o swanetše go khupetša nko le molomo ka botlalo.

eng: facemasks should not be lowered when speaking, coughing or sneezing.
nso: maseke ga se wa swanela go gogelwa tlase ge o bolela, o gohlola goba o ethimola.

eng: it is very important that cloth masks are used correctly.
nso: go bohlokwa kudu gore dimaseke tša lešela di šomišwe ka maleba.

eng: incorrect use might result in users putting themselves at risk of spreading covid19.
nso: tšhomišo ye fošagetšego e ka dira gore badiriši ba ipee kotsing ya go phatlalatša covid19 .

eng: even when you are wearing a mask you must still: wash your hands observe social distancing remember to sneeze and cough into your elbow avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth with unclean hands.
nso: le ge o apere maseke, o swanetše gore: o hlape diatla o bule sekgoba gare ga gago le ba bangwe o gopole go ethimolela le go gohlolela ka sejaba neng o efoge go kgoma mahlo, nko le molomo wa gago ka diatla tšeo di sa hlwe kago.

eng: the public should not use surgical (medical) or n95 respirator masks because these are reserved for healthcare workers and other medical first responders.
nso: batho setšhabeng ga ba swanela go šomiša dimaseke tša go hema tša go šomišwa ke dingaka goba tšeo di tsebegago ka la n95 gobane tšona di beetšwe feela bašomedi ba tša maphelo le batho ba bangwe ba go šoma ka tša maphelo .

eng: may 2020 edition 2how to handle your cloth mask 1. only use a mask that has been washed and ironed.2.
nso: vmopitlo 2020 kgatišo 2ka moo o ka swarago maseke wa gago wa lešela ka gona 1. šomiša feela maseke woo o hlatswitšwego ebile o aenilwe.2.

eng: wash your hands before putting the mask on.3.
nso: hlapa diatla pele o apara maseke.3.

eng: place the mask with the correct side facing your face, and ensure that it covers both your nose and mouth properly.4.
nso: lebantšha lehlakore la maleba la maseke le sefahlego sa gago, gomme o netefatše gore o khupetša nko le molomo gabotse.

eng: tie the strings behind your head, or if you are using elastic bands, make sure these are tight.5.
nso: 4. bofa dithapo tša maseke ka morago ga hlogo ya gago, goba ge e le gore maseke wa gago o bofa ka direkere, netefatša gore di ngangegile.

eng: move it around to get the best fit.
nso: o sokološe go fihlela o go lekana bokaone.

eng: never touch the cloth part.6.
nso: o se ke wa kgoma karolo ya go khupetša nko le molomo.

eng: once you have put on the mask, do not touch your face again until you take it off.7.
nso: 6. ge o se no apara maseke, o se ke wa kgoma sefahlego sa gago go fihla ge o o apola.

eng: when you take it off, undo the ties, and carefully fold the mask inside out, hold it by the strings/elastic and place the mask in a container reserved for washing the cloth mask.8.
nso: 7. ge o apola maseke, bofolla mahuto, gomme o phuthe maseke ka tlhokomelo, o o hlanole, o o sware ka dithapo/direkere gomme o o lokele ka sedirišweng seo eleng gore se šoma feela go hlatswetša maseke.

eng: wash your hands thoroughly and dry before do ing anything else.9.
nso: 8. hlapa diatla gabotse o be o di phumole pele o ka dira se sengwe.

eng: you must have at least two cloth masks per person so you will be able to wash one and have a clean one ready for use.10.
nso: 9. motho yo mongwe le yo mongwe o swanetše a be le bonnyane dimaseke tše pedi gore a kgone gore ge maseke wo mongwe o hlatswitšwe a be le wo mongwe woo a ka o aparago.

eng: masks should be washed with soap and hot water, rinsed thoroughly and ironed.
nso: 10. dimaseke di swanetše di hlatswiwe ka meetse a go fiša a go ba le sesepe, di tlošeletšwe gabotse di be di aeniwe.

eng: the importance of social distancing in the battle against the highly infectious covid19, social distancing is extremely important to help curb the spread of this disease across the country.
nso: bohlokwa bja go bula sekgoba gare ga gago le ba bangwe ge re le gare re elwa le baerase ya go fetela batho ka bontši ya covid19, go bula sekgoba gare ga gago le ba bangwe go bohlokwa kudu go re thuša go fokotša go phatlalala ga bolwetši bjo go kgabaganya naga.

eng: social distancing is about keeping a safe distance of about 2 metres from others so that you reduce the transmission of covid19.
nso: go bula sekgoba gare ga gago le ba bangwe go ra go bula sekgoba seo se bolokegilego sa dimithara tšeo e ka bago tše pedi gare ga gago le batho ba bangwe gore o fokotše phetetšo ya covid19 .

eng: this practice is very important while we are in the midst of the coro navirus epidemic where the virus spreads from person to person via an infected person passing droplets through sneezing, coughing or talking.
nso: mokgwa wo o bohlokwa kudu ka ge re sa le ka gare ga kotsi ya leuba la coronavirus moo elego gore baerase ye e phatlalala go tloga mothong go ya go yo mongwe ge motho yo a fetetšwego a gaša marothinyana ka go ethimola, go gohlola goba go bolela.

eng: our democracy will help us overcome covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed we often take our healthy and robust democracy for granted.
nso: temokrasi ya rena e tla re thuša go fenya covid 19 vukuzenzele unnamed gantši ga re leboge temokrasi ya rena ye botse ye maatla.

eng: yet it is probably our greatest asset in our momentous struggle to overcome the coronavirus pandemic.
nso: le ge go le bjalo ke mothopo wa rena mo ntweng ye kgolo ya go fenya leuba la coronavirus.

eng: we have among the most politicallyengaged citizenry in the world.
nso: re gare ga batho bao ba kgathago tema kudu mo dipolotiking mo lefaseng.

eng: a poll in 2018 by the pew research center shows south africans are strongly inclined to take political action about issues they feel most strongly about, such as health care, education, freedom of speech and corruption.
nso: dipalopalo tša 2018 ka senthara ya dinyakišišo ya pew di bontšha gore maafrika borwa ba hlohloletšwa kudu go tšea dikgato ka ditaba tšeo di ba amago kudu, go swana le tlhokomelo ya maphelo, thuto, tokollo ya polelo le bomenetša.

eng: the poll confirms much that we already know about ourselves.
nso: dipalopalo tše di kgonthiša seo re šetše re se tseba ka ga rena, ga go na seo re ipshinago ka sona go swana le go boledišana gabotse le mmušo gape le ka bo rena ka ditaba tša letšatši tšeo di re tshwenyago.

eng: we have an active civil society ever ready to safeguard our fundamental freedoms and rights.
nso: re na le setšhaba sa selegae sa mafolofolo seo se dulago se itokišeditše go šireletša ditokologo le ditokelo tša rena tše bohlokwa.

eng: one of the triumphs of our democracy is that every south african believes the constitution protects them and that the courts are a fair and impartial arbiter of their interests.
nso: diphenyo tša temokrasi ya rena ke gore maafrika borwa a kgolwa gore molaotheo o a ba šireletša le gore dikgorotsheko ke mmoelanyi wa go kwagala wa go se tšee lehlakore go dikgahlego tša bona.

eng: i got thinking on these matters during a recent visit to the eastern cape to assess the province’s coronavirus state of readiness.
nso: ke dutše ke nagana ka dilo tše nakong ya ketelo ya kgauswanyane go la kapa bohlabela ya go lekola ge e le gore profesene e lokile go lwantšhana le coronavirus.

eng: i was asked by a journalist whether i was concerned at the pending litigation challenging certain provisions of the disaster management act.
nso: raditaba yo mongwe o mpotšišitše ge e le gore ke tshwenywa ke go išwa kgorotshekong go hlohla dinyakwa tše dingwe tša molao wa taolo ya masetlapelo.

eng: this law is the basis for all the regulations promulgated under the national state of disaster we declared to combat coronavirus.
nso: molao wo ke motheo wa melawana ka moka ye e tsebišitšwego ka fase ga maemo a setšhaba a masetlapelo yeo re e tsebišitšego go lwantšha coronavirus.

eng: since the start of this crisis, a number of people have exercised their right to approach the courts.
nso: go tloga mola bothata bjo bo thomago, batho ba bantši ba phethagaditše tokelo ya bona ya go leba dikgorotshekong.

eng: the lockdown regulations were challenged in the very first week of the lockdown by a private citizen from mpumalanga who wanted an exemption from the travel prohibition to attend a funeral.
nso: melawana ya go dula ka gae e hlohlilwe ka beke ya mathomo ya go dula ka gae ke modudi yo a ikemetšego go la mpumalanga yoo a bego a nyaka gore a dumelelwe go ya polokong.

eng: in the seven (7) weeks that have followed, there have been legal challenges from a number of individuals, religious bodies, political parties, ngos and from business organisations against one measure or more of the lockdown provisions they were unhappy with.
