eng: young farmer receives covid19 support vukuzenzele unnamed nomagcinandile suduka (27) is growing her family’s legacy and wealth by investing in agriculture.
nso: molemi wa moswa o amogela thekgo ya covid19 silusapho nyanda molemi yo a sa thomago tša temo wa kua kapa bohlabela ke yo mongwe wa bao ba holegilego go tšwa sekhwameng sa mmušo sa kimollo ya coronavirus.

eng: the o wner of 4 u and 4 me primary cooperative in mooiplaas village received support from the department of agriculture, land reform and rural development’s coronavirus (covid19) relief fund for her egg, livestock and vegetable farm.
nso: nomagcinandile suduka wa mengwaga ye 27 o aga bohwa bja lapa la gabo le lehumo ka go beeletša temong.

eng: "i received three vouchers totalling r19 000. a voucher for r12 000 to buy layer egg chickens, a voucher for r6 500 to buy feed and a r500 voucher to buy medicines.
nso: mong wa kgwebo ya 4 u and 4 me primary cooperative kua motsaneng wa mooiplaas o amogetše thušo go tšwa sekhwameng sa kimollo sa coronavirus (covid19) sa kgoro ya temo, mpshafatšo ya naga le tlhabollo ya dinagamagae ka baka la polasa ya gagwe, ya mae gagwe, diruiwa le merogo.

eng: "she started her egg production farm by feeding her family’s traditional chickens with layer grower feed, which enables them to produce eggs without mating.
nso: kgoro e fane ka dibaotšhara tša go bitša r1.2 bilione go balemi bao ba di hlokago.

eng: suduka, who also farms with 73 goats, 25 sheep and 25 cows, started farming in 2015 after obtaining a public management n6 certificate from ikhala training and vocational education and training college.
nso: "ke amogetše dibaotšhara tše tharo tša go bitša r19 000. tšona ke baotšhara ya r12 000 go reka dikgogo tša go bea mae tse 100, baotšhara ya r6 500 ya go reka dijo tša dikgogo le baotšhara ya r500 ya go reka meryana.

eng: after realising that there were not a lot of job opportunities out there, she decided to take over the family’s then subsistence farm and turn it into a profitable business.
nso: "o thomile polasa ya gagwe ya go tšweletša dikgogo ka go fepa dikgogo tša gae tša lapa la gabo ka dijo tša go di thwathwadiša mae, tšeo di di kgontšhago gore di thwathwatše mae ntle le gore di namelane.

eng: suduka’s sixhectare vegetable farm produces maize, potatoes, peas and beans.
nso: suduka, yo le yena a tsenetšego tša temo ka dipudi tše 73, dinku tše 25 le dikgomo tše 25 o thomile tša temo ka 2015 morago ga go ikhweletša sethifikeithi sa n6 sa taolo ya mmušo go tšwa kholetšeng ya ikhala ya thutatiro le ya tlhahlo.

eng: the maize is planted on four hectares, the potatoes on one hectare and the peas and beans share the last hectare.
nso: morago ga go lemoga gore mešomo ga e kaalo, a tšea sephetho sa go tšea polasa yeo ka nako yeo e bego e dirišwa ke lapa la gabo go iphediša a e fetošetša go ba kgwebo ya go dira letseno.

eng: suduka has learnt a lot from covid19, especially that her best assets are her hands and hard work.
nso: suduka ge a bolela o re: "re gotše re dira tša temo, ke moka morago ga go aloga ke tšeere sephetho sa go tsenela temo legatong la go inyakela mošomo."

eng: building a better life vukuzenzele unnamed from humble begin nings in kwanon goma village, kwa zulunatal, 23yearold silondiwe magwaza has conquered many obstacles to reach her dream of becoming a construction manager.
nso: go aga bophelo bjo bokaone vukuzenzele unnamed go tšwa motsaneng wa kwanongoma gola kwazulunatal fao a goletšego gona ka go itshokolela, silondiwe magwaza wa mengwaga ye 23 o hlotše mapheko a mantši gore a fihlelele toro ya gagwe ya go ba molaodi wa tša kago.

eng: growing up surrounded by poor infrastructure motivated magwaza to explore new ways to uplift her community.
nso: mananeokgoparara a go fokola ao magwaza a gotšego a bona go potologa fao a bego a dula gona a mo file hlohleletšo ya go inyakela ditsela tše diswa tša go kaonafatša setšhaba sa gabo.

eng: she is now the first member of her family to obtain a degree.
nso: ga bjale ke yena wa mathomo ka lapeng la gabo wa go ikhweletša tikrii.

eng: magwaza qualified at the university of the witwatersrand in 2019, obtaining an undergraduate degree in construction studies.
nso: magwaza o phethile dithuto tša gagwe tša mošomo wo wa tša kago go tšwa yunibesithing ya witwatersrand ka 2019, a ikhweletša tikrii ya mathomo ya dithuto tša kago.

eng: "kwanongoma has very poor infrastructure.
nso: "kwanongoma e nale mana neokgoparara a go fokola kudu ebile kabo ya ona e bonagala e sepela ka go nanya kudu.

eng: looking at all the challenges faced by my hometown, i was encouraged to do something relating to construction so that i can be one of the people to change the current state," she says.
nso: ka go lebelela ditlhotlo ka moka tšeo toropo ya gešo e lebaganego le tšona, ke ile ka ba le hlohleletšo ya go dira se sengwe sa go amana le tša kago gore ke kgone go ba yo mongwe wa bao ba fetošago seemo sa bjale," a realo.

eng: obtaining her qualification was no easy feat.
nso: go hwetša lengwalo la gagwe la thuto go be go se bonolo.

eng: magwaza says she found it difficult to concentrate due to her constant worry about funding.
nso: magwaza o bolela gore go be go le boima kudu gore a bee kgopolo ya gagwe dithutong ka baka la ge a be a dula a belaetšwa ke go hloka thekgo ya ditšhelete.

eng: then, the municipal infrastructure support agent (misa) stepped in to assist.
nso: ke moka a thušwa ke kemedi ya thekgo ya mananeokgoparara a mmasepala (misa).

eng: "i used to stress a lot about funding as i come from a disadvantaged background.
nso: "ke be ke dula ke gatelegile kudu mogopolong ka gobane ke gotše ga boima go tloga bonyenyaneng.

eng: that was until 2018, when i received a bursary from misa.
nso: tshokolo yaka e fedile ka 2018 ge ke be ke amogela pasari go tšwa misa.

eng: this helped me to complete my degree without any more stress.
nso: se se nkhotše go phethagatša lengwalo la ka la tikrii ntle le gore ke gatelege mogopolong gape.

eng: i had everything paid for, all i had to do was focus on my studies," she says.
nso: dithuto tšaka ka moka di be di lefetšwe, nna ke be ke šaletšwe fela ke gore ke bee šedi yaka ka moka dithutong tšaka," a realo.

eng: magwaza is one of hundreds of students who pass through misa’s youth development programmes each year.
nso: magwaza ke wo mongwe wa baithuti ba makgolokgolo bao ba fetago matsogong a misa ka mananeo a ngwaga ka ngwaga a tlhabollo ya baswa.

eng: the programmes provide funding and support and help students find job placements once qualified.
nso: mananeo a a fana ka thušo ya tšhelete le ka thekgo ebile a thuša baithuti gore ba ikhwe letše dikgoba tša mešomo ge ba fihleletše maswanedi a mošomo dithutong tša bona.

eng: "i was really looking forward to our graduation ceremony.
nso: "ke be ke tloga ke emetše monyanya wa rena wa dikalogo.

eng: it would have meant a lot considering that i was going to be the first graduate in my family.
nso: e be e tlaba monyanya wo mogolo kudu ka ge ke be ke tla ba motho wa mathomo wa go aloga ka lapeng la gešo.

eng: i am still hoping that we have our graduation ceremony, but this might not be possible given the coronavirus pandemic," she says.
nso: ke sa ntše ke holofela gore re ka ba le letšatši la rena la go aloga, eupša go ka direga gore se se folotše go lebeletšwe leuba la coronavirus ,’’ a realo.

eng: the construction industry mainly consists of men.
nso: intasteri ya tša kago e tletše kudu ka banna.

eng: "at times, women are made to feel small because their ability to bring about change is doubted.
nso: "ka nako tše dingwe, basadi ba ikwa ba nyenyefaditšwe ka gobane bokgoni ba bona ba go tliša diphetogo bo fela bo belaelwa.

eng: sometimes their voices are not heard.
nso: ka nako tše dingwe mantšu a bona ga a theeletšwe.

eng: "i still chose construction management because i believe that i have the power to change the industry and improve it where there is a need.
nso: "gontše go le bjalo ke kgeth ile taolo ya tša kago ka gobane ke dumela gore ke nale maatla a go fetoša intasteri ye le go e kaonafatša fao go nyakegago gona.

eng: i have seen women in this industry making it to top positions and having influence.
nso: ke bone basadi ba bangwe intastering ye ba nyologela maemong a god imo ebile ba nale khuetšo.

eng: i believe that i too can make it," she says.
nso: ke dumela gore le nna nka nyologela maemong a a godimo,’’ a realo.

eng: south africa acts to address ventilator shortage silusapho nyanda a locally developed ventilator will help patients with mild covid19 symptoms to breathe easier.
nso: afrika borwa e tšea kgato ya go rarolla bothata bja tlhokego ya dithušagohema silusapho nyanda sethušagohema seo se dirilwego ka mo afrika borwa se tla thuša balwetši bao ba nago le dika tša magareng tša covid19 gore ba heme gabonolo.

eng: the fight against the coronavirus disease (covid19) in south africa has been boosted with the production of the first ventilator made in the country.
nso: ntwa kgahlanong le bolwetši bja coronavirus (covid19) ka afrika borwa e matlafaditšwe ke sethušagohema sa mathomo seo se dirilwego ka mo nageng.

eng: the continuous positive airway pressure (cpap) ventilator helps patients with mild symptoms of covid19 to breathe easier by providing a mild level of oxygenated air pressure to keep their airways open.
nso: sethušagohema sa continuous positive airway pressure (cpap) se thuša balwetši bao ba nago le dika tša magareng tša covid19 gore ba kgone go hema gabonolo ka go ba fa moya wa oksetšene gore o dire gore meelamoya ya bona e dule e bulegile.

eng: the ventilator was designed by the council for scientific and industrial research (csir) in collaboration with a number of local partners and will be rolled out nationwide to patients showing respiratory distress in the early phase of covid19 infection.
nso: sethušagohema se hlamilwe ke ba council for scientific and industrial research (csir) ka tšhomišano le e tšwelapele letlakaleng la 2o boloke afrika borwammogo re ka fenya coronaviruso bolokeg batšeakarolo ba se bakae ba mo gae, gomme e tla abelwa balwetši go phatlalala le naga bao ba nago le mathata a go hema mo legatong la mathomo la phetelo ya covid19.

eng: "the air a person normally breaths has a 23 percent concentration of oxygen.
nso: "moya woo motho ao hemago o na le dipersente tše 23 tša oksetšene.

eng: the cpap ventilator can pump a higher amount of oxygen, helping a person breathe.
nso: sethušagohema sa cpap se kgona go pompa oksetšene e ntšhi, gomme ya thuša motho go hema.

eng: the cpap pumps continuous concentrated oxygen.
nso: cpap e pompa oksetšene e sa emiše.

eng: you can increase or decrease the amount of oxygen one is breathing in," says executive manager of csir future production: manufacturing martin sanne.
nso: o ka oketša goba wa fokotša bontšhi bja oksetšene yeo motho a e hemago," gwa realo molaodiphethiši wa csir future production: manufacturing, elego martin sanne.

eng: patients using the ventilator are connected via a face mask.
nso: balwetši bao ba šomišago sethušagohema ba se lokelwa maskeng woo ba tla bego ba o apere oksetšene e gogwa go tšwa tankeng ya kgase gomme ya hlakantšhwa le moya wa tlhago ka gare ga sethušagohema, gomme go tloga moo o romelwa maskeng gomme wa hemelwa ka gare ke molwetši.

eng: oxygen is drawn from an oxygen gas tank and is mixed with natural air in the ventilator, from where it is transmitted to the mask and breathed in by the patient.
nso: sanne o bolela gore godimo ga go pompa moya wa go ba le oksetšene, cpap e thuša gape balwetši gore ba hemele ka ntle.

eng: the cpap device can be used in both hightech clinical environments and temporary settings, such as field hospitals and quarantine facilities.
nso: sedirišwa sa cpap se ka šomišwa mafelong a tša maphelo a theknolotši ya godimo gape le ka mafelong a nakwana a bjalo ka maokelo a nakwana le mafelo a boipeelothoko.

eng: sanne says the csir will have produced 10 000 ventilators by the end of august.
nso: sanne a re csir e tla be e kgonne go dira dithušagohema tše 10 000 ge kgwedi ya phato e fihla mafelelong.

eng: working with siemens, simera, akacia, gabler, umoya and the university of cape town, the csir produced the cpap according to world health organisation standards.
nso: ka tšhomišano le siemens, simera, akacia, gabler, umoya le yunibesithi ya cape town, csir e tšweleditše cpap go ya le ka melawana ya mokgatlo wa lefase wa tša maphelo.

eng: the first batch of ventilators will be given to state hospitals experiencing pressure due to the unavailability of equipment to deal with covid19.
nso: dithušagohema tša mathomo di tla fiwa maokelo a mmušo ao a lego bothateng bja tlhokego ya didirišwa tša go lwantšhana le covid19.

eng: the csir started working on the cpap after the world began experiencing an extreme shortage in ventilators.
nso: csir e thomile go šomana le cpap morago ga gore lefase le itemogele tlhokego ye kgolo ya dithušagohema.

eng: help stop the spread of covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed our nation is con fronted by the gravest crisis in the history of our democracy.
nso: thuša go emiša go phatlalala ga covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed setšhaba sa gaborena se lebagane le bothata bjo bogolo historing ya temokrasi ya rena.

eng: for more than 120 days, we have succeeded in delaying the spread of a virus that is causing devastation across the globe.
nso: mo matšatšing a go feta a 120, re atlegile go diteleng go phatlalala ga baerase yeo e hlolago masetlapelo lefaseng ka bophara.

eng: but now, the surge in infections that we had been advised by our medical experts would come, has arrived.
nso: efela gabjale go keka ga diphetetšo, fao re kilego ra eletšwa ke ditsebi tša bongaka gore go tlo ba gona, go fihlile.

eng: more than a quarter of a million south africans have been infected with coronavirus, and we know that many more infections have gone undetected.
nso: palo ya go feta kotara ya milione ya maafrika borwa e fetetšwe ke coronavirus, gomme ebile re a tseba gore diphetetšo tše dintšhi di iphihlile.

eng: we are now recording over 12,000 new cases every day.
nso: gabjale go netefatšwa diphetetšo tše diswa tša go feta 12 000 tšatši le lengwe le le lengwe.

eng: since the start of the outbreak in march, at least 4,079 people have died from covid19.
nso: esale go tloga mola bolwetši bjo bo phulegago ka kgwedi ya hlakola, go hlokofetše batho ba 4 079 ba bolawa ke covid19.

eng: like the massive cold fronts that sweep into our country from the south atlantic at this time of year, there are few parts of the country that will remain untouched by the coronavirus.
nso: bjalo ka maphoto a magolo a go tonya ao a budulelago ka nageng ya rena go tšwa ka lewatleng la south atlantic mo nakong ye ya ngwaga, go na le dikarolo di se kae tša ka mo nageng tšeo di ka se fihlelelwego ke coronavirus.

eng: the coronavirus storm is far fiercer and more destructive than any we have known before.
nso: coronaviruse kotsi le go ba šoro kudu go feta efe goba efe yeo e kilego ya ba gona.

eng: it is stretching our resources and our resolve to their limits.
nso: e tloga e tlaralatša mošomo wa didirišwa tša rena le maikemišetšo ka go fetišiša.

eng: the surge of infections that our experts and scientists predicted over 3 months ago has now arrived.
nso: go keka ga diphetetšo, elego seo se akantšwego ke ditsebi le boramahlale ba borena kgweding tše tharo tšeo di fetilego, go fihlile.

eng: it started in the western cape and is now underway in the eastern cape and gauteng.
nso: go thomile ka kapa bodikela gomme gabjale go tsene ka kapa bohlabela le ka gauteng.

eng: yet, while infections rise exponentially, it is important to note that our case fatality rate of 1.5 percent is among the lowest in the world.
nso: le ge go le bjalo, ge diphetetšo di golela godimo ka lebelo, go bohlokwa go lemoga gore palo ya mahu ya dipersente tše 1.5 ke ye nngwe ya dipalo tša fasefase lefaseng ge e bapetšwa le ya lefase ya dipersente tše 4.4. go ba fasefase ga palo ya mahu ka nageng ya gaborena go hlotšwe ke maitemogelo le boikgafo bja bašomedi ba tša maphelo gape le magato a tšhoganetšo ao re a tšeerego go hlabolla mokgwa wa tša maphelo.

eng: even as most of our people have taken action to prevent the spread of the virus, there are others who have not.
nso: le ge bontšhi bja batho ba gaborena ba tšeere magato a go thibela phatlalalo ya baerase, go na le bao ba sego ba dira bjalo.

eng: there are some among us who ignore the regulations that have been passed to combat the disease.
nso: go na le ba bangwe bao ba hlokomologago melawana yeo e fetišitšwego ya go lwantšhana le bolwetši bjo.

eng: in the midst of such a pandemic, getting into a taxi without a face mask, gathering to meet friends, attending parties or even visiting family, can too easily spread the virus and cost lives.
nso: mo kgabagareng ya leuba le, go tsena ka gare ga thekisi o se wa apara maske, go kopana le bagwera, go ya meletlong goba gona go etela meloko, go ka phatlalatša baerase gabonolo gomme gwa ba le go lobja ga maphelo.

eng: this may be a disease that is caused by a virus, but it is spread by human conduct and behaviour.
nso: bjo e ka no ba e le bolwetši bjoo bo hlolwago ke baerase, efela bo phatlalatšwa ke mekgwa le maitshwaro a batho.

eng: through our own actions – as individuals, as families, as communities – we can and we must change the course of this pandemic in our country.
nso: ka maitshwaro a rena – re le batho, malapa le ditšhaba – re ka kgona ebile re swanetše re fetole mokgwaphatlalalo wa leuba le ka mo nageng.

eng: we need to wear a cloth mask that covers our nose and mouth whenever we leave home.
nso: re swanetše re apare maske wa lešela woo o khupetšago nko le molomo nako ye nngwe le ye nngwe ge re e tšwa ka gae.

eng: we must continue to regularly wash our hands with soap and water or sanitiser.
nso: re swanetše re tšwele pele go hlapa diatla ka meetse le sesepe goba sebolayaditwatši ka mehla.

eng: we must continue to clean and sanitise all surfaces in all public spaces.
nso: re swanetše re tšwele pele go hlwekiša le go bolaya ditwatši mabatong ka moka a mafelo a bohle.

eng: most importantly, we must keep a safe distance – of at least 2 metres – from other people.
nso: sa bohlokwa le go feta ke gore re swanetše re bule sekgoba sa dimitara tše pedi gare ga rena le batho ba bangwe.

eng: there is now emerging evidence that the virus may also be carried in tiny particles in the air in places that are crowded, closed or have poor air circulation.
nso: gabjale go na le bohlatse bjoo bo tšwelelago bja gore baerase ye e ka kgona le go fofa moyeng mo mafelong ao a tletšego batho ba bantšhi, ao a tswalegilego goba ao ka go ona moya o sa sepelego botse.

eng: for this reason we must immediately improve the indoor environment of public places where the risk of infection is greatest.
nso: ka lona lebaka le, re swanetše re hlabolle mafelo a setšhaba ao a tswalegilego ka pelapela, elego fao kotsi ya go fetelwa e lego godimo kudu.

eng: our decision to declare a nationwide lockdown prevented a massive early surge of infections when our health services were less prepared, which would have resulted in a far greater loss of lives.
nso: sephetho sa rena sa go tla ka kiletšo ya mosepelo ya bosetšhaba se thibetše phatlalalo ya diphetetšo mathomong ge ditirelo tša maphelo di be di se tša itokiša, elego seo se ka bego se hlotše tobo ye kgolo ya maphelo.

eng: in the time that we had, we have taken important measures to strengthen our health response.
nso: ka nako yeo re bilego le yona, re tšeere magato a bohlokwa go matlafatša mekgwa ya go ikarabela ya tša maphelo.

eng: we have conducted more than two million coronavirus tests and community health workers have done more than 20 million screenings.
nso: re šetše re dirile diteko tša coronavirus tša go feta dimilione tše pedi, gomme bašomedi ba tša maphelo ba šetše ba dirile diponego tša go feta dimilione tše 20. re dirile gore go be le mepete e 28 000 ya balwetši ba covid19 ka maokelong, gomme ebile re agile maokelo a nakwana go kgabaganya naga.

eng: we have made available almost 28,000 hospital beds for covid19 patients and have constructed functional field hospitals across the country.
nso: gabjale re na le mepete e 37 000 ya boipeelothoko mafelong a poraebete le a setšhaba go kgabaganya naga, gomme a itokišeditše go amogela bao ba sa kgonego go ipeela thoko ka magae.

eng: we have procured and delivered millions of items of personal protective equipment to hospitals, clinics and schools across the country to protect our frontline workers.
nso: re rekile le go aba dimilione tša didirišwa tša go itšhireletša maokelong, dikliniking le dikolong go kgabaganya naga, e lego tša go šireletša bašomedi bao ba šomago ka batho ba bantšhi.

eng: we have recruited and continue to recruit additional nurses, doctors and emergency health personnel.
nso: re thwetše ebile re sa thwala baoki, dingaka le bašomedi ba tša tšhoganetšo ba tlaleletšo.

eng: we continue to make progress in our efforts to deal with covid 19, but our greatest challenge still lies ahead.
nso: re tšwela pele go ba le tšwelopele mo maitekelong a rena a go lwantšha covid19, efela tlhotlo ye kgolo e sa etla.

eng: across all provinces, we are working to further increase the number of general ward and critical beds available for covid19 patients.
nso: re šoma go kgabaganya diprofense go oketša palo ya mepete ya ka diwateng le ka tlhokomelong yeo e tseneletšego re direla balwetši ba covid19.

eng: ward capacity is being freed up in a number of hospitals by delaying nonurgent care, the conversion of some areas of hospitals into additional ward space and the erection or expansion of field hospitals.
nso: sekgoba se a bulwa ka maokelong a mmalwa ka go se amogele balwetši bao ba sa hlokego thušo ya tšhoganetšo.

eng: we are working to increase supplies of oxygen, ventilators and other equipment for those who will need critical care, including by diverting the supply of oxygen from other purposes.
nso: go fetolwa gape le mafelo a mangwe ka maokelong go ba diwate tša tlaleletšo, gape le go agwa goba go oketšwa ga maokelo a nakwana.

eng: we are deploying digital technologies to strengthen the identification, tracing and isolation of contacts, and to provide support to those who test positive.
nso: re šoma go oketša kabo ya oksetšene, dithušagohema le didirišwa tše dingwe bakeng sa bao ba tlo hlokago tlhokomelo yeo e tseneletšego, go balwa le kabo ya oksetšene bakeng sa mabaka a mangwe.

eng: as we now approach the peak of infections, we need to take extra precautions and tighten existing measures to slow down the rate of transmission.
nso: re diriša ditheknolotši tša titšithale go matlafatša taetšo, go nyakana gape le go beela thoko balwetši, le go thekga bao diteko tša bona di laetšago ba fetetšwe.

eng: regulations on the wearing of masks will be strengthened.
nso: melawana ya mabapi le go apara dimaske e tla thatafatšwa.

eng: employers, shop owners and managers, public transport operators, and managers and owners of any other public building are now legally obliged to ensure that anyone entering their premises or vehicle must be wearing a mask.
nso: bengmešomo, bengmabenkele le balaodi, baotledi ba dinamelwa tša bohle, gape le balaodi le beng ba meago efe goba efe ya setšhaba, gabjale ba tlamegile semolao go netefatša gore yo mongwe le yo mongwe yoo a tsenago ka moagong goba ka senamelweng sa bona o swanetše go ba a apere maske.

eng: taxis undertaking local trips will now be permitted to increase their capacity to 100 percent, while long distance taxis will not be allowed to exceed 70 percent occupancy, on condition that new risk mitigation protocols related to masks, vehicle sanitising and open windows are followed.
nso: dithekisi tšeo di tšeago maeto a kgauswi di a dumelelwa go rwala go fihlela dipersenteng tše lekgolo, mola tša maeto a matelele di se tša dumelelwa go feta dipersente tše masomešupa, gomme gona fao go latelwe melawana e meswa ya mabapi le dimaske, go bolaya ditwatši ka dinamelweng gape le go bula mafasetere.

eng: there is now clear evidence that the resumption of alcohol sales has resulted in substantial pressure being put on hospitals, including trauma and icu units, due to motor vehicle accidents, violence and related trauma.
nso: gabjale go na le bohlatse bjoo bo tletšego bja gore thekišo ya dinotagi e hlotše kgatelelo ye kgolo go maokelo, go akaretšwa le ka diyuniting tša maemo a tšhoganetšo le tša tlhokomelo yabao ba bakwago le badimo ka baka la dikotsi tša difatanaga, dikgaruru le mathata a go sepelelana le tšona.

eng: we have therefore decided that in order to conserve hospital capacity, the sale, dispensing and distribution of alcohol will be suspended with immediate effect.
nso: ka fao, re tšeere sephetho sa gore, go re re kgone go lota sekgoba seo se šetšego se le gona ka maokelong, gona thekišo, kabo le phatlalatšo ya dinotagi e tla fegwa go tloga gonabjalebjale.

eng: as an additional measure to reduce the pressure on hospitals, a curfew will be put in place between the hours of 9pm and 4am.
nso: bjalo ka legato la tlaleletšo la go fokotša tlalelo ya maokelo, ga go na motho yoo a swanetšego go ba ka ntle mebileng go tloga ka iri ya senyane bošego go fihla ka iri ya bone ka masa.

eng: we are taking these measures fully aware that they impose unwelcome restrictions on people’s lives.
nso: re tšea magato a re tseba gabotse gore ga a amogelege ebile a bea mapheko maphelong a batho, efela a swanetše gore a tšewe gore re kgone go feta sehloa sa bolwetši.

eng: there is no way that we can avoid the coronavirus storm.
nso: ga go na ka mokgwa woo re ka efogago lephoto la coronavirus, efela re ka kgona go fokotša tshenyo yeo le ka e hlolago maphelong a rena.

eng: crew juliet firefighter shares her story dale hes young firefighter vuyiseka arendse (26) is part of crew juliet, south africa’s first allfemale wildland firefighting team.
nso: rasetimamollo wa crew juliet o hlaloša taba ya gagwe dale hes basadi ba swanetše ba be dipulamadibogo, gwa realo rasetimamollo.

eng: her strength and determination to make a name for herself in the maledominated world of firefighting is a true inspiration to all women.
nso: rasetimamollo wa moswa, vuyiseka arendse (26), ke karolo ya crew juliet, elego sehlopha sa mathomo sa borasetimamollo ba basadi feela sa go lwa le mello ya mašokeng.

eng: arendse grew up in the small western cape town of beaufort west.
nso: arendse o goletše torotswaneng ya beaufort west ka kapa bodikela.

eng: after school, she tried studying at a college in oudtshoorn, but decided to move back home to support her family.
nso: ge a se no fetša sekolo, o lekile go ithuta kholetšheng ka oudtshoorn, efela a tšea sephetho sa go boela gae go hlokomela lapa labo.

eng: she worked at a supermarket for a while, but then firefighting caught her eye.
nso: o šomile lebenkelengkgoparara nakwana, efela botimamollo bo ile bja mo goga mahlo.

eng: "i saw the firefighters in their uniforms and the big red trucks.
nso: "ke bone borasetimamollo ba apere diyunifomo tša bona ka ditheraka tše kgolo tše dihwibidu.

eng: i immediately became interested and wanted to find out more," says arendse.
nso: ka pelapela ka ba le kgahlego gomme ka nyaka go tseba kudu ka seo," gwa realo arendse.

eng: arendse was one of the graduates of the western cape government’s chrysalis academy youth development programme in 2016. after the programme, she worked at the fire station in beaufort west, earning only r1 900 per month.
nso: arendse e be e le yo mongwe wa dialoga tša lenaneo la tlhabollo ya baswa ya chrysalis academy ya mmušo wa kapa bodikela ka 2016. morago ga lenaneo leo, o o ile a šoma setišing sa botimamollo sa ka beaufort west gomme a gola feela r1 900 ka kgwedi.

eng: but then she came across an opportunity offered by ncc environmental services last year.
nso: efela o ile a kopana le monyetla woo o tšwago go ba ncc environmental services ngwagola.

eng: "i was at chrysalis academy as a facilitator when ncc came to talk to the students about the opportunity to apply for training for the first allfemale wildland firefighting team.
nso: "ke be ke le go la chrysallis academy ke šoma bjalo ka monolofatši ge ncc e tla tla go tlo boledišana le baithuti ka ga monyetla wa go dira dikgopelo tša go tsenela tlhahlo ya sehlopha sa mathomo sa basadi feela sa botimamollo bja mašokeng.

eng: even though i was not one of the students, i was very interested and applied for the training, and i was accepted," arendse says.
nso: le ge ke be ke se yo mongwe wa baithuti, ke ile ka ba le kgahlego ye kgolo kudu gomme ka dira dikgopelo tša go tsenela tlhahlo, gomme ke ile ka atlega," gwa realo arendse.

eng: arendse went through the training, which combined theory and practical aspects of firefighting.
nso: arendse o ile a tsenela tlhahlo yeo e kopantšhitšego makala a botimamollo a teori le go šoma ka matsogo.

eng: "i learnt so much.
nso: "ke ithutile tše ntšhi kudu.

eng: for one, i didn’t know that there were firefighters tasked with putting out wildfires.
nso: sa mathomo, ke be ke sa tsebe gore go na le borasetimamollo bao mošomo wa bona elego go tima mello ya mašokeng.

eng: i had previously thought they only worked in towns to put out fires in buildings," she says.
nso: ke be ke nagana gore ba šoma feela ka ditoropong go tima mello ka meagong," a realo.

eng: arendse adds that it was an amazing feeling to pass the training and become part of the first allfemale firefighting team of its kind.
nso: arendse o tlaleletša ka gore o kwele bose kudu ge a tšwelela tlhahlong le go ba karolo ya sehlopha sa mathomo sa moswananoši sa borasetimamollo ba basadi feela.

eng: "i felt very excited, especially because when i had told people i wanted to be a firefighter, many of them said i could not do it because i am a woman and would not cope with the job.
nso: "ke be ke thabile kudu, kudu ka gore ge ke be ke botša batho gore ke nyaka go ba rasetimamollo, bontšhi ba rile nka se kgone ka ge ke le mosadi gomme nka se kgonane le boima bja mošomo.

eng: this pushed me to show them that i can actually do it, not only for myself but for the rest of the women in south africa.
nso: se se nkgoromeditše go ba bontšha gore le nna nka kgona, esego feela bakeng sa ka empa le bakeng sa basadi ka moka ka afrika borwa.

eng: "it was my first full 24hour shift and the first time we were working with all the other male firefighters.
nso: ""e be e le šifithi ya ka ya mathomo ya bošego le mosegare ebile e le la mathomo re šoma le borasetimamollo ba bangwe ba banna.

eng: it was tiring and very hot in our protective gear but we finished the job and the feeling afterwards was very rewarding.
nso: go be go lapiša ebile le yunifomo e fiša kudu empa re kgonne go fetša mošomo gomme maikutlo a ka morago ga moo e be e le a kgotsofalo.

eng: "arendse encourages the women of south africa to never underestimate themselves.
nso: "arendse o hlohleletša basadi ba afrika borwa gore ba se ke ba inyatša.

eng: "don’t be defined by what people say you can and can’t do."
nso: "o se ke wa ya ka mantšu a batho ge ba re o ka kgona eng, o ka se kgone eng."

eng: celebrating women through economic inclusion vukuzenzele unnamed in august south africa celebrates women’s month.
nso: go keteka basadi ka go ba go keteka basadi ka go ba akaretša ekonomingakaretša ekonoming vukuzenzele unnamed ka phato afrika borwa e keteka kgwedi ya basadi.

eng: this occasion marks the anniversary of the day in 1956 when 20,000 women marched to the union buildings – a great sea of womankind speaking many languages, from different places and of all races.
nso: tiragalo ye e dira matswalo a letšatši ka 1956 ge basadi ba 20 000 ba matšhetša union buildings – basadi ba bantši ba go bolela malema a go fapana, go tšwa mafelong a go fapana gomme ba mehlobo ka moka.

eng: they were united in their demand for an end to the dreaded pass laws and for their right to live in freedom.
nso: ba be ba kopane ka senyakwa sa bona sa go fediša melao ya dipasa le tokelo ya bona ya go phela ka tokologo.

eng: the status and position of women in south africa today is vastly different to that faced by our mothers and grandmothers in 1956. we have come a long way in realising a south africa that is nonracial, nonsexist, democratic, prosperous and free.
nso: maemo le kemo ya basadi ka afrika borwa lehono a fapana kudu le ao bommago rena le bokoko a rena ba bego ba phela ka fase ga wona ka 1956. re tšwa kgole gore re be le afrika borwa ya go hloka semorafe, ya go hloka kgethologanyo ya bong, ya go huma gape yeo e lokologilego.

eng: there has been real progress in improving the lives of south african women in the economy, in the political sphere and in public life.
nso: go bile le tšwelopele kudu mo go kaonafatšeng maphelo a basadi ba afrika borwa go ekonomi, lekala la dipolotiki le go bophelo bja setšhaba.

eng: women still face discrimination, harassment and violence, and bear the greatest brunt of poverty.
nso: basadi ba sa lebane le kgethollo, tlhorišo le dikgaruru, gomme ba sa phela ka bohloki.

eng: if we are to truly realise the promise of our constitution we have to tackle the economic and financial exclusion that makes women more vulnerable to abuse and violence.
nso: ge e le gore ka nnete re nyaka go diragatša tshepišo ya molaotheo wa rena re swanetše go lwantšha dikgato tse di dirago gore basadi ba se be le letseno le tšhelete moo go dirago gore ba ikhwetše ba kgotleletše go hlorišwa le go bethwa.

eng: we have joined a groundbreaking campaign that links us to global efforts to achieve gender equality by 2030. generation equality is an ambitious and transformative agenda to end discrimination and violence against women and for their equal participation in political, social and economic life.
nso: re tsenetše lesolo la go ribolla leswika leo le re amantšhago le maitapišo a lefase a go fihlelela tekatekano ya bong ka 2030. tekatekano ya meloko ke agenda ya tlhohleletšo le phetogo go fediša kgethollo le dikgaruru kgahlanong le basadi le bana le go kgatha tema ka go lekana bophelong bja dipolotiki, leago le ekonomi.

eng: as part of this campaign, we have joined two ‘action coalitions’, one for economic justice and rights and another against genderbased violence.
nso: bjalo ka karolo ya lesolo le, re kopantše ‘ditirišano tša twantšho’ tše pedi, yenngwe ke ya toka le ditokelo tša ekonomi ge ye nngwe e le ya kgahlanong le dikgaruru tše di ekadilego ka bong.

eng: both of these themes are critical to our own national agenda.
nso: bobedi ditabakgolo tše di bohlokwa go agenda ya rena ya bosetšhaba.

eng: eleven months since the emergency response action plan to combat genderbased violence and femicide was implemented we have made progress in expanding support and care to survivors, and progress is being made in legal reforms to afford them greater protection.
nso: dikgwedi tše 11 go tloga mola leano la twantšho la go arabela la tšhoganetšo go lwantšha dikgaruru tšeo di ikadilego ka bong le dipolao tša basadi (gbvf) ke banna le phethagatšwago go bonagetše tšwelopele go godiša thekgo le tlhokomelo ya bao ba phologilego, gomme go na le tšwelopele go kaonafatšeng molao go ba fa tšhireletšo ye kgolo.

eng: during the month of august, we begin the implementation of the national strategic plan to combat genderbased violence and femicide.
nso: mo kgweding ya phato, re thoma ka phethagatšo ya leano la peakanyo la bosetšhaba go lwantšha gbvf ke banna.

eng: a key aspect of the plan is on ensuring greater women’s financial inclusion.
nso: ntlha ya bohlokwa ya leano le ke go kgonthiša gore basadi ba bantši ba fiwa kudu menyetla mo ditšheleteng.

eng: this is because economic inequality and social inequality are interconnected.
nso: se ke ka gore go se lekalekane ga ekonomi le go se lekalekane ga leago go a sepelelana.

eng: the economic status of women in south africa makes them more vulnerable to abuse.
nso: maemo a basadi ka afrika borwa a ba dira gore ba be kotsing ya go hlorišwa.

eng: we must therefore scale up support for women to enable them to become financially independent.
nso: re swanetše go oketša thekgo ya basadi go ba kgontšha gore ba itirele tšhelete ya bona.

eng: we have made a number of commitments under generation equality that will be given effect to through the national strategic plan.
nso: re dirile maikgafo a mmalwa ka fase ga tekatekano ya moloko yeo e tla tšweletšago dipoelo ka leano la peakanyo ya bosetšhaba.

eng: firstly, we are going to drive women’s economic inclusion through public procurement.
nso: sa mathomo, re ya go tsentšha basadi mererong ya ekonomi ka go ba abela dithendara.

eng: we have set the target of ensuring that at least 40 percent of goods and services procured by public entities are sourced from womenowned businesses.
nso: re beile selebanywa sa go kgonthiša gore bonnyane dithoto le ditirelo tša go lekana 40% tšeo di rekilwego ke makala a setšhaba di tšwe dikgwebong tša basadi.

eng: secondly, we are going to scale up support for womenowned smmes and for women who work in the informal sector or are unemployed.
nso: sa bobedi, re ya go oketša thekgo go dismme tša basadi le go basadi bao ba nago le dikgwebo tša mo mebileng goba bao ba sa šomego.

eng: this will include engagement with the financial sector to make financial services accessible and affordable for women.
nso: se se tla akaretša go boledišana le makala a ditšhelete go dira gore ditirelo tša ditšhelete di fihlelelege le go rekega go basadi.

eng: thirdly, we want to ensure more women have access to productive assets such as land.
nso: sa boraro, re nyaka go kgonthiša gore basadi ba bantši ba na le dithoto tša bohlokwa go swana le naga.

eng: it is essential that women are beneficiaries of the accelerate land reform programme.
nso: go bohlokwa gore basadi e be baholegi ba lenaneo le potlakišitšwego la poelo ya mafase.

eng: it is significant that of the r75 million in covid19 relief earmarked for farming input vouchers 53 percent of the beneficiaries will be rural women.
nso: go bohlokwa gore go r75 milione ya diboutšhara tšeo di beetšwego kimollo ya covid19 ya kabo ya temo 53% ya baholegi e tla ba basadi ba magaeng.

eng: we must ensure that women subsistence and smallscale farmers continue to receive support beyond the pandemic.
nso: re swanetše go kgonthiša gore basadi ba balemi ba ka gae le ba bannyane ba tšwela pele go amogela thekgo ka morago ga leuba.

eng: fourthly, we want to ensure that women are protected from genderbased violence in the workplace.
nso: sa bone, re nyaka go kgonthiša gore basadi ba šireletšwa go dikgaruru tšeo di ikadilego ka bong mo mošomong.

eng: in this regard, we will be working at a national and regional level towards the ratification of the ilo convention on violence and harassment in the workplace.
nso: ka tsela yeo re tla ba re šoma legatong la bosetšhaba le la selete go tumelelano ya kopano ya ilo ka ga dikgaruru le tlhorišo mošomong.

eng: it is said that freedom is not given, but taken.
nso: go thwe tokologo ga e fiwe, eupša e a tšewa.

eng: the emancipation of women is only words on paper unless it is matched by commitment from all sectors of society.
nso: tokologo ya basadi ke mantšu fela ao a lego letlakaleng ntle le ge e ka bapetšwa ke boikgafo go tšwa go makala ka moka a setšhaba.

eng: as we prepare for the reconstruction of our economy in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, we have said that we cannot simply return to where we were before the outbreak of the virus.
nso: ge re beakanya kagolefsa ya ekonomi ya rena mo tlhohlong ya leuba la coronavirus , re rile re ka se boele moo re bego re le gona pele ga go phulega ga baerase.

eng: we must build a fundamentally different economy which, among other things, substantially improves the material position of women.
nso: re swanetše go aga ekonomi ye bohlokwa ya go fapana le yeo re bego re na le yona yeo, gare ga dilo tše dingwe, e kaonafatšago maemo a bohlokwa a basadi.

eng: this means that our investment in infrastructure must support not only the development of local industry, but also womenowned businesses.
nso: se se ra gore peeletšo ya rena ka mananeokgoparara ga se ya swanela go thekga fela kaonafatšo ya diintasteri tša gae, eupša le dikgwebo tša basadi.

eng: it must deliberately create employment opportunities for women in all stages of planning, financing, building and maintaining infrastructure.
nso: e swanetše go hlola dibaka tša mešomo mo magatong ka moka a peakanyo, go thekga ka ditšhelete, go aga le go hlokomela mananeokgoparara.

eng: by the same measures, as we scale up our public employment programmes, we must ensure that young women in particular are identified as participants.
nso: ka tekanyo ya go swana ge re oketša thekgo ya mananeo a mešomo ya setšhaba, re swanetše go kgonthiša gore makgarebe kudu ba swanetše go ba bakgathatema.

eng: in addition to an income, these programmes will provide them with an opportunity to acquire some of the skills and experience necessary to enter the mainstream economy.
nso: godimo ga go hwetša letseno, mananeo a a tla ba fa sebaka go hwetša mabokgoni a mangwe le maitemogelo ao a hlokegago go kgatha tema ekonoming ye kgolo.

eng: as much as it is government’s responsibility to provide economic opportunities for women and create an enabling framework for advancing gender equality, everyone in society needs to play their part.
nso: le ge e le maikarabelo a mmušo go aba dibaka tša ekonomi go basadi le go hlola tlhako ya go kgontšha go tšwetša pele tekatekano ya bong, mang le mang mo setšhabeng o swanetše go kgatha tema ya gagwe.

eng: businesses must support womenowned enterprises in the procurement of goods and services.
nso: dikgwebo di swanetše go thekga dikgwebo tša basadi ka go reka mo go tšona dithoto le ditirelo.

eng: they should employ more women and appoint more women to management positions.
nso: di swanetše go thwala basadi ba bantši gomme ba thwale basadi ba bantši maemong a bolaodi.

eng: this is all the more important considering that the private sector’s record on genderrepresentation at management level lags behind that of the public sector.
nso: se se bohlokwa kudu go lebeletšwe gore rekoto ya lekala la praebete mo go kemedi ya bong legatong la taolo e šaletše morago go ya lekala la setšhaba.

eng: this is an issue that is repeatedly raised in engagements i have had with a number of women’s business organisations.
nso: ye ke taba yeo e tšweletšwago gantši mo dipoledišanong tšeo ke bilego le tšona le mekgatlo ye mmalwa ya dikgwebo tša basadi.

eng: by equal measure, we must eliminate gender disparities in pay for men and women, and give effect to the principle of equal pay for equal work contained in the employment equity act.
nso: gore re be le tekatekano re swanetše go fediša setlwaedi sa megolo ya go se lekane go ya ka gore motho ke monna goba mosadi gomme re lefa batho ba ba dirilego mošomo wa go swana ka go lekana go ya ka molao wa tekatekano ya mošomo.

eng: women must also be protected from harassment and discrimination in the workplace.
nso: basadi ba swanetšwe go šireletšwa go tlhorišo le kgethologanyo mošomong.

eng: it is up to transport operators, university administrators, school governing bodies and religious organisations to create conditions for women and girls to travel, study and worship in safety.
nso: ke maikarabelo a basepediši ba dinamelwa, balaodi ba diyunibesithi, makgotlataolo a dikolo le mekgatlo ya sedumedi go hlola maemo a a bolokegilego go basadi le basetsana go ka tšea maeto, go ya dikolong le go ya dikerekeng.

eng: we must forge ahead with our efforts to eradicate chauvinism, sexism and patriarchy.
nso: re swanetše go tšwela pele ka maitapišo a rena a go fediša go nyatšwa ga basadi ke banna, kgethollo ya basadi ke banna le go dira banna dihlogo.

eng: it is these attitudes that enable the oppression of women.
nso: ke mekgwa ye yeo e dirago gore go be le kgatelelo ya basadi.

eng: it is up to us – both men and women – to affirm that a woman’s value, position and opinions are no less than that of a man.
nso: go tšwa go rena – bobedi banna le basadi – go kgonthiša gore mohola wa mosadi, maemo le dikgopolo ga di fetwe ke tša monna.

eng: it is up to us as parents and grandparents to treat and raise our sons and our daughters the same.
nso: ke maikarabelo a rena bjalo ka batswadi le bokoko le borakgolo go swara le go godiša barwa le barwedi ba rena go swana.

eng: it is up to us as men to reject and speak out against genderbased violence wherever we see it, even if it is against our friends, fathers or brothers.
nso: go tšwa go rena bjalo ka banna go gana le go bolela kgahlanong le ditiragalo tša gbv ge re di bona, le ge e le gore di dirwa ke bagwera ba rena, bopapa ba rena goba bobuti ba rena.

eng: let us be the generation that ends the oppression of women in all its forms, in our lifetime.
nso: a re beng moloko woo o fedišago kgatelelo ya basadi ka mekgwa ya yona ka moka, mo maphelong a rena.

eng: the brave generation of 1956 marched for us all.
nso: moloko wa bagale wa 1956 o matšheditše rena ka moka.

eng: back to work after covid19 a full guide allison cooper when can you return to work if you have tested positive for the coronavirus (covid19)?
nso: go boela mošomong ka morago ga go kaonafala bolwetšing bja covid19 allison cooper naa o ka boela mošo mong neng ge o fe tetšwe ke coronavirus (covid19)?

eng: the national institute for communicable diseases has the answers you need.
nso: institute ya bosetšhaba ya malwetši a go fetela e na le dikarabo tšeo o di hlokago.

eng: when i test positive for covid19, how long do i have to stay in isolation?
nso: ge ke fetetšwe ke ge ke fetetšwe ke covid19covid19 , , ke swanetše go dula nako ye ke swanetše go dula nako ye kaakang ke ipeetše thoko?

eng: people who test positive for covid19, but don’t have any symptoms, must remain in isolation at home or in a government isolation facility for 10 days, from the day they receive their positive test result.
nso: batho bao ba fetetšwego ke covid19 , eupša ba se na maswao, ba swanetše go ipeela thoko ka gae goba ka lefelong la mmušo leo le diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase lebaka la matšatši a 10, go tloga ka letšatši leo ba amogelago dipoelo tša gore ba fetetšwe ke baerase.

eng: those who have mild symptoms must remain in isolation at home or in a government isolation facility for 10 days, from the day their symptoms start.
nso: bao ba nago le maswao a mannyane ba swanetše go ipeela thoko ka gae goba ka lefelong la mmušo leo le diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase lebaka la matšatši a 10, go tloga ka letšatši leo maswao a bona a thomilego.

eng: those who have severe disease, who have to go to hospital, must remain in isolation for 10 days, from when they are stable and don’t need oxygen anymore.
nso: bao ba nago le maswao a mašoro, bao ba swanelago go ya bookelong, ba swanetše go ipeela thoko matšatši a 10, go tloga ge ba le kaone ba se sa nyaka oksetšene.

eng: how can a covid19 positive people transfer the disease to others?
nso: naa batho bao ba fetetšwego ke naa batho bao ba fetetšwego ke covid19covid19 ba ka fetetša bolweba ka fetetša bolwetši go batho ba bangwe bjang?

eng: according to health minister zweli mkhize, most people who have a mild infection can spread the virus for between seven to 12 days.
nso: go ya ka tona ya maphelo zweli mkhize, batho ba bantši bao ba nago le maswao a mannyane ba ka phatlalatša baerase nako ya gare ga matšatši a šupa le a 12. le ge go le bjalo, batho bao ba lwalago kudu ba ka fetetša ba bangwe gomme ba phatlalatša baerase go ba bangwe nako ye telele.

eng: do i have to have another covid19 test, proving that i am negative, before i return to work?
nso: naa ke swanetše go dira diteko naa ke swanetše go dira diteko tše dingwe tša tše dingwe tša covid19covid19 , tšeo , tšeo di bontšhago gore ga ke sa na di bontšhago gore ga ke sa na yona, pele ke boela mošomong?

eng: no.
nso: aowa.

eng: retesting people who have experienced mild illness and have recovered is not recommended.
nso: go dira diteko gape go batho bao ba itemogetšego maswao a mannyane gomme ba kaonafetše ga go bohlokwa.

eng: a person is considered safe to return to work and come out of isolation if they are no longer infectious.
nso: motho o tšewa go ba a bolokegile go boela mošomong ge a feditše nako ya go ipeela thoko e bile a se sa hlwa a kgona go fetetša ba bangwe.

eng: this means they developed their first symptoms more than 10 days ago and have not had any symptoms for at least three days.
nso: seo se ra gore o bile le maswao a gagwe a mathomo matšatši a 10 a go feta gomme ga se a ba le maswao bonnyane matšatši a mararo.

eng: in most cases, employees can return to work without testing again if: they have completed 10 days of mandatory quarantine or selfisolation.
nso: ka dinako tše dintši, bašomi ba ka boela mošomong ntle le go dira diteko gape: ba phethile matšatši a 10 a go beelwa thoko ga kgapeletšo goba go ipeela thoko.

eng: those who had moderate or severe symptoms undergo a medical evaluation.
nso: bao ba bilego le maswao a magareng goba a mašoro ba ya tekolong ya kalafo.

eng: they continue to practice personal hygiene and social distancing.
nso: ba tšwela pele go hlapa le go se batamelane le batho ba bangwe.

eng: the employer monitors the worker to ensure they do not regress.
nso: bengmošomo ba lekola bašomi go kgonthiša gore ga ba boele morago.

eng: they wear a mask, from the date of diagnosis for at least 21 days.
nso: ba apara sešira molomo le dinko, go tloga ka letšatši la phekolo sebaka se ka bago matšatši a 21. matšatši a 21. diteko di bontšhitše gore ga ke diteko di bontšhitše gore ga ke na bolwetši bjo eupša ke sa na na bolwetši bjo eupša ke sa na le maswao.

eng: what now?
nso: bjale go direga eng?

eng: it is possible to get a false negative test result.
nso: go a kgonagala go hwetša dipoelo tšeo di fošagetšego tša gore ga o na bolwetši bjo.

eng: this means that your first test could be negative, but you could test positive at a later stage.
nso: se se ra gore diteko tša mathomo di ka bontšha gore ga o na bolwetši bjo, eupša diteko tša ka morago di ka bontšha gore o na le bona.

eng: if you continue to have covid19 symptoms contact your healthcare professional.
nso: ge o ka tšwela pele go ba le maswao a covid19 o ikgokaganye le setsebi sa tlhokomelo ya maphelo.

eng: what if i am still showing symptoms after 10 days?
nso: naa go direga eng ge ke sa naa go direga eng ge ke sa bontšha maswao ka morago bontšha maswao ka morago ga matšatši a 10?

eng: it is common for patients to continue to have symptoms for longer than 10 days.
nso: go tlwaelegile gore balwetši ba tšwele pele go ba le maswao go feta matšatši a 10. go kaonafala mo go feletšego go ka tšea dibeke tše mmalwa.

eng: if you still have symptoms, seek advice from your healthcare professional.
nso: ge o sa na le maswao, nyaka maele go setsebi sa gago sa maphelo.

eng: for more information about covid19, visit the national institute for communicable diseases’ website at www.
nso: go hwetša tshedimošo ka botlalo ka ga covid19 , eya wepsaeteng ya sehlongwa sa bosetšhaba sa malwetši a go fetela go www.

eng: nicd.
nso: nicd.

eng: ac.
nso: ac.

eng: za, the covid19 free website at coronavirus.
nso: za, wepsaete ya go se lefelwe ya covid19 go coronavirus.

eng: managing covid19: at home and at a dedicated facility allison cooper if you are not able to selfisolate, call the national coronavirus hotline at 0800 029 999 for more information about your closest isolation or quarantine facility.
nso: go laola covid19 : ka gae le ka mafelong ao a diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase ye allison cooper ge o sa kgone go ipeela thoko, leletša mogala wa coronavirus wa bosetšhaba go 0800 029 999 go hwetša tshedimošo ye nngwe ka ga lefelo leo le diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase goba ka mafelong ao a diretšwego go beela batho thoko.

eng: it’s extremely important to separate yourself from others, either at home or at a free isolation facility, if you have tested positive for covid19.
nso: go bohlokwa kudu go kudu go arogana le ba bangwe, e ka ba ka gae goba ka lefelong arogana le ba bangwe, e ka ba ka gae goba ka lefelong le le diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase ye la go beela batho thoko le le diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase ye la go beela batho thoko la go se lefelwe, ge diteko di bontšha gore o fetetšwe ke la go se lefelwe, ge diteko di bontšha gore o fetetšwe ke covid19covid19 .

eng: many south af ricans who test positive for the coronavirus (covid19) cannot selfisolate because their home is too small for them to live and sleep in a room that’s not shared by anyone else.
nso: maafrika borwa a mantši ao a fetetšwego ke coronavirus (covid19) ba ka se kgone go ipeela thoko ka gore magae a bona ke a mannyane gomme ga ba na phapoši yeo e sa abelanwego le ba bangwe yeo go yona ba ka kgonago go dula le go robala go yona ba le tee.

eng: government has ensured that dedicated isolation facilities are available for people who have tested positive, and dedicated quarantine facilities are available for people who are still waiting for their test results.
nso: mmušo o kgonthišitše gore mafelo ao a diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase ye a gona go thuša batho bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase, gomme mafelo ao a diretšwego go beela batho thoko a gona go thuša batho bao ba sa emetšego dipoelo.

eng: both services are free.
nso: ditirelo ka moka ga di lefelwe.

eng: according to dr marlin mccay, a general practitioner based in florida on the west rand, the first thing you need to do when diagnosed with covid19 is to limit the spread of the infection.
nso: go ya ka ngaka marlin mccay, ngaka ya malwetši a go fapana yo a šomelago florida ka west rand, selo sa mathomo seo o swanetšego go se dira ge o dirilwe diteko gomme go hweditšwe o na le covid19 ke go fokotša lebelo la go phatlalala ga diphetelo.

eng: "you want to protect your family," he says.
nso: "selo se o se nyakago ke go šireletša lapa la gago," a realo.

eng: to do this, you need to go into isolation – either at home or at an isolation facility.
nso: go dira se, o swanela ke go ipeela thoko e ka ba ka gae goba ka mafelong ao a diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase ye.

eng: "if you are selfisolating it means you have to find a part of the house where you are totally cut off from the rest of the family.
nso: "ge o ipeetše thoko go ra gore o swanetše go hwetša karolo ya ntlo moo o sa hlakanego le batho ba bangwe ka lapeng.

eng: no one should come within three metres of you.
nso: ga go na yoo a swanetšego go batamela dimetara tše tharo kgauswi le wena.

eng: you must eat on your own; use your own cutlery and crockery; use your own bathroom, if possible; and make sure there’s no contact with anyone else in the family.
nso: o swanetše go ja o le tee; o be le malepola le dibjana tšeo di šomišwago ke wena o le tee; o be le phapoši ya gago ya go hlapela o le tee, ge go kgonega; gomme o kgonthiše gore ga o kopane le mang goba mang ka lapeng.

eng: "your doctor or primary care giver should help you with certain basic medications to ease most of the symptoms, especially things like body aches and pains, headache and fever.
nso: "ngaka ya gago goba mohlokomedi yo bohlokwa yoo a go abelago ka ditirelo tša maphelo o swanetše go go fa dihlare tše bohlokwa tše diretšwego go go fokoletša bontši bja maswao, kudu a go swana le mahlaba mmeleng le dihlabi, go opša ke hlogo le phišo.

eng: there are also some good vitamins one can use to stay healthy," he says.
nso: go na le gape divitamine tše dibotse tšeo motho a ka di šomišago gore a dule a phetše gabotse," a realo.

eng: it’s also important to get enough rest and drink enough water or clear fluids to make sure that your urine stays a pale clear colour.
nso: go bohlokwa gape go khutša nako ye e lekanego le go nwa meetse a mantši goba diela tšeo di sekilego go kgonthiša gore mohlapologo o dula o sekile.

eng: most people with mild illness will start feeling better within a week of the first symptoms, but it’s important to monitor your symptoms carefully.
nso: batho ba bantši bao ba sa lwalego kudu ba tla thoma go kaonafala morago ga beke go tloga nakong yeo ba thomilego go bona maswao a mathomo ka yona, eupša go bohlokwa go lekola maswao a gago gabotse.

eng: if you develop any emergency warning signs, such as trouble breathing, chest pain or pressure in your chest that does not go away, coughing up blood, becoming confused, severe sleepi ness or blue lips or face you must call an ambulance or go to hospital immediately.
nso: ge o ka ba le maswao a tšho ganetšo, go swana le mathata a go hema, dihlabi mafahleng goba kgatelelo mo mafahleng yeo e ganelelago, go gohlola madi, go hlakahlakana, go se robale gabotse go go šoro goba go ba le dipounama le sefahlego se se talalerata o swanetše go leletša ambulanse goba o ye bookelong ka bjako.

eng: for those who are not able to keep themselves away from others living in the home, government has setup free quarantine facilities around the country to keep you and your loved ones safe.
nso: mafelo ao a diretšwego go beela batho thokobao ba sa kgonego go ipeela thoko go bao ba dulago le bona ka gae, mmušo o beakantše mafelo ao a diretšwego go beela batho thoko nageng ka bophara gore wena le balapa la gago le bolokege.

eng: the western cape government recently published some comments from patients about its isolation facilities.
nso: mmušo wa profense ya kapa bodikela kgauswanyana o phatlaladitše ditshwayotshwayo tše di itšego go tšwa go balwetši ka ga mafelo ao a diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase.

eng: marie jantjies from witzenberg decided to follow healthcare workers’ advice and go to the isolation facility because her 97yearold mother lives with her and her children and she wanted to protect them.
nso: marie janties go tšwa witzenberg o tšere sephetho sa go latela keletšo ya bašomi ba tlhokomelo ya maphelo gomme a ya lefelong leo le diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase ka gore mmagwe wa mengwaga ye 97 o dula le yena le bana ba gagwe gomme o nyaka go ba šireletša.

eng: "i was treated very well.
nso: "ke swerwe gabotse kudu.

eng: the food was nice – even nicer than at home.
nso: dijo di be di le bose – go feta le tša ka gae.

eng: i realised i just had to stay positive.
nso: ke lemogile gore ke swanetše go dula ke nagana tše dibotse.

eng: i was anxious, but i prayed and tried to relax," she said.
nso: ke be ke tšhogile, eupša ka rapela ka leka gore ke lokologe," a realo.

eng: "that place can save lives!
nso: "lefelo leo le ka boloka maphelo!

eng: it really is the best," said john arnoldus, who recovered from covid19 at an isolation facility in drakenstein.
nso: le tloga e le le lekaone kudu," gwa realo john arnoldus, yoo a kaona fetšego go tšwa bolwetšing bja covid19 mo lefelong leo le diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase la drakenstein.

eng: "one of my friends was in quarantine at home and he struggled to recover on his own.
nso: "yo mongwe wa bagwera ba ka o be a ipeetše thoko ka gae gomme a swara bothata bja go kaonafala.

eng: i told him to contact the people who cared for me – that is the way to get better.
nso: ke bile ka mmotša gore a ikgokaganye le batho bao ba ilego ba nhlokomela – yeo ke tsela ya go kaonafala.

eng: the support of the medical staff and the manager there – that pulls you through," he said.
nso: thekgo ya bašomi ba kalafo le ya molaodi moo – ke yona e go dirago gore o tielele," a realo.

eng: arnoldus was initially hesitant to go to the isolation facility because of the wrong perception that if you go to a facility like this you will get sicker and die.
nso: arnoldus mathomong o be a tšhaba go ya lefelong leo le diretšwego go hlokomela bao ba fetetšwego ke baerase ka lebaka la kgopolo ya go fošagala ya gore ge o eya lefelong la go swana le le o tla lwala gomme wa hlokofala.

eng: "i expected the worst, but i was received so well.
nso: "ke be ke letetše tše šoro, eupša ke amogetšwe gabotse.

eng: let’s keep each other safe vukuzenzele unnamed our country has moved to alert level 2 in our response to the coronavirus pandemic.
nso: a re bolokegeng ka moka ga rena vukuzenzele unnamed naga ya gaborena e theošeditšwe go maemotemošo a bobedi mo magatong a rena a leuba la corona virus .

eng: this has come as a relief to all south africans who have had to live under stringent restrictions for the last five months.
nso: se se tlile bjalo ka kimollo go maafrika bo rwa ka moka bao ba ilego ba swanela ke go phela ka fase ga dikiletšo tše tiišeleditšwego letsogo dikgweding tše tlhano tša go feta.

eng: it is a sign of the progress we are making in reducing new infections and demand on our health facilities.
nso: maemo a ke taetšo ya kgatelopele yeo re e dirago go fokotša diphetelo tše diswa le tlalelo dinolofatšing tša rena tša maphelo.

eng: it is also a very important development as we strive to restart our economy.
nso: se sengwe ke gore ye ke kgatelopele ye bohlokwa kudu ge re le gare re kalokana le go thomiša ikonomi ya gaborena ka leswa.

eng: but it is too soon to celebrate.
nso: eupša e sale ka pela gore re ka keteka.

eng: we are still very much in the middle of a deadly pandemic that has taken over 11,000 lives in south africa alone.
nso: re sale ka gare ga leuba la go bolaya leo le tšeerego maphelo a 11 000 ka afrika borwa e le noši.

eng: at more than half a million confirmed cases, we still have the fifth highest number of infections in the world.
nso: ka diphe telo tšeo di netefaditšwego tša go feta seripa sa milione, re santše re nale palo ya godimodimo ya bohlano ya diphetelo lefaseng.

eng: and there is always a chance of a resurgence of the disease.
nso: e bile gape go nale kgonagalo ya go bowa gape ga bolwetši.

eng: if we ever need a stark reminder of the need for vigilance, we should look to recent events thousands of kilometres away in new zealand.
nso: ge eba re nyaka seo se ka re gopotšago gabotse ka bohlokwa ba go ntšha mahlo dinameng, re swanetše go lebelela ditiragalo tše hlagi lego malobanyana dikhilo mithara tše diketeteke kgole le rena go la new zealand.

eng: three months since the country was declared coronavirusfree, new zealand is once again under lockdown.
nso: dikgwedi tše tharo go tloga nakong ya ge naga yeo e tsebagaditšwe gore ga e na coronavirus , new zealand e tswaletše naga ka bophara gapegape.

eng: although the latest outbreak was of relatively few cases, the government swiftly reimposed lockdown restrictions.
nso: le ge e le gore go phulega ga diphetelo tšeo tša moragorago di be di se kaalo, mmušo o ile wa nanoga wa phethagatša gape dikiletšo tša go tswalelwa ga naga.

eng: similar restrictions have had to be reimposed in several parts of europe as they experience a ‘second wave’ of infections.
nso: dikiletšo tša go swana le tše di ile tša swanela ke go phethagatšwa ka leswa di karolong tše ntši tša yuropa ge naga ye e itemogela le photo la bobedi la diphetelo.

eng: these experiences show just how swiftly things can change when it comes to covid19.
nso: maitemogelo a a laetša ka fao dilo di ka fetogago ka lebelo ge go bolelwa ka covid19 .

eng: it is a wakeup call to any among us who may harbour illusions that we are even close to seeing the end of this grave public health emergency.
nso: se ke segopotšo go mang goba mang magareng ga rena yo a ka bego a na le kgopolo ye fošagetšego ya gore re kgauswi le go bona mafelelo a seemo sa mohuta wo se se mpe sa tšhoganyetšo maphelong a bohle.

eng: certainly, there are signs of hope.
nso: go ya nneteng, go nale dika tša go re tlišetša tshepho.

eng: the number of new confirmed cases in south africa continues to decline.
nso: palo ya diphetelo tše diswa tšeo di netefaditšwego mo afrika borwa e tšwelapele go theoga.

eng: at the peak of the disease just one month ago, we were recording around 12,000 new cases a day.
nso: nakong ya ge bolwetši bjo bo nyologetše godimodimo, re be re gatiša diphetelo tše diswa tša go balelwa 12 000 ka letšatši.

eng: this has dropped to an average of around 5,000 a day over the past week.
nso: palo ye e theogetše fase go fihla palogare ya go balelwa 5 000 ka letšatši bekeng ya go feta.

eng: our recovery rate stands at 80 percent.
nso: palo ya rena ya bao ba fodilego ke 80%.

eng: as the country moves to alert level 2, many restrictions on social and economic activity have been lifted.
nso: ge naga e theošetšwa go maemotemošo a bbedi, dikiletšo tše ntši ka ditira galo tša leago le tša ikonomi di fedišitšwe.

eng: with this comes increased risk of transmission.
nso: eupša se se tsamaišana le kotsi yeo e hlatlogilego ya diphetelo.

eng: we now need to manage this risk and ensure the gains we have made thus far in containing the pandemic’s spread are not reversed.
nso: go nyakega gore gabjale re laole kotsi ye le go netefatša gore diphenyo tšeo re di fihleletšego go fihla ka nako ye tša go bea phatlalalo ya leuba le ka fase ga taolo ga di bušetšwe morago.

eng: the greatest threat to the health of nation right now is complacency.
nso: kotsi ye kgolokgolo maphelong a setšhaba ka nako ye ke go iketla kudu.

eng: it may be that we are now permitted to meet friends and family, to visit entertainment venues, to travel for leisure and to consume alcohol in restaurants, bars and taverns.
nso: re a tseba gore gabjale re dumeletšwe go kopana le bagwera le ba malapa a rena, go etela mafelo a boithabišo, go tšea maeto a boiketlo le go nwa mabjala ka diresturenteng, dipareng le ka dithabeneng.

eng: but as the old adage goes, just because you can, doesn’t mean you should.
nso: eupša mmolelwana wa segologolo o re seo o se kgo nago ga go re o se dire.

eng: many people who have the coronavirus do not have symptoms and may not even know they are infected.
nso: batho ba bantši ba go ba le coronavirus ga ba laetše dika tša bolwetši ebile le bona ba kaba ba sa tsebe gore ba fetetšwe.

eng: this is a sobering reality because it means that any of us could be infected right now and could unwittingly infect others.
nso: ye ke nnete ya se bele ya go se leše di wela ka gobane e ra gore wo mongwe le wo mongwe wa rena a ka be a fetetšwe ka nako ye ebile a ka fetetša ba bangwe e se ka maikemišetšo.

eng: this is particular the case when visiting relatives, especially the elderly and those with preexisting medical conditions that render them vulnerable to infection.
nso: se se diragala kudu ge go etelwa meloko, kudukudu batšofadi le bao ba nago le malwetši a mangwe ao a bego a le gona mebeleng ya bona ao a ba dirago gore ba be kotsing ya go fetelwa.

eng: it is also true for attending religious services or cultural activities.
nso: nnete ke gore se se diragala gape ge batho ba e ya diko panong tša sedumedi goba ditiragalong tša setšo.

eng: the ‘second wave’ of infections that several other countries have experienced is an everpresent possibility for us too.
nso: lephoto la bobedi la diphe telo leo dinaga tše dingwe tše ntši di itemogetšego lona ke kgonagalo yeo e dulago e le gona le ka mo nageng ya rena.

eng: although many restrictions have been lifted, it does not mean they will not return should we experience a significant rise in infections.
nso: le ge e le gore tše ntši tša dikiletšo di fedišitšwe, ga go re gore di ka se boye gape ge go ka direga gore re itemogele tlhatlogo ye kgolo ya diphetelo.

eng: this pandemic is a matter of life and death.
nso: leuba le ke taba ya lehu le bophelo.

eng: we need to adapt and we need to be vigilant.
nso: re swanetše go tlwaela seemo ebile re swanetše go ntšha mahlo dinameng.

eng: in the days, weeks and months that lie ahead, we must urgently focus our efforts on recovery.
nso: mo matšatšing, dibekeng le dikgweding tše tlago, re swanetše gore ka pejana re lebiše šedi ya rena pholong.

eng: our economy and our society has suffered a great deal.
nso: ikonomi ya rena le setšhaba sa gaborena di tlaišegile kudu.

eng: as we return to economic activity across almost all industries – and work to repair the damage done – we have a responsibility to not let our guard down as individuals, employers, communities, families, professionals, workers and citizens.
nso: ge re le gare re boela ditiragalong tša ikonomi go kgabaganya diintasteri tša go lekana tšohle gotee le mošomo wa go lokiša fao go senyegilego, re nale mai karabelo a gore re se lahlele toulo bjalo ka motho ka noši, bjalo ka bengmešomo, bjalo ka setšhaba, bjalo ka malapa, bjalo ka ditsebi, bjalo ka bašomi le bjalo ka badudi.

eng: none of us wants a return to the early days of extreme lockdown restrictions.
nso: ga gona le ka o tee wa rena yo a nyakago go boela matšatšing a mathomo a dikiletšo tše bogale tša go tswalelwa ga naga.

eng: we want to move on with our lives.
nso: re nyaka go gatela pele ka maphelo a rena.

eng: we want our friends and loved ones to remain healthy and safe.
nso: re nyaka gore bagwera le baratwa ba rena ba dule ba phetše gabotse ebile ba bolokegile.

eng: as a nation, let us continue to work together to ensure that we progress.
nso: bjalo ka setšhaba, a re tšweleng pele go šoma mmogo go netefatša gore re gatela pele.

eng: the move to alert level 2 of the lockdown is not a ‘free for all.’ the rules on social distancing, mask wearing, social gatherings and international travel remain.
nso: melao ya go šielana sekgala, go apara maseke, dikgobokano tša leago le maeto a boditšhaba e santše e le gona.

eng: our success rests on our ability to abide by these regulations and to ensure that we each behave carefully and responsibly.
nso: katlego ya rena seemong se e godimo ga bokgoni ba rena ba go latela melao ye beilwego le go netefatša gore re itshwara ka tlhokomelo le ka maikarabelo.

eng: every time we are considering any form of nonessen tial activity, we should ask: what is the risk of infection to ourselves and to others?
nso: nako le nako ge re gopola go dira tiragalo ya mohuta ofe goba efe ye sego bohlo kwa, re swanetše go ipotšiša potšišo ye: naa e kaba kotsi ya se ke efe go rena le ba thong ba bangwe?

eng: where there is a risk, even a slight one, it is better not to do it.
nso: fao go nago le kotsi, le ge e kaba ye nnyane ka mokgwa mang, go kaone ge re ka ema ka yona.

eng: let us proceed, as ever, with caution.
nso: a re gateleng pele, bjalo ka mehla, ka tlhokomelo.

eng: nsfas powered my dreams more matshediso the national student financial aid scheme (nsfas) has bridged the financial gap between karabo mashego (21) and his plan to further his studies.
nso: nsfas e phethagatša ditoro tša ka more matshediso setlamo sa setšhaba sa thušo ya ditšhelete tša baithuti (nsfas) se hotše karabo mashego (21) mathateng a gagwe a ditšhelete le go mo thuša go fihlelela leano la gagwe la go tšwetša dithuto tša gagwe pele.

eng: mashego of sebokeng in gauteng’s vaal area says he would not have managed to afford tuition fees and the other expenses that come with postmatric education had he not received a bursary from nsfas.
nso: mashego wa go tšwa sebo keng profenseng ya gauteng tikologong ya vaal o bolela gore a ka be a sa kgona go fihlelela ditefo tša dithuto tša gagwe le disenyegelo tše dingwe tša go tsamaišana le dithuto tša ka morago ga marematlou ge nkabe a sa hwetša pasari go tšwa nsfas.

eng: "in addition, the monthly allowance i receive from nsfas enables me to sleep and study on a full stomach," he says.
nso: "godimo ga mo, tšhelete ya kgwedi ka kgwedi yeo ke e hwetšago go tšwa nsfas e nkgontšha gore ke ithute le gore ke se robale ka tlala," a realo.

eng: mashego is a thirdyear student studying towards a degree in civil engineering at the university of pretoria.
nso: mashego ke moithuti wa ngwaga wa boraro dithutong tša gagwe tša lengwalo la degree ya civil engineering kua yunibesithing ya pretoria.

eng: "tuition fees are very expensive.
nso: "ditefelo tša thuto di tura ka maatla.

eng: for the course that i have chosen, i really could not afford to pay for a semester, never mind a single academic year," he explains.
nso: ka dithuto tšeo ke di kgethilego, nkabe ke saka ka kgona go lefela dikgwedi tše tshela, ke sa bolele ka ngwaga o tee wa dithuto," a hlaloša mashego.

eng: mashego matriculated in 2016 and was a top learner in his class, but had no means to pay for his studies.
nso: mashego o feditše mare matlou ka 2016 e le moithuti wa go šoma bokaonekaone ka mphatong wa gagwe, eupša o be a hloka tšhelete ya go lefela dithuto tša gagwe.

eng: he successfully applied for funding from nsfas for the 2018 academic year.
nso: o ile a atlega dikgopelong tša gagwe tša thekgo ya tšhelete go tšwa nsfas ka ngwaga wa dithuto wa 2018.

eng: "this gave me the opportunity to make my dream of studying engineering come true.
nso: "se se mphile monyetla wa go dira toro yaka ya go ithutela engineering go ba nnete.

eng: education plays a huge role in my personal development and it helps me to progress in all that i intend to achieve.
nso: thuto e kgatha tema ye bohlokwa kudu tlhabo llong yaka ebile e nthuša go gatela pele go tšeo ke ikemišeditšego go di fihlele la.

eng: moreover, it empowers me to empower other people in my community and thus contribute to the economy of our country," mashego explains.
nso: go feta mo, e mmatlafatša gore ke maatlafatše batho ba bangwe setšhabeng sa gešo ka gona ke kgathe tema tlhabollong ya ikonomi ya naga ya gaborena," gwa hlaloša mashego.

eng: "i urge young people to apply for nsfas funding because following your dream is not a free exercise, it needs funding, and nsfas will bridge that gap for you," he says.
nso: "ke hlohleletša baswa go dira dikgopelo tša thekgo ya tšhelete tša nsfas ka gobane go latela toro ya gagwe ga se mahala, go nyakega thekgo ya tšhelete, ebile nsfas e tla go tšwela mohola," a realo.

eng: the minister of higher education, science and innovation, dr blade nzimande, has opened the nsfas 2021 application cycle for a period of four months, from 3 august to 30 november 2020. students from disadvan taged and workingclass backgrounds who wish to further their studies at any public technical and vocational education and training (tvet) college or university may apply.
nso: tona ya thuto ya godimo, saense le diphetogo, ngaka blade nzimande, o butše dikgopelo tša nsfas tša 2021, go tloga ka la 3 phato go fihla ka la 30 dibatsela 2020. baithuti ba go tšwa mae mong ao ba gotšego ka go sokola le bao ba šomago eupša ba rata go tšwetša dithuto tša bona pele ditlha hlong dife goba dife tša mmušo, tša sethekniki le tša thutatiro (tvet), kholetšeng goba yunibesithing, ba ka dira dikgopelo.

eng: to be eligible for nsfas funding, an applicant must be a south african citizen and come from a family with a combined annual household income of not more than r350 000. the household annual income for students with a disability should not be more than r600 000.
nso: gore o kgone go dira kgope lo ya nsfas, modirakgopelo o swanetše go ba modudi wa afrika borwa a be a tšwe lape ng leo mogolo wa lona ge o kopane wa ngwaga ka moka o se fete r350 000. mogolo wo kopanego wa lapa wa ngwaga ka moka go baithuti bao ba nago le bogole ga wa swanela go feta r600 000.

eng: "in the current academic year, nsfas has funded over 700 000 students, 248 242 at tvet colleges and 481 339 at universities (students with registrations data).
nso: "mo ngwageng wo wa ditšhelete, nsfas e thekgi le baithuti ba go feta 700 000, ba 248 242 ba dikholetšeng tša tvet le ba 481 339 ba diyunibesithing (baithuti ka tshedimošo ya boingwadišo).

eng: this is a 20 percent increase from the previous year when we compared registration data received in the same period of 2019 versus 2020," says minister nzimande.
nso: ye ke tlha tlogo ya 20% go tloga ngwa ga wo fetilego ge re bapetša tshedimošo ya boingwadišo yeo e amogetšwego ka tšona dikgwedi tšeo ka 2019 ge e bapetšwa le 2020’’ a realo tona nzimande.

eng: nsfas accounts for 40 percent of the undergraduate population at universi ties and 70 percent at tvet colleges.
nso: nsfas e arabela 40% ya palo ya baithuti bao ba sa ithutela mangwalo a bona a mathomo diyunibesithing le 70% ya dikholetšeng tša tvet.

eng: v applicants must visit www.
nso: vka fao o ka dirago dikgopelo badiradikgopelo ba swanetše go etela www.

eng: nsfas.
nso: nsfas.

eng: org.
nso: org.

eng: they must create a mynsfas account, click the apply tab, answer the questions on screen and upload the required documents.
nso: ba swanetše go itirela akhaonto ya nsfas, ba kgotle mo go apply, ba arabe dipotšišo tšeo di tšwelelago skrining le go lokela dito kumente tšeo di nyakegago fao.

eng: once that is done, they must click submit.
nso: ge ba feditše, ba swanetše go kgotla mo go submit .

eng: after clicking submit, the application reference number will appear on the screen.
nso: morago ga ge ba kgotlile submit, no moro ya referense ya kgopelo yeo e tla tšwelela mo skrining.

eng: the reference number will also be sent to the cellphone number and email address that the applicant provided.
nso: nomoro yeo ya re ferense e tla romelwa gape mo nomorong ya sellathekeng le atereseng ya imeile yeo modirakgopelo a fanego ka yona.

eng: applicants can use a cellphone, tablet or computer to apply.
nso: badirakgopelo ba ka šomiša sellathe keng, theipolete goba khomphuthara go dira kgopelo.

eng: the nsfas portal has undergone minor changes to make it easier to use and more secure.
nso: phothale ya nsfas e nale diphetogo tša go se iše kae go dira gore go be bonolo go e šomiša le gore e bolokege kudu.

eng: new applicants need a copy of their id or birth certificate to register and create a profile on the mynsfas portal.
nso: go badiradikgopelo ba mathomo go nyakega khophi ya bona ya pasa goba sethifikeithi sa matswalo ebile ba swanetše go itirela profaele phothaleng ya nsfas.

eng: applicants with existing accounts need to log into their accounts – remember, only one profile per applicant is allowed.
nso: badiradikgopelo bao ba dirago dikgopelo lekga la bobedi ba swanetše go tsena diakhantong tša bona – gopola, go dumeletšwe fela profaele ye tee ka modirakgopelo.

eng: the applicant must give consent for their personal information to be checked by a third party and if they do not agree to this, they will not be allowed to continue with the application process.
nso: modirakgopelo o swanetše go fana ka tumelelo ya gore tshedimošo ka ga yena e lekolwe ke lekoko la boraro ebile ge a ka se dumele se, a ka se dumelelwe go tšwelapele ka tshepedišo ya kgopelo.

eng: as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, applicants will not be required to submit or upload the consent form.
nso: ka baka la leuba la coronavirus , go ka se nyakege gore badiradikgopelo ba romele goba ba lokele foromo ya tumelelano.

eng: protect our women and children vukuzenzele unnamed a year ago, almost to the day, thousands of wom en, men and children marched to parliament to protest against a spate of rapes and killings of women and girls.
nso: šireletšang basadi le bana ba rena vukuzenzele unnamed ngwaga wo o feti lego, go nyaka go fihla lehono, diketekete tša basadi, tša banna le bana ba ile ba gwantela palamenteng go tliša ditšhupetšo kgahlanong le bothata bja go katwa le go bolawa ga basadi le bana.

eng: at the time, the nation was reeling from the murders of uyinene mrwetyana, leighandre jegels, jesse hess and a number of other women who had lost their lives at the hands of brutal men.
nso: ka nako yeo, setšhaba se be se sa tšhošitšwe ke go bolawa ga uyinene mrwetyana, leighandre jegels, jesse hess le ga basadi ba bangwe ba bantši bao ba lahlegetšwego ke maphelo a bona ka diatleng tša banna ba bašoro.

eng: from all social backgrounds, young and old, students and working women, the peaceful protesters held aloft placards that read ‘enough is enough’ and ‘am i next?’.
