eng: we rolled out a special coronavirus disease (covid19) social relief of distress grant, which has reached some six million people to date.
nso: re phethagaditše thušo ya tšhelete ya kimollo ya leago ya moswananoši ya covid19 , yeo e fihleletšego batho ba go fihla dimilione tše tshela.

eng: this was done within weeks of the national state of disaster being declared.
nso: se se dirilwe mo nakong ya dibeke tše mmalwa morago ga go tsebagatšwa ga seemo sa masetlapelo a bosetšhaba.

eng: the scale of such an undertaking cannot be understated.
nso: bogolo ba mošomo wo o di rilwego bo ka se ke ba tšeelwa fase.

eng: to bring this system online there was extensive collaboration between the south african social security agency, south african revenue service, home affairs and many others.
nso: gore peakanyo ye e kgone go šoma dikhomphuthareng, go bile le tšhomišanommogo ye nabilego magareng ga setlamo sa afrika borwa sa tšhireletšego ya leago, tirelo ya metšhelo ya afrika borwa, kgoro ya merero ya selegae le tše dingwe tše ntši.

eng: we set up a fully automated application and disbursement process, and integrated multiple databases, including the national population register and the unemployment insurance fund (uif) database.
nso: re hlomile peakanyo ya go šoma ka noši ya tshepedišo ya go dira dikgopelo le ya ditefo, ebile re kopantše mmogo dathapeisi tša go fapafapana, go akaretšwa le dathapeisi ya retšistara ya bosetšhaba ya palo ya batho le ya sekhwama sa inšorense ya bao ba lahlegetšwego ke mešomo (uif).

eng: we set up new application channels like whatsapp and ussd, and created systems with the commercial banks to enable banking detail verification.
nso: re hlomile mekgwa ye meswa ya go dira dikgopelo go swana le ka whatsapp le ka ussd, ebile re hlomile dipeakanyo gotee le dipanka tše kgolo go kgontšha kgonthišišo ya tshedimošo ya diakhaonto tša dipanka.

eng: this is a remarkable achievement in a very short space of time.
nso: ye ke phenyo ye kgolo ka nakwana ye kopana.

eng: alongside the measures we took to protect and sustain livelihoods, we also supported ailing businesses.
nso: godimo ga magato ao re a tšeerego go šireletša le go thekga mekgwa ya batho ya go iphediša, re thekgile gape le dikgwebo tša go goga ka kgara.

eng: we provided relief to small businesses in the form of debt relief, finance, tax payment deferrals and other instruments.
nso: re fane ka thekgo ya kimollo go dikgwebo tše nnyane ka sebopego sa ki mollo ya sekoloto, thekgo ya tšhelete, go fegwa ga ditefo tša metšhelo le mekgwa ye mengwe.

eng: we implemented a covid19 loan guarantee scheme to enable businesses to meet their operational expenses during the lockdown, and are currently looking at how this scheme can reach more companies in need.
nso: re phethagaditše sekimo sa covid19 sa kgonthišišo ya dikadimo go kgontšha di kgwebo go fihlelela disenye gelo tša tšona tša mošomo nakong ye ya kiletšo ya mesepelo, ebile ka nako ye re lebeletše ka fao sekimo se se ka fihlelelago dikhamphani tše ntši tšeo di se hlokago.

eng: we provided income protection to workers and relief to business owners through the temporary employer relief scheme administered by the uif.
nso: re fane ka tšhireletšo ya meputso go bašomedi le kimollo go bengdikgwebo ka sekimo sa nakwana sa kimollo ya bengmešomo seo se sepedišwago ke uif.

eng: these were all in direct response to an emergency and were by nature temporary.
nso: tše ka moka e be e le ma gato a go arabela thwi seemo sa tšhoganyetšo ebile e be e le a mohuta wa nakwana.

eng: some are now coming to an end, while others have been extended as the labour market recovers.
nso: a mangwe a fihla mafelelong mola a mangwe a okeditšwe ka ge mmaraka wa bašomi o kaonafala.

eng: the measures we implemented went a long way towards protecting our society from the harsh winds of covid19.
nso: magato ao re a phetha gaditšego a fihlile kgole go šireletša setšhaba sa gaborena kgahlanong le maima a covid19 .

eng: the additional grants helped to prevent millions of people from falling below the food poverty line.
nso: dithušo tša tšhelete tša tlaleletšo di thušitše go thibela diketekete tša batho gore ba se wele kgotlompong ya bohloki ba dijo.

eng: had we not intervened to secure livelihoods and save businesses, the living conditions of our people and the circumstances of thousands of businesses would have been considerably worse.
nso: ge nkabe re saka ra tšea magato go šireletša mekgwa ya batho ya go iphediša le go hlakodiša dikgwebo, maemo a bophelo ba batho ba gaborena le maemo a dikgwebo tše ntši a ka be amegile gampe kudu.

eng: now we are in a transition from relief to recovery.
nso: bjale re ka gare ga diphetogo tša go tloga seemong sa kimo llo go ya go sa kaonafalo.

eng: the emergency measures we put in place have laid a firm foundation on which to rebuild our economy.
nso: magato a tšhoganyetšo ao re a hlomilego a re beetše mothe o wa go tia wo ka ona re tla agang ikonomi ya gaborena ka leswa.

eng: as our focus now shifts to the implementation of the economic reconstruction and recovery plan, our priority will be to stimulate growth and create jobs.
nso: ka baka la ge šedi ya rena gabjale e fetoga e lebišwa phethagatšong ya leano la tšošološo le kagoleswa ya ikonomi šedi ye kgolo ye tlago pele ga tšohle e tla ba go hlohleletša kgolo le go hlola mešomo.

eng: there has already been progress in a number of areas.
nso: go bile le kgatelopele mafe long a mantši.

eng: we are seeing new funding commitments for infrastructure development following an infrastructure project roundtable last week.
nso: re bona boikgafo bjo boswa ba thekgo ya ditšhelete bakeng sa tlhabollo ya mananeokgoparara morago ga ditherišano tša mohla kanelwa tša protšeke ya mananeokgoparara beke ya go feta.

eng: a number of employment programmes under the presidential employment stimulus have started.
nso: mananeo a mmalwa a tlholego ya mešomo ka fase ga lenaneohlohleletšo la mešomo la mopresidente a thomilwe.

eng: we are pushing ahead with economic reforms in areas such as energy and telecommunications.
nso: re gatela pele ka mpshafatšo ya ikonomi mererong ye bjalo ka enetši le dikgokagano tša megala.

eng: plans are being converted to action and commitments are being reflected in jobs and opportunities.
nso: maano a gare a fetošetšwa go ba magato ebile mai kgafo a thoma go bonagala mešomong le menyetleng ya mešomo.

eng: it is all the more critical at this time, more so with the festive season approaching, that we do not become the architects of our own undoing.
nso: tšona dithulaganyo tše di bohlokwa kudu ka nako ye, kudukudu ka baka la ge sehla sa maikhutšo se batamela, gore re seke ra itshenyeletša ka mediro ya rena.

eng: the greatest vigilance is required from us all to keep the virus at bay.
nso: go nyakega gore ka moka re ntšhe mahlo dinameng gore re thibele baerase ye.

eng: a resurgence at any scale will not just dramatically reverse our health gains.
nso: lephoto la bobedi la bolwetši ka bogolo bofe goba bofe le ka se bušetše fela diphenyo tšeo re di fihleletšego morago, le tla senya dikgatelopele tšeo di bonagetšego tša kaonafalo ya ikonomi, le go re bušetša morago go tloga sehleng sa se ruthwana go ya go sa marega.

eng: it will choke the green shoots of economic recovery that have emerged, and take us back from spring to winter.
nso: go efoga lephoto la bobedi la diphetelo tša covid19 , re swanetše go latela melao ya maphelo yeo e sa ntšego šoma.

eng: when we fail to wear a mask at a social gathering, when we attend crowded events, we are not only putting ourselves and others at risk.
nso: ge re šitwa ke go apara dimaseke dikopanong tša setšhaba, ge re eya ditiraga long tša go tlala ka batho, ga re bee fela maphelo a rena le a batho ba bangwe kotsing.

eng: we are also putting our economic recovery in jeopardy.
nso: re bea gape le kaonafalo ya ikonomi kotsing ye kgolo.

eng: let us all continue to play our part.
nso: a re tšweleng pele go kgatha tema ya rena.

eng: the positive actions of wearing a mask, of maintaining social distancing and of regular hand washing helped us overcome the worst effects of the pandemic.
nso: magato a mabotse a go apara maseke, a go šielana sekgala le go hlapa matsogo kgafetšakgafetša a re thušitše go fenya ditlamorago tše šoro tša leuba le.

eng: they are still our best defence.
nso: ona magato a ka moka e sale mokgwa wa rena wo kaonekaone wa go itšhireletša.

eng: healthdrink water to avoid dehydration allison cooper severe heat and not drinking enough fluids can lead to dehydration and heatstroke, which can be fatal.
nso: enwa meetse o efoge go hloka meetse mmeleng allison cooper phišo ye šoro le go se nwe diela tše lekanego go ka hlola go hloka meetse mmeleng le strouku sa phišo, le gona motho a ka hlokofala.

eng: according to the western cape department of health, the summer heat brings with it a high risk of dehydration, which is a harmful loss of water in the body.
nso: goya ka kgoro ya maphelo ya kapa bodikela, phišo ya selemo e tsamaišana le kotsi ye kgolo ya go hloka meetse mmeleng, e lego tahlegelo ya meetse mmeleng.

eng: dehydration is usually caused by not drinking enough liquids to replenish the water lost by sweating.
nso: go hloka meetse mmeleng gantši go hlolwa ke go se nwe diela tše lekanego go tšea legato la meetse ao a tšwilego mmeleng ka kodumela.

eng: it can also be caused by an illness, that causes vomiting or diarrhoea; and by sweating from a fever.
nso: go hloka meetse mmeleng go ka hlolwa gape ke bolwetši, bjo bo ka hlolago go hlatša le/goba letšhologo; le go tšwa kodumela ka baka la letadi.

eng: the loss of body fluids does not only occur during hard physical activities, but can also result from walking, gardening or riding a bike, especially in hot or humid conditions.
nso: tahlegelo ya diela mmeleng ga e diragale fela nakong ya ge motho a itšhidulla mmele ga boima, eupša e ka hlolwa gape ke go sepela, go šoma ka tšhengwaneng le go reila paesekela, kudukudu maemong a go fiša goba a monola.

eng: when you are dehydrated, your body cannot function as usual.
nso: ge o hloka meetse mmeleng, mmele wa gago o ka se šome ka tshwanelo.

eng: children younger than five, the elderly and people working outdoors are especially vulnerable to dehydration and heatstroke (a condition caused when your body overheats).
nso: bana ba mengwaga ya ka fase ga ye mehlano, batšofadi le batho bao ba šomago ka ntle ga magae ba kotsing ya go hloka meetse mmeleng le strouku sa phišo (bolwetši ba go hlolwa ke ge mmele wa gago o fiša go feta tekano).

eng: heatstroke is a medical emergency.
nso: strouku sa phišo ke bolwetši bja tšhoganyetšo bjo bo hlokago ngaka.

eng: seek medical help immediately for any of these symptoms: feeling confused or your speech starts to become slow and unclear.
nso: hwetša thušo ya bongaka ka yona nako yeo ge o bona efe goba efe ya dika tše: go ikwa o gakanegile goba ge polelo ya gago e thoma go nanya le go se kwagale.

eng: nausea and vomiting.
nso: go sellega le go hlatša.

eng: rapid, shallow breathing.
nso: go hema ka pela o sokodišwa ke go buša moya.

eng: heart starts to race.
nso: pelo e thoma go kiba ka lebelo.

eng: a throbbing headache.
nso: go opa ke hlogo ye bohlokwana.

eng: dehydration warning signssome of the early warning signs of dehydration include: feeling thirsty and lightheaded.
nso: dika tša temošo ya go hloka meetse mmelengtše dingwe tša dika tša mathomo tša go hloka meetse mmeleng di akaretša: go ikwa o swere ke lenyora le modukologo.

eng: a dry mouth.
nso: molomo wa go gomelela.

eng: having dark coloured, strongsmelling urine.
nso: mohlapologo wa mmala wa go fifala, wa go ba le lefetla.

eng: passing urine less often than usual.
nso: go se hlapologe gantši go swana le ka matšatši a mangwe.

eng: to stay hydrated and avoid heatstroke you should: drink more water than you usually do on hot days.
nso: gore o dule o nale meetse mmeleng le go efoga strouku sa phišo o swanetše gore: o nwe meetse a mantši go feta ka fao o wa nwago ka gona ge letšatši le fiša.

eng: stay inside or in shaded areas.
nso: itulele ka ngwakong goba fao go nago le meriti.

eng: wear a wide rim hat or use an umbrella.
nso: apara lephephe la go phaphamala goba o šomiše amporela.

eng: always carry a bottle of water with you and drink regularly.
nso: dula o swere lebotlelo la meetse mo go wena o be o nwe meetse kgafetšakgafetša.

eng: take regular breaks from the sun if you work outside.
nso: khutša kgafetšakgafetša ge o le letšatšing ge o šoma ka ntle.

eng: cool yourself down by using a spray bottle.
nso: timola phišo ka go šomiša lebotlelo la meetse la go šašetša.

eng: babies and childrenparents and caregivers should pay extra attention to children and babies, to make sure they are hydrated.
nso: masea le banabatswadi le baledi ba swanetše go ba le šedi ye kgolo go bana le masea, ba netefatše gore ba nale meetse mebeleng.

eng: breastfeeding moms should feed their babies more frequently when it is very hot.
nso: bommagobana bao ba nantšhago ba swanetše go nantšha masea a bona kgafetšakgafetša ge go fiša kudu.

eng: keep children indoors or in the shade, dress them in light clothing and wipe them down with a damp cloth to help them stay cool.
nso: bana ba dule ka dintlong goba ka fase ga meriti, ba apare diaparo tše bofefo le gore ba phumolwe ka lešela la go thapa go ba thuša go timola phišo.

eng: remember to apply sunscreen when they go outdoors.
nso: gopola go šomiša ditlolo tša go thibela go fišwa ke letšatši letlalong ge o le ka ntle.

eng: if children younger than five have watery stools, keep vomiting and are tired, seek medical help immediately.
nso: ge bana ba mengwaga ya ka fase ga ye mehlano ba tšhologa, ba tšwelapele go hlatša ebile ba lapa, hwetša thušo ya bongaka ka yona nako yeo.

eng: also seek immediate medical care if your baby is unable to breastfeed or has sunken eyes and a sunken soft spot (fontanelle) on its head.
nso: hwetša thušo ya bongaka ka yona nako yeo ge lesea la gago le sa kgone go nyanya letswele goba le nale mahlo a go wela ka gare goba phogwana ya go wela ka gare mo hlogong.

eng: in children, other dehydration warning signs include: a dry or sticky mouth.
nso: mo baneng, dika tše dingwe tša temošo ya go hloka meetse mmeleng di akaretša: molomo wa go gomelela goba wa go mata.

eng: sa overcoming hiv and aids vukuzenzele unnamed as we continue our efforts to manage the devastating coronavirus pandemic, we cannot ignore the other public health challenges that our country faces.
nso: afrika borwa e fenya hiv le aids vukuzenzele unnamed ge re tšwela pele ka maitekelo a rena a go tliša masetlapelo a leuba la kokwanahloko ya khorona ka tlase ga taolo, re ka se kgone go hlokomologa dihlotlo tše dingwe tša maphelo a setšhaba tšeo naga ya gaborena e lebaganego natšo.

eng: for more than three dec ades, our country has been engaged in an ongoing struggle against hiv and aids, which has cost many lives and caused great hardship and suffering.
nso: mo mengwageng ya go feta masometharo, naga ya borena e be e dutše e le ntweng kgahlanong le hiv le aids tšeo di feditšego maphelo a mantšhi ebile di hlotšego mathata le maima.

eng: since the outbreak of cov id19 in the country, with the nationwide lockdown and the pressure on our health facilities, many hiv , aids and tuberculosis services have suffered.
nso: esale go phulega ga covid19 go e ba gona ka mo nageng, gape gwa ba le kiletšo ya mosepelo ya naga ka bophara mmogo le go bea mafelo a tša maphelo ka tlase ga kgatelelo, bontšhi bja ditirelo tša hiv , aids le bolwetši bja mafahla (tb) bo ile bja tekateka.

eng: this has posed a challenge for people testing and starting antiretroviral treatment.
nso: se se hlotše hlotlo go batho bao ba nyakago go dira diteko mmogo le bao ba thomago kalafo ya diantiretroviral.

eng: many people found it difficult to collect their medicines and fewer people accessed other services, such as voluntary male medical circumcision.
nso: batho ba bantšhi ba humane go le boima go yo tšea dihlare tša bona, gomme e le feela batho ba se bakae bao ba kgonago go ﬁ hlelela ditirelo tše dingwe bjalo ka go bolla ka mokgwa wa sekgowa.

eng: at the same time, there are many lessons that have been learnt from our public health response to the coronavirus pandemic that can strengthen our fight against hiv and tb.
nso: ka yona nako yeo go na gape le tše ntšhi tšeo re ithutilego tšona go tšwa go mokgwa woo mafelo a tša maphelo a setšhaba a ikarabelago ka gona go leuba la kokwanahloko ya khorona, tšeo di ka matlafatšago ntwa ya rena kgahlanong le hiv le tb.

eng: south africa continues to have the largest number of people living with hiv in the world.
nso: afrika borwa e tšwela pele go ba le palo ya godimo ya batho bao ba phelago ka hiv mo lefaseng.

eng: it is encouraging, however, that over the last decade we made progress in reducing the number of new hiv infections in the population by nearly 60%.
nso: le ge go le bjalo, sa go kgahliša ke gore mo ngwagasomeng woo o fetilego re ile ra ba le kgatelopele tabeng ya go fokotša palo ya diphetetšo tše mpsha setšhabeng ka 60%.

eng: it is also encouraging that hiv infections in adolescent girls and young women have significantly declined in the last decade.
nso: se sengwe gape sa go kgahliša ke gore diphetetšo tša hiv go basetsana le makgarebe go fokotšegile kudu mo ngwagasomeng woo o fetilego.

eng: this is a crucial group because they are much more likely to be at risk of getting hiv .
nso: se ke sehlopha sa batho se bohlokwa ka gore ba tloga ba le kotsing ya go fetelwa ke hiv .

eng: our treatment programme has contributed to a reduction in the number of deaths due to aids by 60%.
nso: lenaneo la rena la kalafo le bile le seabe phokotšong ya mahu a mantšhi a go hlolwa ke aids ka 60%.

eng: there has been a greater reduction in hivrelated deaths among young people.
nso: go bile le phokotšego e kgolo ya mahu ao a amanago le hiv go baswa.

eng: it was possible to reduce the number of deaths because we, together with our partners, have rolled out an extensive antiretroviral programme reaching millions of people living with the disease.
nso: go bile le kgonagalo ya go fokotša palo ya mahu ka ge, mmogo le badirišanimmogo le rena, re tlile ka lenaneo leo le tseneletšego la diantiretroviral , leo le ﬁ hlelelago dimilione tša batho bao ba phelago ka bolwetši bjo.

eng: at the beginning of the decade, our programme to prevent mother to child transmission (pmtct) of hiv had very low coverage.
nso: mathomong a ngwagasome woo o fetilego, lenaneo la rena la thibelo ya phetetšo ya hiv go tšwa go mma go ya go ngwana (pmtct) le be le se la naba, le sa akaretše batho ka moka.

eng: now we have one of the highest rates of coverage of pmtct in southern africa, which has substantially reduced rates of infection among children.
nso: gabjale re na le le lengwe la mananeo a magolo a kakaretšo ya pmtct ka borwa bja afrika, leo le tlogago le fokoditše diphetetšo go bana.

eng: while we have reduced deaths and new infections, we still are far from reaching the goal we committed ourselves in 2016 of achieving a 75% reduction in hiv infections by 2020. if we succeed in doing so, we are likely to end aids as a public health threat by 2030. unfortunately, we are not there yet.
nso: le ge re kgonne go fokotša mahu le diphetetšo tše diswa, re sa le kgole le go ﬁ hlelela nepo yeo re ipeetšego yona ka 2016 ya go ﬁ hlelela phokotšego ya 70% ya diphetetšo tša hiv ka 2020. ge re ka atlega ka go dira seo, gona go ka kgonagala gore re fediše aids bjalo ka lepheko la tša maphelo ka 2030. ka madimabe, ga sešo re ﬁ hla fao.

eng: we have to do far more to ensure that young people are empowered to prevent infections, including through changing behaviour, accessing condoms and testing regularly.
nso: re swanetše re šome go feta mo go netefatša gore baswa ba a matlafatšwa gore go thibelwe diphetetšo, go balwa taba ya go fetola maitshwaro, go ﬁ hlelela dikgotlopo mmogo le go dira diteko kgafetšakgafetša.

eng: we need to make sure that everyone who is infected has access to treatment and care.
nso: re hloka go netefatša gore batho ka moka bao ba fetetšwego ba ﬁ hlelela kalafo le tlhokomelo.

eng: we need to work harder on hiv prevention among key populations, including sex workers, men who have sex with men, and people who inject drugs.
nso: re hloka go šoma ka maatla go thibela hiv dihlopheng tšeo di ikgethilego, go balwa bagwebakammele, banna bao ba robalanago le banna ba bangwe, gape le batho bao ba ihlabelago ka diokobatši.

eng: we must end the stigma and discrimination towards these populations.
nso: re swanetše re fediše phoko le kgethollo go batho ba.

eng: we cannot hope to end hiv if we ignore the needs, concerns and rights of any part of our population.
nso: re ka se holofele go fediša hiv ge eba re tlo hlokomologa dihlokwa, dingongorego le ditokelo tša karolo efe goba efe ya setšhaba sa borena.

eng: south africa needs to increase efforts to medically circumcise young men to reduce their risk of acquiring hiv .
nso: afrika borwa e hloka go oketša maitekelo a go bolotša bašemane gore go fokotšege kotsi ya gore ba fetelwe ke hiv .

eng: unsafe circumcision should not leave young men with lifelong health problems, and no one should die from circumcision.
nso: go bolla ga go se bolokege ga se gwa swanela go tlogela bašemane le mathata a bophelo ka moka, gomme go se ke gwa ba le motho yoo a hlokofalago ka baka la lebollo.

eng: we must make sure that young men have safe circumcision.
nso: re swanetše re netefatše gore bašemane ba bolokegile ge ba bolla.

eng: we are encouraged by findings of a recent study on preexposure prophylaxis (prep).
nso: re hlohleletšwa ke dipoelo tša diphatišišo ka ga preexposure prophylaxis (prep).

eng: unlike antiretroviral treatment that is given to people who are hiv positive, prep involves the regular use of antiretroviral drugs by hiv negative people to prevention infection.
nso: go fapana le kalafo ya diantiretroviral yeo e fiwago batho bao ba fetetšwego ke hiv , prep yona e šomišwa ke batho bao ba sego ba fetelwa ke hiv go thibela phetetšo.

eng: the study, conducted by scientists from the hiv prevention trials network, found that longacting injections once every eight weeks was better than the daily tablet used for hiv prevention.
nso: diphatišišo tše, tšeo di dirilwego ke boramahlale go tšwa hiv prevention trials network, di humane gore go hlabelwa gatee dibekeng tše dingwe le tše dingwe tše seswai go kaone go phala go nwa pilisi tšatši ka tšatši go thibela hiv .

eng: these findings have the potential to significantly strengthen our response to the epidemic.
nso: dipoelo tše di ka kgona go matlafatša ntwa ya rena kgahlanong le leuba le.

eng: if we are to succeed in ending aids as a public health threat within the next decade, we need to combine these medical breakthroughs with fundamental changes in behaviour.
nso: ge eba re nyaka go atlega mo phedišong ya aids bjalo ka lepheko la tša maphelo a setšhaba mo ngwagasomeng wo o tlago, gona re hloka go kopantšha diphihlelelo tše tša maphelo le go fetola maitshwaro e le ka nnete.

eng: we also need to tackle the economic and social conditions that contrib ute to high rates of infection.
nso: re swanetše gape re lwe le maemo a ikonomi le a leago, elego ona a nago le seabe go palo ya godimo ya diphetetšo.

eng: one of our central tasks is to empower adolescent girls and young women, educationally, economically and socially.
nso: wo mongwe wa mešomo ya rena ye megolo ke go matlafatša basetsana bao ba tšwelego mahlalagading le makgarebe ka tša thuto, tša ikonomi le tša leago.

eng: they need to be able to make their own decisions about every aspect of their lives, including their sexuality and sexual behaviour.
nso: ba swanetše gore ba kgone go itšeela diphetho ka lekala le lengwe le le lengwe la maphelo a bona, go balwa le bong bja bona mmogo le ka moo ba itshwarago ka gona ge go etla go tša thobalano.

eng: ultimately, we will achieve the end of aids through the empowerment of young people, women and other people at risk.
nso: mafelelong re tlo kgona go fediša aids ka go matlafatša baswa, basadi le batho bao ba lego kotsing ya phetetšo.

eng: this includes empowerment through access to information, advice and support.
nso: se se akaretša matlafatšo ka go ﬁ hlelela tshedimošo, maele le thekgo.

eng: it includes access to education and economic opportunities, especially for young women.
nso: go balwa gape le phihlelelo go menyetla ya thuto le ikonomi, kudu ga makgarebe.

eng: another chance to get your matric cathy grosvenor it is never too late to get your matric or to achieve the results you want, is the message behind the department of basic edu cation’s (dbe) second chance matric support programme.
nso: monyetla o mongwe wa go humana marematlou cathy grosvenor go sa na le nako ya gore o humane marematlou goba dipoelo tšeo o di nyakago – wo ke molaetša woo o tšwago go ba lenaneo la thekgo ya sebaka sa bobedi sa go hwetša marematlou la lefapha la thuto ya motheo (dbe).

eng: director of the programme, dr sandy malapile, says a matric qualification is an absolute necessity because without it, many doors of opportunity remain closed.
nso: molaodi wa lenaneo, ngaka sandy malapile, o re marematlou o tloga o le bohlokwa kudu ka gore ntle le wona menyetla ga e be gona.

eng: "sector training and education authorities (setas), tasked with upskilling the nation through skills programmes and apprenticeships, also require that candidates have a matric," says dr malapile.
nso: "ditheo tša tlhahlo le thuto ya lekala (diseta), tšeo di filwego maatla a go kaonafatša le go ruta batho ka mananeo a go thuša go humana mabokgoni, mmogo le ditlhahlo tša morago ga thuto tša mešomo ya diatla le tšona di nyaka gore batsenedi ba mananeo a tšona ba be le marematlou.," gwa realo ngaka malapile.

eng: launched in january 2016, the second chance programme supports anyone – of any age – who wants to achieve or improve a matric qualification, subjectbysubject and on a parttime basis.
nso: lenaneo la thekgo ya sebaka sa bobedi sa go hwetša marematlou, leo le tsebagaditšwego ka pherekgong 2016, le thekga batho ka moka go sa lebelelwe mengwaga, bao ba nyakago go fihlelela goba go kaonafatša marematlou wa bona ka go dira thuto ka e tee ka e tee goba ka go ithuta ba le gae.

eng: there are no costs involved.
nso: ga go lefelwe selo.

eng: people who want to im prove their matric results, whether they wrote matric recently or even decades ago.
nso: batho bao ba nyakago go kaonafatša dipoelo tša bona tša marematlou, e ka ba e se kgale ba dirile marematlou goba ba o dirile mengwaga e mentšhi yeo e fetilego.

eng: dr malapile explains that a person wanting to obtain an engineering qualification, for in stance, might need to im prove their mathematics mark to qualify for the course.
nso: ngaka ma lapile o hlaloša gore motho yoo a nyakago go ithutela bointšinere, go fa mohlala, o hloka go kaonafatša dipoelo tša dipalo gore a tle a kgone go dira thuto yeo.

eng: people who failed matric and want a second chance at passing.
nso: batho bao ba šitilwego ke marematlou gomme ba nyaka go boela ba o dire gape gore ba tšwelele.

eng: people who left school after passing grade 9 (then standard 7), are 21 or older, and wish to obtain their matric.
nso: batho bao ba tlogetšego sekolo morago ga go tšwelela go kreiti 9 (mphato wa bošupa wa kgale), ba na le mengwaga e 21 goba go feta, gomme ba nyaka go ba le marematlou.

eng: how to get startedregister at one of the 75 dis trict education offices across the country or online at this website: www.
nso: ingwadiše ka go ya go ye nngwe ya dikantoro tša thuto tša selete tše 75 naga ka bophara goba inthaneteng mo websaeteng ye: www.

eng: eservices.
nso: eservices.

eng: gov.
nso: gov.

eng: za.
nso: za.

eng: registration opened on 1 october and will close in february 2021. learners either study on their own or at one of the 133 second chance centres where facetoface learning takes place afterhours and on weekends.
nso: go ingwadiša go thomile ka di 1 diphalane gomme go tla tswalela ka dibokwane 2021. baithuti ba ka ithutela ka gae goba go ye nngwe ya disenthara tše 133 tša thekgo ya sebaka sa bobedi sa go hwetša marematlou moo ba rutwago mathapama le mafelelong a beke.

eng: dr malapile says only the top performing teachers in each district are employed at these centres.
nso: ngaka malapile o bolela gore ka disenthareng tše go thwetšwe feela barutiši bao mošomo wa bona o tšweletšego ka magetla go tšwa seleteng se sengwe le se sengwe.

eng: the centres are not available in every town and village, but are located in areas where the greatest number of people have registered, which means their location could change each year.
nso: disenthara ga di toropong goba motseng wo mongwe le wo mongwe, efela di mafelong ao go nago le palo ya godimo ya batho bao ba ingwadišitšego, gomme se se ra gore moo di lego gona go ka fetoga ngwaga kangwaga.

eng: both facetoface learners and learners who study at home have access to a full range of study support services, from lessons broadcast on radio and television at specific times; to downloadable online material; and, for those without access to computers, printers and the inter net−printed study material is sent to them by the dbe.
nso: bobedi baithuti ba go rutelwa disenthareng le ba go ithuta ba le ka gae ba hwetša ditirelo tša thekgo ya thuto, go tloga go mananeo a tša thuto ao a gašwago seyalemoyeng goba thelebišeneng ka dinako tše itseng, gape le go taonlouta dithuto tšeo go tšwa inthaneteng; gomme bao ba se nago dikhomphu thara, digatiši le inthanete ba ka humana dipuku tša go ithuta go tšwa go dbe.

eng: people with a computer but no internet or data, may request a cd with all the study material, which will be mailed to them.
nso: batho bao ba nago le khomphuthara efela ba se na inthanete ba ka kgopela cd yeo e nago le dipuku ka moka, yeo ba tla e romelwago.

eng: "many adult learners may not have lots of time to devote to their studies.
nso: "baithuti ba bantšhi ba bagolo ba ka hloka nako e ntšhi ya go ithuta.

eng: luck ily, they may decide how many subjects they want to do a year because they do not have to complete their matric within a set time.
nso: ka mahla tse, ba ka ikgethela gore ba nyaka go dira dithuto tše kae ka ngwaga ka ge ba sa gapeletšege gore ba fetše marematlou wa bona ka nako e itseng."

eng: "once registered, the dbe will help each older learner choose the subjects they want to do and explain which ones are compulsory.
nso: ge ba šetše ba ingwadišitše, dbe e tla thuša moithuti yo mongwe le yo mongwe yo mogolo go kgetha dithuto tšeo a nyakago go di dira ba be ba mo hlalosetše gore ke dithuto dife tšeo elego tša kgapeletšo.

eng: on qualifying, people who left school after 2008 receive a national senior certificate and those who left school earlier, receive an amended senior certificate.
nso: ge ba šetše ba tšweletše dithutong tša bona, batho bao ba tlogetšego sekolo morago ga 2008 ba fiwa national senior certificate, gomme bao ba tlogetšego sekolo pele ga fao ba fiwa amended senior certificate.

eng: however, dr malapile says both qualifications carry the same weight and, depending on the subjects taken and marks achieved, can be used to apply to universities and colleges.
nso: le ge go le bjalo, ngaka malapile o bolela gore bobedi disetifikeiti tšeo di a lekana gomme motho a ka šomiša seo a se filwego go dira dikgopelo tša go ithuta diyunibesithing goba dikholetšheng, go ya le ka dithuto tšeo motho a tla bego a di dirile mmogo le dipoelo tšeo a di humanego.

eng: giving second chancesthe dbe holds community roadshows to encourage people to enrol for the second chance programme.
nso: go fa monyetla wa bobedidbe e ba le mananeo a setšhaba a go ralala, a go hlohleletša batho go ingwadišetša lenaneo la sebaka sa bobedi.

eng: tertiary education institutions and setas are invited to provide as much information as possible to interested people.
nso: ditheo tša thuto yeo e phagamego mmogo le diseta di a mengwa go tlo fa batho bao ba nago le kgahlego tshedimošo e ntšhi ka moo go kgonegago.

eng: at many of these roadshows, minister angie mot shekga was asked by youth to introduce programmes that could assist young people to be more employable, says dr malapile.
nso: go bontšhi bja mananeo a a go ralala, tona angie motshekga o kgopetšwe ke baswa go tla ka mananeo ao a ka ba thušago gore ba thwalege, gwa realo ngaka malapile.

eng: in response, the dbe is launching a skills development programme this year that will target about 3.4 million young people who are not in employment, education or training.
nso: ka go arabela seo, dbe e tsebagatša lenaneo la tlhabollo ya mabokgoni ngwageng o leo le tla lebelelago baswa bao ba ka bago3.4 milione bao ba sa šomego, ba sa ithutego goba ba sa tsenelago tlhahlo.

eng: courses will range from life skills – covering topics such as how to write a cv and what to do at a job interview; to basic skills courses, such as shoe repair, basic itc and literacy.
nso: dithuto e tla ba tšeo di fapafapanego, go tloga go ya mabokgoning a tša bophelo ao a akaretšago dihlogotaba tše bjalo ka go ngwala taodišophelo le maitshwaro a ge motho a ile ditekong tša mošomo; go ya go dithuto tša mabokgoni a motheo a bjalo ka go roka dieta, mabokgoni a go šomiša khomphutha (ict), le a go bala le go ngwala.

eng: did you know?
nso: vnaa o be o tseba?

eng: a better 2021 for all south africans the first weeks of the year have been difficult for all south africans.
nso: 2021 e kaone go maafrika borwa ka moka dibeke tša mathomo tša ngwaga e bile tše boima go maafrika borwa ka moka.

eng: vukuzenzele unnamed the coronavirus pandemic has gotten worse, with new infections increasing far faster and far higher than before.
nso: vukuzenzele unnamed leuba la coronavirus le galefile, ka diphetetšo tše diswa tše di oketšegang ka lebelo le ka palo ya godimo go feta pele.

eng: hospitals have been under great strain as more people have needed medical attention.
nso: dipetlele di bile ka fase ga kgatelelo ye kgolo ka batho ba bantši ba go hloka thušo ya kalafo.

eng: while most economic sectors have been able to operate again for several months, it will take some time for the economy to recover and for lost jobs to be restored.
nso: mola bontši bja makala a ikonomi bo kgonne go šoma gape dikgwedi tše ntšinyana, go tla tšea nakwana gore ikonomi e kokotlele le mešomo ye e lobilwego gore e tsošološwe.

eng: as the new year starts, many families are still feeling the effects of the pandemic on their lives and livelihoods.
nso: bjale ka ge ngwaga wo moswa o thoma, malapa a mantši a sa ntše a itemogela ditlamorago tša leuba le maphelong a bona le mo mokgweng wa bona wa boiphedišo.

eng: the world is now entering the second year of the coronavirus pandemic.
nso: lefase bjale le tsena ngwageng wa bobedi wa leuba la coronavirus.

eng: for south africa, as for most countries around the world, the year 2021 will be extremely challenging.
nso: go afrika borwa, go swana le bontši bja dinaga go dikologa lefase, ngwaga wa 2021 o tla ba le ditlhohlo tše ntši kudukudu.

eng: the second wave of covid19 infections may well be followed by further waves, which will threaten both the health of our people and the recovery of our economy.
nso: lephoto la bobedi la diphetetšo tša covid19 le ka no latelwa ke maphoto a mangwe, ao a tlogo ama gampe bobedi maphelo a batho ba rena le tsošološo ya ikonomi ya rena.

eng: difficult as this year will be, i am certain that we will overcome the pandemic and set our country firmly on the path to recovery.
nso: le ge ngwaga wo e tla ba wa boima, ke na le tshepho ya gore re tla fenya leuba le go bea naga ya rena tseleng ye tieletšeng ya tsošološo.

eng: my confidence comes from the south african people.
nso: tshepho ya ka e tšwa go batho ba afrika borwa.

eng: if i look at how south africans responded to this crisis from the moment the virus arrived on our shores, i have no doubt that we have the resilience, discipline and ability to defeat this disease.
nso: ge ke lebelela ka fao maafrika borwa a arabilego masetlapelong a go tloga nakong ya ge baerase e fihla mellwaneng ya rena, ga ke na pelaelo ya gore re na le maatla, taolo le bokgoni bja go fenya bolwetši bjo.

eng: certainly there were exceptions, but the vast majority of south africans understood the need for restrictions on their movement and activities, and complied with the regulations that we had to put in place.
nso: ka nnete go be go na le ditetelo, eupša palo ye ntši ya maafrika borwa e kwešišitše nyakego ya mapheko mesepelong le ditirong tša bona, ebile e latetše melawana yeo re ilego ra swanela ke go e phethagatša.

eng: even more important than compliance, most south africans took responsibility for themselves and for others, following advice on issues like social distancing, wearing a mask and hand washing.
nso: sa bohlokwa gape go feta tatelo, bontši bja maafrika borwa bo ithwaletše maikarabelo le go rwalela ba bangwe, ka morago ga keletšo mabapi le ditaba tša go swana le go fana sekgoba, go apara seširankolemolomo le go hlapa diatla.

eng: and where we fell short, we have, sadly, seen the consequences.
nso: gomme fao re paletšwego, ka manyami, re bone dipoelo.

eng: we now know about the risks of closed spaces and crowded gatherings, of not wearing masks and not keeping our distance from others.
nso: bjale re a tseba ka dikotsi tša mafelo ao a tswaletšwego le dikgobokano tša go pitlagana, go se apare seširankolemolomo le go se fane sekgoba le batho ba bangwe.

eng: we now know much more about the disease and how to prevent its spread.
nso: bjale re tseba tše ntši go fetiša mabapi le bolwetši le gore go thibelwa bjang phatlalalo ya bjona.

eng: and despite what one could call ‘pandemic fatigue’, we are no less determined as south africans to do what needs to be done.
nso: gomme ka ntle le seo motho a ka se bitšago 'go lapišwa ke leuba', ga se re nyefiše bjalo ka maafrika borwa go seo se swanelwago go dirwa.

eng: as we adhere even more rigorously to the basic prevention measures, we will also be rolling out a mass vaccination campaign.
nso: ge re latela gape ka tlhokomelo magato a thibelo a motheo, re tla ba gape re thakgola lesolo le legologolo la mokento.

eng: as more and more people are vaccinated, we will both save lives and progressively reduce the risk of infection across the population.
nso: ge batho ba bantšintši ba kentwa, re tla boloka bobedi maphelo le go gatela pele go fokotša kotsi ya phetetšo go kgabaganya setšhaba.

eng: getting enough vaccines as quickly as possible – and making sure that they reach the people who need them – will be one of the biggest tasks of the year.
nso: go hwetša dithibelamalwetši tše di lekaneng ka lebelo mo go kgonegang – le go kgonthiša gore di fihlelela batho bao ba di nyakang – e tla ba o mongwe wa mešomo ye megolo ya ngwaga.

eng: this will be particularly challenging as every country in the world is clamouring to secure a limited supply of vaccines.
nso: se e tla ba tlhohlo ye kgolo ka ge naga ye nngwe le ye nngwe mo lefaseng e lwela go hwetša kabo ye e lekantšwego ya dithibelamalwetši.

eng: but we are hard at work with partners in business, labour and civil society to make this happen.
nso: eupša re gare re šomišana le bašomišane ka lekaleng la kgwebo, mekgatlong ya bašomi le setšhabeng go dira gore se se direge.

eng: we are working on several fronts to get vaccines, including through the global covax facility, the african union initiative and through our own engagements with vaccine manufacturers.
nso: re šoma ka mahlakoreng ka moka go hwetša dithibelamalwetši, go akaretšwa le ka lesolong la covax la lefase, lesolong la kopano ya afrika le ka dipoledišanong tša rena ka noši le batšweletši ba dithibelamalwetši.

eng: as we act together to overcome the pandemic, we will need to work together to rebuild and transform our economy.
nso: bjalo ka ge re tšea kgato mmogo go fenya leuba, re tla swanela go šomišana go agaleswa le go fetola ikonomi ya rena.

eng: we have both the ability and the will to stimulate economic activity, grow our economy and create jobs.
nso: re na le bobedi bokgoni le thato ya go hlohleletša tiro ya ikonomi, go godiša ikonomi ya rena le go hlola mešomo.

eng: public finances are under extreme strain, now even more so because of the cost of our health response to covid19 and the social and economic relief measures we put in place to assist businesses and poor households.
nso: ditšhelete tša setšhaba di ka fase ga kgatelelo ye kgolo, bjale le go feta pele ka lebaka la ditshenyegelo tša rena tša karabo ya maphelo go covid19 le magato a kimollo a leago le ikonomi ao re a phethagatšang go thuša dikgwebo le malapa ao a hlokago.

eng: the contraction of the economy also meant that tax revenue has declined significantly.
nso: go phuhlama ga ikonomi gape go bolela gore letseno la motšhelo le lona le theogile kudu.

eng: there are some parts of the economy that will take longer to recover due to lower global demand generally and restrictions on international travel.
nso: go na le dikarolo tše dingwe tša ikonomi tšeo di tlogo tšea nako ye teletšana go tsoga ka lebaka la nyako ya fase ya dihlagišwa lefaseng ka kakaretšo le mapheko a maeto a boditšhabatšhaba.

eng: that is why we need to be innovative and focused in our plans to rebuild the economy.
nso: ke ka lebaka leo re swanelago go hlabolla le go šetša mo dipeakanyong tša rena tša kagoleswa ya ikonomi.

eng: significantly, the economic reconstruction and recovery plan that we announced in october last year is based on broad consensus among all social part ners on the actions needed to rebuild the economy.
nso: gagolo, peakanyo ya kagoleswa ya ikonomi le tsošološo yeo re e tsebišitšego ngwaga wa go feta e theilwe godimo ga kwano ye e nabileng magareng a bašomišane ba leago ka moka dikgatong tše di nyakegang go aga ikonomi leswa.

eng: this lays a firm basis for effective cooperation that draws on the resources, capabilities and energies of all sections of society.
nso: se se bea motheo wa go tia wa tšhomišano ye botse yeo e kgoboketšago methopo, mabokgoni le maatla a dikarolo ka moka tša setšhaba.

eng: we are seeing this in various practical ways.
nso: re bona se ka ditsela tša go fapana tša tiragatšo.

eng: for example, we have been working closely with private funders and multilateral development institutions to prepare infrastructure projects in areas like transport, human settlements, water and telecommunications.
nso: mohlala, re be re šomišana kudu le bathekgi ba ditšhelete ba poraebete le diinstitšhušene tša mohlakanelwa tša tlhabollo go beakanya diprotšeke tša mananeokgoparara ka makaleng a go swana le a dinamelwa, madulo a batho, meetse le dikgokagano tša megala.

eng: using the infrastructure fund as one of the vehicles, we are developing funding models for these projects that draw on several sources in both the public and private sectors.
nso: ka go šomiša sekhwama sa mananeokgoparara bjalo ka o mongwe wa mekgwa ye re e šomišago, re bopela diprotšeke tše dimmotlolo tša thekgo ya ditšhelete tšeo di kgoboketšago methopo ya go balega bobedi ka makaleng a setšhaba le a poraebete.

eng: this is particularly important at a time when public finances are limited.
nso: se se bohlokwa kudu bjale ka ge ditšhelete tša setšhaba e le tše nnyane.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus is another example of partnership in action.
nso: tsošološo ya mešomo ya bopresidente ke ye nngwe ya mehlala ya tšhomišano ye e šomago.

eng: understanding that it will take time for economic growth to translate into private sector employment, we have launched the employment stimulus to start creat ing work opportunities now.
nso: go kwešiša gore kgolo ya ikonomi e tla tšea nakwana go fetogela go mešomo ya lekala la poraebete, re thakgotše tsošološo ya mešomo go thoma go hlola dibaka tša mešomo bjale.

eng: this programme is being coordinated from the presiden cy, but is being implemented by a range of government departments and different spheres.
nso: lenaneo le le laolwa ka kantorong ya bopresidente, eupša le phethagatšwa ke dikgoro tša go fapana tša mmušo.

eng: through this programme, tens of thousands of unemployed people are able to both earn and learn as they provide valuable social services.
nso: ka lenaneo le, batho ba masome a diketekete bao ba sa šomego ba kgona bobedi go hwetša letseno le go ithuta ge ba aba ditirelo tša leago tša go ba le mohola.

eng: in time, this programme will include a ‘social employment’ part, where we will partner with other social actors to employ people in a variety of activities – from improving food security, to tackling genderbased violence to upgrading informal settlements – that all contribute to the common good.
nso: mafelelong, lenaneo le le tla akaretša karolo ya 'mošomo wa leago', fao re tlogo šomišana le bakaonafatši ba bophelo go thwala batho ka ditirong tša go fapana – go tloga go kaonafatšo ya khwetšagalo ya dijo, go ya go go šoganeng le dikgaruru tša bong go ya kaonafatšong ya metse ya mešašana – gore ka moka di kgathetema go morero wo mobotse.

eng: all this work is being reinforced by an aggressive focus on those economic reforms that will have the greatest focus on growth.
nso: mošomo wo ka moka o tiišetšwa ke nepišo ye maatla go diphetošo tšeo tša ikonomi tšeo di tlogo nepiša kudukudu godimo ga kgolo.

eng: these include the expansion of electricity generation capacity, making our ports more efficient and competitive, improving access to affordable broadband, and improving turnaround times for water, mining and other licenses.
nso: tše di akaretša katološo ya bokgoni bja tšweletšo ya mohlagase, go dira gore mabopo a rena a šome botse go fetiša le go ba le bokgoni, go kaonafatša phihlelelo ya porotepente ye e sa turego, le go kaonafatša dinako tša phihlelelo ya meetse, meepo le dilaesense tše dingwe.

eng: these efforts are being coordinated and monitored jointly by my office and national treasury.
nso: maiteko a a beakanywa le go lekolwa mmogo ke kantoro ya ka le kgoro ya bosetšhaba ya matlotlo.

eng: there is much to be done in the year ahead.
nso: go na le tše ntši tše di swanelang go dirwa mo ngwageng wo re o lebileng.

eng: and we should be in no doubt that we will have to confront many daunting challenges.
nso: gomme re swanela go se hloke pelaelo ya gore re tla swanela go lebana le ditlhohlo tše ntši tše di tšhošago.

eng: parenting a child with epilepsy allison cooper while it may be a shock for a family to learn that a child has epilepsy, you can build an understanding, loving and accepting environment in which your child can grow and believe in their ability to succeed.
nso: go ba motswadi wa ngwana wa go ba le bolwetši bja go hwa dithunthwane allison cooper mola e ka ba semaka mo go ba lapa go tseba gore ka lapeng go na le ngwana wa go ba le bolwetši bja go hwa dithunthwane, o le motswadi o ka dira gore ngwana wa gago a golele mo lapeng leo le amogetšego, leo le nago le lerato le kwešišo go dira gore ngwana wa gago a gole ka tumelo ya gore o na le bokgoni bja go atlega.

eng: according to epilepsy south africa, parents could be concerned about their child’s future and find epilepsy difficult to accept or talk about.
nso: go ya ka epilepsy south africa, gare ga tše dingwe batswadi ba ka tshwenyega ge ba nagana ka bokamoso bja ngwana wa bona, gomme se se ka dira gore go be boima go bolela ka bona goba go amogela gore bana ba bona ba na le bolwetši bja go hwa dithunthwane.

eng: you may feel angry, depressed, inadequate and guilty, but you can overcome these feelings and your anxiety by educating yourself about the condition.
nso: o ka kwa o befetšwe, o gatelegile monagano, o inyatša le go itshola, eupša o ka fola mo maikutlong le go emiša go ba mo tlalelong ka go ithuta ka bolwetši bjo.

eng: epilepsy is the tendency to have recurrent seizures, which occur when there is an abnormal electrical discharge in the brain.
nso: bolwetši bja go hwa dithunthwane ke bolwetši bja go idibala gantšhi, gomme se se direga ge go na le tokollo ya mohlagase ya go se tlwaelege ka bjokong.

eng: why my child?
nso: gobaneng ngwana wa ka?

eng: understanding epilepsy and why seizures occur doesn’t explain why this happened to your child.
nso: go kwešiša bolwetši bja go hwa dithunthwane le gore gobaneng motho a idibala gantšhi ga go hlalose lebaka la gore se se diragaletšeng go ngwana wa gago.

eng: in approximately 66% of cases, the underlying cause of epilepsy is unknown.
nso: mo dipegong tša go balelwa go tše 66%, mabaka a tlholo ya dithunthwane ga a tsebege.

eng: this is referred to as idiopathic epilepsy.
nso: se se bitšwa dithunthwane tša go se tsebege.

eng: in the remaining cases the underlying causes can be identified, which is known as symptomatic epilepsy.
nso: mo dipegong tša go šala mabaka a tlholo a ka hlaolega, gomme a tsebja bjalo ka dithunthwane tša go ba le dika.

eng: there can be a variety of underlying causes such as a head injury, that can occur at any age; a birth injury, such as a lack of oxygen during birth; fever convulsions, encephalitis, meningitis or childhood measles; and metabolic or biochemical disturbances or imbalances.
nso: go ka ba le mabaka a go fapana a go bo hlola go swana le kgobalo ya hlogo, yeo e ka diregago mo mengwageng efe goba efe; kgobalo ya pelego, go swana le tlhaelelo ya oksitšene nakong ya pelego; dithunthwane tša letadi, go ruruga bjoko, menentšaethisi goba mooko wa bobjana; le go se lekane ga dikhemikhale tša mmele.

eng: a doctor will prescribe medication based on the age, physical condition and type of seizures your child has.
nso: ngaka e tla fana ka dihlare a lebeletše mengwaga, seemo sa mmele le ka fao ngwana wa gago a idibalago ka gona.

eng: remember, anticonvulsant medication does not cure epilepsy but, in most cases, will reduce the frequency and severity of seizures.
nso: gopola, dihlare tša go thibela go idibala ga di fodiši bolwetši bja go hwa dithunthwane eupša, gantši di fokotša bontši le bogale bja go idibala.

eng: some tips on parenting a child with epilepsy: make your child aware of the condition.
nso: maele a mangwe mabapi le go ba motswadi wa ngwana wa go ba le bolwetši bja go hwa dithunthwane: lemoša ngwana wa gago ka bolwetši bjo.

eng: children as young as three can understand that the brain controls the body.
nso: bana ba bonnyane bja mengwaga ye meraro ba ka kwešiša gore bjoko bo laola mmele.

eng: older children should be given a more comprehensive explanation.
nso: bana ba bagolwane ba swanela go fiwa tlhalošo ka botlalo.

eng: inform close relatives and your child’s friends, teachers and other responsible school officials.
nso: tsebiša maloko a kgauswi le bagwera ba ngwana wa gago, barutiši le bahlankedi ba bangwe ba sekolo ba maikarabelo.

eng: ensure your child receives a comprehensive medical assessment by a qualified professional, ideally a neurologist.
nso: kgonthiša gore ngwana wa gago o amogela tshekatsheko ka botlalo ya kalafo ya go dirwa ke setsebi sa go ba le mangwalo a maleba, gabotse ngaka ya bjoko le methapo.

eng: emphasise your child’s abilities and any activity that will improve their selfacceptance, selfworth and selfconfidence.
nso: gatelela bokgoni bja ngwana wa gago le mediro ye mengwe yeo e tlogo kaonafatša boikamogelo bja gagwe, boitlhompho le boitshepho.

eng: ensure adult supervision for some activities, such as swimming.
nso: kgonthiša gore go ba le tlhokomelo ka motho yo mogolo mo medirong ye mengwe, go swana le go rutha.

eng: ensure medication is administered and taken reg ularly as prescribed.
nso: kgonthiša gore dihlare di šomišwa le go nwewa ka mehla bjalo ka ge go laeditšwe.

eng: an honour to lead the african union vukuzenzele unnamed south africa’s term as chair of the african union has come to an end.
nso: ke tlhompho ye kgolo go be re filwe monyetla wa go eta pele ditšhaba tšeo di kopanego (au) vukuzenzele unnamed nako ya afrika bor wa ya go ba mo dulasetulo wa au e fihlile mafelelong.

eng: as we reflect on our year in this position, i am reminded of the old saying that ‘in crisis lies opportunity’.
nso: ge re gadima morago mo re tšwago go ngwaga wa ge re le mo setulong se, ke gopola mmolelo wa kgale woo o rego ‘ngwana le ka mohla wa marumo o a tswa lwa’.

eng: ours was a baptism of fire, having assumed the chairship in the same month the first case of coronavirus was reported on the continent.
nso: ya rena e bile kolobetšo ka mollo, re sa tšwa go tšea bodulasetulo kgweding yona yeo ke ge go begwa ka bolwetši bja kokwanahloko ya khorona kontinenteng.

eng: the priorities we outlined for our term, among them furthering peace and security, the economic empowerment of women and deepening economic integration, had to be immediately and dramatically reoriented to deal with the pandemic.
nso: tšeo di bego di fiwa bohlokwa bja pele di ile tša alwa tafoleng nakong ya boetapele bja rena, gomme magareng ga tšona e bile go tšwetša pele khutšo le tšhireletšo, go matlafatša ekonomi ya basadi le kopanyo ya ekonomi ka go tsenelela, tšeo di ilego tša swanelwa ke gore ka potlako di tšeišwe lenanoga le lengwe gore re swaragane le leuba la bolwetši.

eng: our most pressing task was to steer the focus of the african union to addressing the worst global emergency in over a century.
nso: mošomo wa rena wo o bego o gapeletša go phethagatšwa ka pela e bile wa go hlohleletša au go šomana le bothata bjo bo šorošoro lefaseng bo kilego ba ba gona ngwagakgolo wo o fetilego.

eng: covid19 has affected all the countries on the continent.
nso: covid19 e amile dinaga ka moka kontinenteng.

eng: to date there are more than 3.5 million confirmed cases in africa, and more than 88,000 people have died.
nso: go fihla ga bjale go na le batho ba go feta dimilione tše tharo le seripagare bao go netefaditšwego ba na le bolwetši ka afrika, gomme go šetše go hlokofetše batho ba 88 000. e bile pharela makaleng a tša maphelo, a tša tlhokomelo ya botho, a tša leago le go a tša ekonomi a dinaga tša afrika, tšeo bontši bja tšona di se go tša tlabakelwa ka didirišwa ka mo go lekanetšego gore di kgone go laola tšhoganetšo ya tša maphelo ya bogolo bjo bokaa bjo.

eng: it has been a health, humanitarian, social and economic crisis for african countries, most of whom are inadequately resourced to manage a health emergency of this size.
nso: le ge leuba le le be le sa tlwaelega, go bile bjalo le ka mokgwa woo dinaga tša afrika di ilego tša kopanya dihlogo mmogo go lwantšhana le lona.

eng: and yet, as unprecedented as the nature of the pandemic has been, so too has been the manner in which african countries have come together to fight it.
nso: ka go dira bjalo re be re itshepetše kudu ditswerereng tša kontinente, mabokgoni a yona le dihlongweng tše bjalo ka disenthara tša afrika tša taolo le thibelo ya malwetši (cdc) ya afrika).

eng: in doing so we have drawn principally on the continent’s own expertise, capabilities and institutions such as the africa centres for disease control and prevention (africa cdc).
nso: afrika ga se ya no dula tlhenkge e sa dire selo ge bonabo bja nnete le kotsi ya leuba la bolwetši bjo le thoma go iponagatša.

eng: from the earliest days of the pandemic and led by the au, we swiftly developed a continental response strategy, driven by the africa cdc and regional task forces.
nso: go tloga ka matšatši a mathomothomo a leuba la bolwetši au e re etile pele, ka ponyo ya leihlo re ile ra loga leano la kontinente la boikarabelo leo le bego le hlahlwa ke cdc ya afrika le dihlophatšhomo tša dilete.

eng: we realised that every country on the continent would be severely affected by the pandemic.
nso: re ile ra lemoga gore naga ye nngwe le ye nngwe ka kontinenteng e tlo angwa ke leuba la bolwetši gabohloko.

eng: most would not have the resources needed to meet the public health challenge or to protect their economies.
nso: bontši bja dinaga di be di ka se be le didirišwa tšeo di nyakegago gore di kgotsofatše tlhohlo ya maphelo a setšhaba goba go šireletša diekonomi tša gabobona.

eng: we therefore agreed as african countries to appoint several prominent africans as special envoys, who would engage with international funders and multilateral institutions to make the case for financial support and debt relief on africa’s behalf.
nso: ka gona re kwane bjalo ka dinaga tša afrika gore re kgethe maafrika a mmalwa ao a tsebegago gore e be batseta bao ba ikgethilego bao ba romilwego ke afrika go rerišana le bathekgi ba boditšhabatšhaba le dihlongwa tša dinagabontši ka mašeleng go re bolelela gore re hwetše thekgo ya mašeleng le kimollo ya mekitlana.

eng: in this way, working as a one continent, we were able to achieve debt relief for many countries and financial assistance towards our covid response and economic recovery.
nso: ka tsela ye, ka go šoma bjalo ka kontinente e tee, re ile ra kgona go fihlelela kimollo ya mekitlana ya dinaga tše ntši le thušo ya mašeleng gore re ikarabele go covid19 le tsošološo ya ekonomi.

eng: but much as african countries went to the international community for support, we first helped ourselves – establishing and capitalising a continental covid19 response fund.
nso: feela le ge dinaga tša afrika di ile tša ya go dinaga tša boditšhabatšhaba go kgopela thekgo, re ile ra thoma ka gae ra leka go ithuša – ra hloma le gona go kgoboketša matlotlo a sekhwama sa boikarabelo bja covid19 sa kontinente.

eng: for every partnership forged with betterresourced nations and the international donor community, we set up our own innovative and groundbreaking african medical supplies platform to enable all african countries to quickly secure personal protective equipment and other medical supplies in an equitable, affordable manner.
nso: re ile ra šomiša segwera se sengwe le se sengwe sa rena seo naga ye nngwe le ye nngwe ya rena e nago le sona le dinaga tšeo di ikgonago tšeo di nago le ditlabakelo tše kaone go re phala le seo re nago le sona le ditšhabatšhaba tšeo di ilego tša re fa meneelo, go hloma pulamadibogo ya pholathefomo ya afrika ya kabo ya dihlare ka mekgwa ya rena ya tlholompsha ya go kgontšha dinaga tša afrika ka moka gore di kgone go reka ka pele ditlabakelo tša tšhireletšo ya motho kgahlano le kokwanahloko le di kabelo tše dingwe tša kalafi ka go swana le ka go lekana, ebilego e le ka theko ya go kwega.

eng: and now that the covid19 vaccine is available, we have worked as a collective to ensure that the continent gets its fair share, working with the covax facility and led by our own african vaccine acquisition task team.
nso: moento wa covid19 bjale ka ge o hwetšagala, bjalo ka seboka re šomišane go netefatša gore kontinente e hwetše se tseka sa yona ka tekatekano, re šoma le sehlongwa sa cov ax seo se etilwego pele ke sehlophatšhomo sa rena sa afrika sa go hwetša moento.

eng: vaccine rollout has already commenced on the continent and we aspire to have the majority of the continent’s population vaccinated by the end of 2021 to achieve herd immunity.
nso: thankgollo ya moento e šetše e thomile kontinenteng gomme re nyaka gore mafelelong a ngwaga wa 2021 bontši bja setšhaba kontinenteng bo be bo entilwe gore bontši bja batho ba se fetetšwe bolwetši.

eng: we have acted as one to protect health, people and livelihoods on the continent.
nso: re tšere magato re le seboka go šireletša maphelo, batho le ta boiphedišo kontinenteng.

eng: in doing so, we have demonstrated our capacity for selfreliance and our ability to be the drivers of our own development.
nso: ka go dira bjalo, re laeditše bokgoni bja rena bja go ipota le go kgona go eta tlhabollo ya gaborena pele.

eng: despite the dominance of covid19, we have still managed to make advances in several of our key priorities.
nso: le ge covid19 e be e iphi le maatla, re kgonne go ba le tšwelopelo go ye mengwe ya mešomo ye mentši ye bohlokwa.

eng: during our term, the africa continental free trade area (afcfta) was finally launched, heralding a new era of intraafrican trade and economic integration.
nso: nakong ya ge re le boetapeleng, lesolo la kgwebišano ya tokologo dinageng tša afrika (afcfta) le ile la thankgollwa, e le sešupo sa mekgwa ye meswa ya go dira kgwebo ka gare ga afrika le go kopanya ekonomi.

eng: even under the difficult conditions posed by the pandemic, the continent has pushed ahead with towards the goal of ‘silencing the guns’ on the continent.
nso: le ka tlase ga maemo a boima ao a hlotšwego ke leuba le, kontinente e gapeleditše go tšwetša pele morero wa ‘homotša dithunya’ kontinenteng.

eng: the au has been actively involved in negotiations around the grand ethiopian renaissance dam, in achieving a ceasefire in libya and promoting peace in south sudan.
nso: au e tsweletše go tšea karolo ka mo go bonalago ditherišanong tša grand ethiopian renaissance dam, gore go fihlelelwe tumelano ya go emiša dintwa go la libya le go godiša go hlola khutšo go la south sudan.šedi ye nngwe yeo nako ya rena ya boetapele e bego e lebišitšwe gona ke matlafatšo ya ekonomi ya basadi, yeo e tlago tšwela pele go ba thwaadi le ka morago ga nako ya rena le nakong ka moka ya lesolo la ngwagasome la go akaretša basadi ba afrika mererong ya ditšhelete le ya ekonomi go ya go 2030. ge re neela democratic republic of congo (drc) marapo re tlogela setho se se sebotse sa kontinente se le maemong ao a matlafetšego le go fetišiša.

eng: south africa will continue to play its part to foster integration on the continent, and support the incoming chair and the organisation in its efforts to meet the aspirations of the au’s agenda 2063. when the organisation for african unity was founded in 1963, member states planted the seeds of cooperation and solidarity in pursuit of a better life for all the peoples of africa.
nso: afrika borwa e tla tšwela pele go bapala karolo ya yona ya go hlohletša botee bja kontinente, le go thekga modu lasetulo yo a tlago gammogo le mokgatlo maitekelong a wona a go fihlella ditlhologelo tša lenaneothero la 2063 la au.

eng: they affirmed that african unity was paramount if the welfare and wellbeing of africa’s people was to be assured.
nso: ge mokgatlo wa botee bja afrika o hlongwa ngwageng wa 1963, dinaga maloko di bjetše dipeu tša tirišano le thekgano ka phegelelo ya bophelo bjo bo botse bja batho ka moka ba afrika.

eng: history bears witness that these seeds have not always fallen on fertile ground, and over the years the continental unity project has experienced many hurdles and false starts.
nso: ba tiišeditše gore botee bja afrika bo bohlokwa ge merero ya kagišo le go phela gabotse ga batho ba afrika bo ka netefaletšwa.

eng: but the grave threat posed by this pandemic has galvanised african countries to collective action.
nso: histori e hlatsela gore dipeu tše di be di fela di sa wele mobung wa go nona, gomme ge mengwaga e eya, phorotšeke ya botee bja kontinente bo ile bja kopana le mathata a mantši le gore ga se bja thongwa gabotse.

eng: in the hothouse of the covid19 crisis, the seeds of unity and cooperation planted by our pioneering forebears have come to life and flourished.
nso: le ge go le bjalo, bothata bjo bogologolo bjo bo hlotšwego ke leuba le la bolwetši bo hlohlile gore dinaga tša afrika di ipope ngatana di šomišane.

eng: covid19 vaccine: what you need to know allison cooper with south afri ca’s mass coro navirus disease (covid19) vaccination programme rolling out for healthcare workers in february, vuk’uzenzele sheds some light on what the covid19 vaccine is, how it works and why it’s so important to stop the spread of the virus.
nso: dilo kamoka tšeo o swanetšego go di tseba ka moento wa covid19 allison cooper ka lesolokgoparara la afrika borwa la lenaneo la moento wa bolwetši bja kokwanahloko ya khorona (co vid19) leo le thankgo llwago la bašomi ba tša maphelo kgweding ya dibokwane, vuk’uzenzele e fa lesedi ka ga seo moento wa covid19 e lego sona, ka moo o šomago ka gona le ka moo o lego bohlokwa ka gona go fediša phatlalatšo ya kokwanahloko.

eng: what does a vaccine do?
nso: naa moento o dira eng?

eng: a vaccine trains your body’s immune system (which fights infection), to produce antibodies (proteins that fight disease) – exactly like it would if you were exposed to a virus.
nso: moento o fa mmele wa gago tlhahlo ya tshepetšo ya mašole a mmele (ao a lwantšhanago le phetetšo), go tšweletša mašole a mmele (diproteine tšeo di lwantšhago bolwetši) – go swana le ka moo o bego o tla dira ka gona ge o be o ka lebagana le kokwanahloko.

eng: why is the vaccine so important?
nso: naa ke ka lebaka la eng moento o le bohlokwa?

eng: being vaccinated against covid19 is an effective way to protect yourself against the virus because your risk of infection is reduced.
nso: go entwa kgahlano le covid19 ke tsela yeo e phethagetšego ya go itšhireletša kgahlano le kokwanahloko ye ka lebaka la gore go ba kotsing ga gago ga go fetelwa ke bolwetši bjo go a fokotšega.

eng: you are then less likely to pass the virus on to someone else.
nso: ka gona o ikhwetša go se bonolo gore o fetetše motho yo mongwe ka kokwanahloko ye.

eng: the aim of vaccination is to reach herd immunity – when enough of the population is immune to the virus it provides indirect protection to those who aren’t immune, bringing the spread of the virus under control.
nso: maikemišetšo a moento ke go fihlelela boiphemelobaeraseng bja setšhaba ka bontši – ge setšhaba seo se lekanego se na le mašole a mmele ao a tla go ba šireletša kgahlano le kokwanahloko, e lego seo se fago tšhireletšo go bao ba sa entwago, e lego seo se dirago gore kokwanahloko e laolege.

eng: are vaccines necessary to prevent the spread of covid19?
nso: naa meento e bohlokwa go thibela phetetšo ya bolwetši bja covid19?

eng: there is overwhelming scientific evidence that vaccination is the best defence against serious infections.
nso: go na le bohlatse bjo bontši bja tša mahlale bja gore moento ke tšhireletšo ye kaonekaone kgahlano le phetetšo ya malwetši a kotsi.

eng: will the vaccine stop me from getting covid19?
nso: naa moento o tla nthibela go hwetša bolwetši bja covid19?

eng: no vaccine provides 100% protection.
nso: ga go moento woo o šireletšago kgahlano le malwetši kamoka.

eng: herd immunity also does not provide full protection to those who are not vaccinated.
nso: gore bontši bja batho ga ba kgonege go fetetšwa bolwetši gape ga go fe tšhireletšo yeo e tletšego go bao ba se go ba entwa.

eng: however, with herd immunity, these people will have substantial protection.
nso: le ge go le bjalo, ka bontši bja batho bao go sa kgonegego gore ba fetetšwe bolwetši, bona batho ba ba tla hwetša tšhireletšego yeo e kwagagalago.

eng: is the vaccination safe?
nso: naa moento wo o bolokegile?

eng: covid19 vaccines go through a demanding, multistage testing process, including large trials that involve tens of thousands of people.
nso: meento ya covid19 e fetišwa tlase ga magato a mantši a magolo a tekolo, go akaretšwa masolo a magolo a maitekelo a moento ka go enta diketekete tša batho go leka go bona gore o šoma gabotse.

eng: every vaccine used in south africa’s mass vaccination programme has to be approved by the south african health products regulatory authority.
nso: moento wo mongwe le wo mongwe woo o šomišwago ka afrika borwa wa lenaneo la moento wa mašabašaba o swanetše go fetišwa ke bolaodi bja afrika borwa bja tekolo ya ditšweletšwa tša maphelo.

eng: the oxford universityastrazeneca vaccine has already been approved by various regulators around the world and is being rolled out in other countries.
nso: moento wa yunibesithi ya oxfordastrazeneca o šetše o fetišitšwe ke balekodi lefaseng ka bophara gore o loketše go ka šomišwa, gomme lesolo la go o šomiša dinageng tše dingwe le thankgollotšwe.

eng: who will get the vaccine first?
nso: naa afrika borwa e hwetša kae meento ya yona ya mathomo?

eng: the country’s estimated 1.25 million healthcare workers will receive the vaccine first.
nso: bašomi ba tša maphelo ka na geng bao ba akanyetšwago go milione le kotara ba tla hwetša moento pele.

eng: in phase two, essential workers such as teachers, police, municipal workers, taxi drivers and other frontline personnel; people in institutions such as old age homes, shelters and prisons; and people over 60 and adults with comorbidities will be prioritised.
nso: legatong la bobedi, bašomi ba go aba ditirelo tše bohlokwa bjalo ka barutiši, maphodisa, bašomi ba mmasepala, baotle di ba dithekesi, le bašomi ba bangwe ba diketapele; batho ba dihlongwa tše bjalo ka magae ao go dulago batšofadi, mafelo a tšhireletšo le dikgolego; gammogo le batho bao ba fetilego mengwaga ye 60 le batho ba bagolo ba nago le malwetši a go se alafege le bona ba tla hwetša moento pele.

eng: in phase three, about 22.5 million of the remaining adult population will be vaccinated.
nso: legatong la boraro, go tla entiwa setšhaba seo se šetšego sa batho ba bagolo se ka bago dimilione tše 22.5. go lebeletšwe gore mafelelong a ngwaga wa 2021 batho ba ka bago 67% setšhabeng ebe ba setše ba hweditše moento.

eng: steps to revive the economy vukuzenzele unnamed it will soon be a year since the first reported case of coronavirus disease (covid19) in our country.
nso: dikgato tša go tsošološa ekonomi vukuzenzele unnamed go se go ye kae re tla be re swara ngwaga mola tshwaetšego ya mathomo ya coronavirus e begwago ka mo nageng ya rena.

eng: the pandemic has come at a great cost to both public health and the livelihoods of millions of our people.
nso: leuba le le tlile ka ditshenyegelo tše kgolo tša kalafo mo setšhabeng le maphelong a dimilione tša batho ba rena.

eng: many workers lost part of their income as their work hours were reduced with many being retrenched.
nso: bašomi ba bantši ba lahlegetšwe ke letseno ka ge diiri tša bona tša go šoma di ile tša swanelwa ke go fokotšwa mola ba bangwe ba bantši ba ile ba swanelwa ke go fokotšwa mešomong.

eng: several businesses have incurred heavy losses from scaledback operations.
nso: dikgwebo tše dingwe di lahlegetšwe kudu ka ge di ile tša swanelwa ke go fokotša tšweletšo goba mošomo.

eng: others have had to close.
nso: tše dingwe di ile tša swanelwa ke go tswalela.

eng: people working in the informal sector have also suffered.
nso: bašomi ba lekala leo e sego la semmušo le bona ba ile ba amega kudu.

eng: most difficult of all, the pandemic has claimed the lives of breadwinners in many families, leaving them destitute and fearful for the future.
nso: se bohloko le go feta, leuba le le fetile ka maphelo a bontši bja bahlokomedi ba malapa, moo malapa a šalago a hloka, a tšhogetše bokamoso.

eng: this is why the extensive relief measures we put in place were both necessary and urgent.
nso: ke ka fao magato a a tseneletšego a kimollo a bilego bohlokwa le gona a ilego a swanelwa ke go tšewa ka potlako.

eng: and, now that nearly a year has passed, we can say that these measures have proved effective.
nso: bjale ka ge go fetile nako ye e nyakilego go lekana ngwaga, re ka re magato a a laeditše go ba a katlego.

eng: of the full package of relief measures that we introduced, perhaps the two measures that had the greatest impact were the special covid19 social relief of distress grant and the unemployment insurance fund's (uif) covid19 temporary employer/employee relief scheme, generally known as covid ters.
nso: gare ga magato ao re a tsebešitšego a kimollo, mohlomongwe a mabedi ao a bilego le seabe se segologolo ke thušo ya go ikgetha ya covid19 le sekema sa uif sa kimollo ya nakwana ya mošomi/mongmošomo nakong ya covid19, seo re tlwaetšego go se bitša covid ters.

eng: we would not have been able to roll out these measures in such a short space of time if we had not had an extensive social security infrastructure already in place.
nso: nkabe e se ka mananeokgorarara a go naba a tšhireletšo ya leago ao re šetšego re na le ona, re be re ka se kgone go thakgola magato a ka nako ye kopana ka tsela ye.

eng: we were able to respond to this huge and immediate need in our society thanks to the substantial nationwide infrastructure and systems of the south african social security agency and the uif.
nso: re ile ra kgona go arabela tlhokego ye ye kgolo ya bjako mo setšhabeng sa rena; malebo go mananeokgoparara a rena a go naba naga ka bophara le ditshepetšo tša etšensi ya afrika borwa ya tšhireletšo ya leago (sassa) le sekhwama sa inšorentshe ya bao ba lahlegetšwego ke mešomo (uif).

eng: there were certainly technical and other glitches along the way, but most of these were speedily resolved.
nso: ka kgonthe mathatana a setegeniki le mapheko a mangwe a bile gona ditshepetšong tše, eupša bontši bja ona a ile a rarollwa ka bjako.

eng: these government agencies did outstanding work to enroll millions of new beneficiaries and ensure they were paid.
nso: dietšensi tše tša mmušo di dirile mošomo wa makgethe wa go ngwadiša baholegi ba bafsa ba dimilione le go netefatša gore ba a lefša.

eng: the support provided by the uif was a lifeline to struggling businesses and employees.
nso: thekgo go tšwa go uif e thušitše bašomi le dikgwebo tšeo di bego di goga boima.

eng: it made the difference between companies remaining open and being forced to close, between jobs saved and jobs lost.
nso: e tlišitše phapano gare ga gore dikhamphane di tšwele pele go šoma le gore dikhamphane di gapeletšege go tswalela; gare ga mešomo yeo e bolokilwego le mešomo yeo e lobilwego.

eng: this benefited businesses like sihle’s brew, a restaurant in gauteng, which was able to retain its 18 employees because of the ters scheme.
nso: se se hotše dikgwebo tša go swana le sihle’s brew, lebenkele la go jela ka gauteng, leo bašomi ba lona ba 18 ba ilego ba tšwela pele go ba le mešomo ka lebaka la sekema sa ters.

eng: thanks to government support, mamoshal agae trading and projects, an autoelectrical business in mokopane, was able to pay its workers as well as its rent and rates during the lockdown.
nso: malebo go thekgo go tšwa go mmušo, mamoshalagae trading and projects, kgwebo ya mohlagase wa dikoloi ka mokopane, e ile ya kgona go lefa bašomi ba yona gammogo le rente le ditirelo tša mmasepala ka nako ya kiletšo ya mosepelo.

eng: employees in dire straits were able to receive a portion of their salaries.
nso: bašomi bao ba bego ba le maemong a boima ba ile ba kgona go amogela karolo ya megolo ya bona.

eng: lindiwe ntuli, a paralegal in centurion, has told how receiving her benefits enabled her to work from home and be able to afford her rent.
nso: lindiwe ntuli, mothuši wa ramolao ka centurion, o boletše ka moo dikholego tše di mo kgontšhitšego go šoma a le ka gae le go lefa rente.

eng: there are many stories of companies that have been able to stay afloat over the past year because of the support they received from the uif.
nso: go na le dikanegelo tše ntši mabapi le dikhamphane tšeo di kgonnego go phologa ngwaga wo o fetilego ka thekgo go tšwa go uif.

eng: the same can be said of the small businesses helped by the various grants and loans provided by a number of departments.
nso: go no ba bjalo le ka dikgwebopotlana tšeo di hweditšego thekgo le dikadimo tša ditšhelete go tšwa dikgorong tša go fapafapana.

eng: these measures greatly helped our people in their time of need.
nso: magato a a thušitše batho ba rena kudu nakong yeo ba bego ba hloka thušo.

eng: as we transition from relief to recovery, we have to shift gear.
nso: ge re etšwa kimollong gomme re kokotlela, re swanetše go fetola ditsela tša go dira dilo.

eng: while these relief measures were designed to be temporary, the economy will continue to feel the effects of the pandemic for some time.
nso: le ge magato a a kimollo a beakantšwe go ba a nakwana, ekonomi e tla itemogela seabe sa leuba nako ye telele.

eng: even as lockdown restrictions have been eased, many companies are struggling to cope with the fallout of months of diminished operations and lost revenue.
nso: le ge dikiletšo tša mosepelo di fokoditšwe, go sa le boima go dikhamphani tše ntši go tšwa ditšhaleleong tšeo di hlotšwego ke go se šome dikgwedikgwedi le tahlegelo ya letseno.

eng: it is for this reason that, following extensive discussion with social partners at the national economic development and labour council the covid ters benefit has been extended until 15 march 2021 for sectors that have not been able to fully operate.
nso: ke lebaka leo, morago ga ditherišano tša go tsenelela le bašomimmogo ba rena ba tša leago lekgotleng la bosetšhaba la mešomo le tlhabollo ya ekonomi (nedlac), dikholego tša covid ters di katošeditšwego go 15 hlakola 2021, bakeng sa makala ao a sa kago a kgona go šoma ka botlalo.

eng: the special covid grant has been extended for another three months.
nso: thušo ya go ikgetha ya covid e katošitšwe ka dikgwedi tše dingwe tše tharo.

eng: our focus now must be on creating an enabling environment for businesses to recover, and for economic growth that spurs job creation and attracts invest ment.
nso: maemo a e tla dula e le a nako ye kopana.šedi ya rena bjale e swanetše go lebišwa tlholong ya tikologo ya go kgontšha dikgwebo go kokotlela, le go kgolo ya ekonomi ya go hlola mešomo le go goketša dipeeletšo.

eng: the recovery will be difficult and will take time, not least because we are still in the midst of the pandemic.
nso: go kokotlela go tla ba boima le gona go tla tšea nako, kudukudu ka gore re sa lebane le leuba.

eng: important as these relief measures are now, we will not be able to sustain them indefinitely.
nso: le ge maemo a a kimollo a tloga a le bohlokwa, re ka se kgone go tšwela pele ka ona go ya go ile.

eng: we need to make sure that these relief measures provide a firm foundation for a broader recovery without driving the country deeper into debt.
nso: re hloka go netefatša gore maemo a a kimollo a fana ka motheo wo maatla go kgontšha go kokotlela go go nabilego, ntle le go tsenya naga dikolotong tša tlaleletšo.

eng: unless we can bring our national debt down to sustainable levels no meaningful economic recovery will be possible.
nso: ntle le gore re fokotše sekoloto sa rena sa bosetšhaba, gore se be maemong ao re kago se kgona, ekonomi ya rena e ka se kokotlele ka tsela ya go bonala.šedi ya setšhaba sa rena bjale e swanetše go feta kgatong ya kimollo, e lebišwe kgatong ya kokotlelo, gomme ka moka re swanetše go ba karolo ya maitapišo a. bjale ka mmušo re tla swanelwa ke go tšea diphetho tše boima ngwageng wo mabapi le tšhomišo ya tšhelete ya setšhaba, le go tsenya tirišong diphetho tšeo.

eng: companies will need to be innovative in driving methods and processes that secure their sustainability and profitability, with job retention being their foremost consideration.
nso: dikhamphani di tla swanelwa ke go ba mahlahla taolong ya ditsela le ditshepetšo tša go netefatša gore di kgona go ikemela gape le gore di ba le letseno, moo tšhireletšo ya mešomo e lego nepo ya tšona ya pele.

eng: we must put our money back into our economy by buying local products, supporting local businesses and industrie and procuring from local suppliers.
nso: re swanetše go bušetša ditšhelete tša rena ekonoming ya rena ka go reka ditšweletšwa tša ka mo nageng, go thekga dikgwebo le diintaseteri tša tikologo le go reka dithoto le ditirelo go tšwa go baabaditirelo ba tikologo.

eng: an injured patient with strong prospects for recovery is given regular phys ical therapy to help them get stronger until they can stand unaided.
nso: molwetši yo a gobetšego yo a nago le dikgonagalo tše maatla tša go kokotlela o fiwa phekolo ya mmele ka mehla go mo thuša go maatlafala, go fihlela a kgona go ikemiša ka noši ntle le thušo.

eng: so must these temporary relief measures be seen as the means to get our economy back on its feet.
nso: go no ba bjalo le ka magato a a kimollo ya nakwana; a swanetše go tšewa bjalo ka tsela ya go thuša ekonomi ya rena gore e boele e ikemele.

eng: our ultimate goal is to walk again.
nso: nepo ya rena ke gore mafelelong re kgone go itshepetša gape.
