eng: the centre brings together the investigative capabilities of government’s crime prevention and security structures and those of the financial intelligence centre, which develops intelligence for law enforcement agencies to use in their investigations.
nso: lefelo le le kopanya mmogo bokgoni bja dinyakišišo bja makala a mmušo a thibelo ya bosenyi le tšhireletšo le bja lefelo la bohlodi bja ditšhelete, leo le hlomago bohlodi bja ditheo tša phethagatšo ya mošomo go bo šomiša ka dinyakišišong tša bona.

eng: two years since the fusion centre was established, its multidisciplinary approach to ‘follow the money’ has yielded significant results.
nso: mengwaga ye mebedi go tloga mola lefelo la kopanyomešomo le hlo ngwago, mokgwa wa lona wa makala a mantši a ‘go latelela tšhelete’ o tšweleditše dipoelo tše kgolo.

eng: in the last financial year, the work of the fusion centre supported 276 fraud and corruption investigations.
nso: mo ngwageng wo o fetilego, mošomo wa lefelo la kopanyomešomo o thekgile dinyakišišo tša tsogolekobong le bomenetša tše 276. tšhelete ye e ka bago r659 milione e bušeditšwe mmušong ka go lota le go hwetša dipoelo tša go hwetšwa ka bosenyi.

eng: approximately r659 million was restored to the state through preservation and recovery of the proceeds of crime.
nso: tshepedišo ya tšhelete ye e ka bago r613 milione yeo e hweditšwego ka ditiro tše go belaelwago gore ke tša bosenyi e ile ya emišwa.

eng: the fusion centre was initially set up to investigate corruption around covidrelated procurement.
nso: lefelo la kopanyomešomo mathomong le ile la hlongwa ka maikgafo a go nyakišiša bomenetša bja mabapi le dithendara tše di amanago le covid .

eng: its mandate is now being expanded to include moneylaundering, fraud, maladministration, terrorist financing and other serious financial crimes.
nso: mošomo wa lona bjale o katološitšwe go akaretšwa go hlatswa tšhelete, bora dia, tšhomišobošaedi ya ditšhelete, go thekga bogo gelathoko ka ditšhelete le melato ye mengwe ye e šiišago ya ditšhelete.

eng: the hawks recently outlined some of the progress that has been made by the anticorruption task team, of which the fusion centre forms part.
nso: mo nakong ye e sa tšwago go feta the hawks e adile kgatelopele yeo e dirilwe go ke sehlophatšhomo sa twantšho ya bomenetša, yeo lekala la kopanyomošomo le bopago karolo ya yona.

eng: between the 2019 and 2022 financial years, 554 suspects were arrested for corruption, of which 142 were convicted.
nso: magareng ga ngwaga wa ditšhelete wa 2019 le wa 2022, bagononelwa ba 554 ba ile ba golegwa gore ba dirile bomenetša, gomme go bona ba 142 ba ile ba bonwa molato.

eng: another vital financial intelligence tool is the lifestyle audits conducted by the south african revenue service (sars).
nso: setlabelo se sengwe se bohlokwa sa bohlodi bja dišhelete ke tekodišišo ya mekgwa ya bophelo yeo e dirwago ke tirelo ya metšhelo ya afrika borwa (sars).

eng: last year, sars completed 25 lifestyle audits to the value of over r450 million to resolve discrepancies between declared income and an individual’s lifestyle.
nso: ngwageng wo o fetilego, sars e phethile ditekodišišo tša mekgwa ya bophelo tše 25 tša boleng bja r450 milione ka nakong ya go rarolla go se amane magareng ga letseno leo le begilwego le mokgwa wa bophelo wa motho.

eng: it is clear that the measures we have taken as this administration to restore the capacity, capability and credibility of the institutions involved in the fight against corruption are having a demonstrable impact.
nso: go molaleng gore magato ao re a tšerego bjalo ka pušo ye a go bušetša sekeng bokgoni, botsebi le seriti sa dihlongwa tšeo di kgathago tema ka ntweng kgahlanong le bomenetša a na le seabe seo se bonagalago.

eng: the synchronised work of all the law enforcement agencies is hitting criminals where it hurts most: in their pockets.
nso: mošomo wo o kopa ntšwego wa ditheo tša phethagatšo ya molao ka moka o betha basenyi fao ba kwago bohloko kudu gona: ka dipotleng tša bona.

eng: public funds that were looted and diverted are being recovered and those responsible for these acts are being prosecuted by our courts.
nso: ditšhelete tša setšhaba tšeo di utswitšwego le go timetšwa di a utollwa gomme bao ba rwelego maikarabelo a ditiro tše ba sekišwa ke dikgorotsheko tša rena.

eng: to further strengthen our efforts to turn the tide against corruption, i am announcing appointments to the national anticorruption advisory council.
nso: go tšwela pele go maatlafatša matsapa a rena a go fetoša ntwa kgahlanong le bomenetša, ke tsebagatša go thwalwa ga batho go ya ka lekgotleng la keletšo kgahlanong le bomenetša la bosetšhaba.

eng: look out for early signs of childhood cancer more matshediso a lack of awareness of childhood cancer and its symptoms means that many south african children are diagnosed when the disease is at an advanced stage.
nso: lebelela maswao a kankere ya bana nako e sa le gona more matshediso tlhokego ya temošo ya kankere ya bana le maswao a yona go ra gore bontši bja bana ba ka afrika borwa ba phekolwa gore ba na le bolwetši bjo ge bo šetše go kekile.

eng: the earlier cancer is diagnosed and treated, the higher the chance of a full recovery.
nso: ge kankere e ka phekolwa nako e sa le gona gomme ya alafša, go na le kgonagalo ye ntši ya gore molwetše a ka fola fodi.

eng: childhood cancer foundation south africa (choc) communication coordinator taryn seegers says by knowing the common signs of cancer in young people, you could help save a life.
nso: mokgokaganyi wa dipoledišano wa setheo sa kankere ya bana sa afrika borwa (choc) taryn see gers o bolela gore ge o tseba maswao ao a tlwaelegilego a kankere go bana, o ka thuša go phološa bophelo.

eng: "the signs and symptoms can be difficult to spot amid the normal bumps, bruises, growth spurts and mood swings.
nso: "dika le maswao go ka ba boima go a bona ka lebaka la ge bana e le setlwaedi go ba le dikutwana, go ruruga, go gola ka lebelo le go tšeega maikutlo kgafetšakgafetša.

eng: however, early detection is key," she says.
nso: le ge go le bjale, go utolla bolwetši bjo ka pela go bohlokwa," a realo.

eng: according to the cancer association of south africa (cansa), between 800 to 1 000 south african children are diagnosed with cancer each year.
nso: go ya ka mokgatlo wa kankere wa afrika borwa (cansa), magareng ga bana ba 800 go fihla go ba 1 000 ba ka afrika borwa ba phekolwa gore ba na le kankere ngwaga o mongwe le o mongwe.

eng: however, the association estimates that half of the children with cancer in south africa are never diagnosed.
nso: le ge go le bjale, mokgatlo wo o akanya gore seripa gare sa bana bao ba nago le kankere ka afrika borwa ga ba ke ba phekolwa gore ba na le yona.

eng: to help ensure cancer is spotted as soon as possible, choc runs awareness programmes in communities, telling parents and children about the early warning signs they must look out for.
nso: go thuša go netefatša gore kankere e utollwa ka pela ka fao go kgonagalago, choc e sepetša mananeo a temošo ditšhabeng, e botša batswa di le bana ka ga maswao a ka pela a temošo ya kanke re ao ba swanetšego go a hlokomela.

eng: the foundation supports children and teenagers with cancer or lifethreatening blood disorders and their families.
nso: setheo se se thekga bana le bafsa ba mahlalagading ba ba nago le kankere goba malwetši a go ba kotsi a madi gammogo le ba malapa a bona.

eng: "we aim to improve early detection and facilitate effective treatment.
nso: "re ikemišeditše go kaonafatša bokgoni bja go utolla kankere ka pela le go nolofatša kalafo ye e šomago gabotse.

eng: at any one time, choc can have over 1 500 children and teenagers in its care, while offering psychosocial support to over 1 500 families," says seegers.
nso: ka nako efe goba efe, choc e ka kgona go hlokomela bana le bafsa ba mahlalagading ba go feta ba 1 500, mola ka go le lengwe e fana ka thekgo ya tša leago go malapa a go feta a 1 500," gwa bolela seegers.

eng: in the past financial year, seegers says choc was able to serve 1 724 children, 553 teenagers and 2 232 adults through its core programmes.
nso: mo ngwageng wa ditšhelete wo o fetilego, seegers o bolela gore choc e kgonne go direla bana ba 1 724, bafsa ba mahlalaga ding ba 553 le batho ba bagolo ba 2 232 ka go diriša mananeo a yona a motheo.

eng: "our services include emotional support through their cancer journey, comfort, endoflife care and bereavement support," says seegers.
nso: "ditirelo tša rena di akaretša thekgo ya maikutlo ge ba le gare ba phela le kankere, khomotšo, tlho komelo ya bao ba bakwago le badimo le thekgo ka tša poloko go bao ba hlokofaletšwego," gwa bolela seegers.

eng: st siluan’s signs of childhood cancer s – seek medical help early for ongoing symptoms.
nso: maswao a kanke re ya bana ao a reetšwego ka st siluan s – nyaka thušo ya tša kalafo e sa le ka pela mabapi le maswao ao a sa iphodišego.

eng: i – white spot in the eye, new squint, sudden blindness or bulging eyeball.
nso: i – dipatso tše tšhweu ka leihlong, go thoma go leana mahlo, go foufala mo go hlagelelago go na mo goba thaka ya leihlo ye e rurugago.

eng: the n3 upgrade is empowering south africans owen mngadi mduduzi jijana is the owner of the disability empowerment movement, which is one of the companies that is currently benefiting from the r26 billion upgrade of the n3 highway between pietermaritzburg and durban in kwazulunatal.
nso: mpshafatšo ya n3 e matlafatša maafrika borwa owen mngadi mduduzi jijana ke mong wa disability empowerment movement yeo e lego ye nngwe ya dikhamphani tšeo di holegago gabjale go tšwa mpshafatšong ya tsela ya lephefo ya n3 yeo e jelego dibilione tše 26 tša diranta gareng ga pietermaritzburg le durban ka kwazulunatal.

eng: the project, which is being spearheaded by the south african national roads agency soc limited (sanral), is ensuring that entrepreneurs such as jijana not only benefit but in turn create employment for others.
nso: projeke ye, yeo e etilwego pele ke ba south african national road agency soc limited (sanral), e netefatša gore baipereki ba bjalo ka jijana ga ba holege feela empa ba hlolela le batho ba bangwe mešomo.

eng: jijana, who lives with a disability, says his company installs road signs between hilton and pietermaritzburg.
nso: jijana, yoo a phelago ka bogolofadi, o re khamphani ya gagwe e tsenya maswao a tsela gareng ga hilton le pietermaritzburg.

eng: he employs 13 people and says the project has changed their lives.
nso: yena o thwetše batho ba 13 gomme o re projeke ye e fetotše maphelo a bona.

eng: "as people living with a disability, we have shown that we are capable.
nso: "bjalo ka batho bao ba phelago ka bogolofadi, re bontšhitše gore re a kgona.

eng: we do the actual work," says jijana.
nso: re a šoma," gwa realo jijana.

eng: sanral n3 programme manager tsepo matekane says his company ensured that 30% of the work was assigned to local companies with the ability to provide various services.
nso: molaodi wa mananeo ka sanral n3, tsepo matekane, o re khamphani ya gabo e netefaditše gore dipersente tše 30 tša mošomo di fiwa dikhamphani tša kgauswi tšeo di nago le bokgoni bja go aba ditirelo tša go fapafapana.

eng: this created many opportunities for small businesses owned by youth, previously disadvantaged people and women.
nso: se se hlotše menyetla go dikha mphani tše nnyane tšeo beng ba tšona e lego baswa, batho bao ba bego ba gateletšwe peleng mmogo le basadi.

eng: "there are 108 small, medium and micro enterprises currently working on the various projects," he says.
nso: "go na le dikhamphani tše nnyane, tša magareng le tše nnyanennyane tše 108 tšeo gabjale di šomago ka dipro jekeng tša go fapafapana," a realo.

eng: nokuthula zondi of ingqalabutho yamalinda multipurpose trading was awarded a contract to supply soil and install water drainage pipes.
nso: nokuthula zondi wa ingqalabutho yamalinda multipurpose trading yena o filwe konteraka ya go aba mabu le go tsenya diphaephe tša go gamola meetse.

eng: she says her company employed eight skilled workers, including drivers.
nso: yena o re khamphani ya gagwe e thwetše batho ba seswai bao ba nago le mabo kgoni, go balwa le baotledi.

eng: zondi adds that women are as capable as men and her company has a good service track record.
nso: zondi o tlaleletša ka gore basadi ba na le bokgoni bja go swana le bja banna gomme khamphani ya gagwe e na le rekote ya bohlatse bja go laetša bokgoni bja yona bja kabo ya ditirelo.

eng: "we understand the importance of time and meet all our targets to ensure the project runs accordingly.
nso: "re kwešiša bohlokwa bja nako gomme re fihlelela dinepo tša rena go netefatša gore projeke e sepela botse.

eng: we appreciate the opportunity and we hope more will come so that our company can grow according to construction levels," she adds.
nso: re tloga re leboga monyetla wo gomme re holofela go hwetša e mengwe menyetla gore khamphani ya rena e gole go ya le ka maemo a tša boagi," a tlaleletša ka go realo.

eng: national government’s key projects matekane says the durbanfree stategauteng logistics and industrial corridor development has an estimated budget of r26 billion and is one of national government’s key strategic integrated projects.
nso: diprojeke tše bohlokwa tša mmušo wa bosetšhaba matekane o bolela gore kaonafatšo ya kgorwana ya tshepetšo ya dithoto le diintaseteri ya durbanfree stategauteng e na le tekanyetšo yeo e ka bago dibi lione tše 26 tša diranta gomme ebile ke ye nngwe ya diprojeke tše bohlokwa tša mmušo wa bosetšhaba tša togamaano e kopantšwego yeo e tsebegago ka la sip2.

eng: the project will widen the n3 with more lanes in each direction.
nso: projeke ye e tla oketša n3 ka bophara bja yona ka go oketša mekgothana go ba e mene goba e mehlano ka mahlakoreng ka moka, gomme le maphamoganomagolo a ditsela a tla be a fetotšwe go kaonafatša kelelo ya sephethephethe.

eng: it also includes changing some of the major interchanges to improve traffic flow.
nso: karolo yeo e amegilego ya n3 e be e dutše e itemogela sephethephethe se sentšhi, kudu nakong yeo bontšhi bja difatanaga di tla bego di le tseleng, ka baka la bontšhi bja dilori tša go rwala merwalo go tloga lebopong la durban di šomiša tsela ya lephefo go ya gauteng le diprofenseng tše dingwe tša ka gare ga naga.

eng: the affected section of the n3 has over the years experienced traffic congestion, particularly during peak hours because the majority of cargo trucks from the durban harbour use the highway to gauteng and other inland provinces.
nso: go bile gape le palo e ntšhi ya dikotsi tša tsela tšeo di hlotšwego ke baotledi ba dilori tša go rwala merwalo bao ba sa hlokomelego ge ba feta moo tsela e tepogago ka pejana.

eng: some of the cargo truck drivers have caused accidents by not taking care on sharp curves.
nso: "ntle le go rarolla bothata bja sephethephethe ka go kaonafatša tshepelo ya difatanaga ka go aga mekgothana ya tlaleletšo, mpshafatšo ya n3 e tla oketša gape le polokego.

eng: dangerous curves will be ironed out.
nso: ditepogo tše kotsi di tla kaonafatšwa.

eng: unsafe intersections will be redesigned," maketane says.
nso: makopano a ditsela ao a sa bolokegago a tla hlangwa leswa," gwa realo matekane.

eng: sanral awarded three contracts in the last quarter of 2021, and construction work began between january and april.
nso: sanral e fane ka dikonteraka tše tharo ka kotareng ya mafelelo ya 2021, gomme mošomo wa go aga tsela o thomile gareng ga pherekgo ng le moranang.

eng: the sections currently being upgraded are the 19 kilometre (km) stretch from cato ridge to dardanelles, commonly known as umlaas road; the 26.6 km section from the dardanelles interchange to lynnfield park; and the 30 km stretch from lynnfield park to the ashburton interchange.
nso: dikarolo tšeo di mpshafatšwago gabjale ke ya dikilomitara tše 19 go tloga cato ridge go ya dardanelles yeo e tsebegago ka la umlaas road; ya dikilomitara tše 26.6 go tloga phamoganong ya ditsela ya dardanelles go ya lynnfield park; le ya dikilomitara tše 30 go tloga lynnfield park go ya phamoganong ya ditsela ya ashburton.

eng: matekane explains that sip2 will strengthen the logistics and transport corridor between south africa’s main industrial hubs, improve access to durban’s export and import facilities and raise efficiency along the corridor.
nso: matekane o hlalosa gore sip2 e tla matlafatša kgorwana ya tshepetšo ya dithoto le dinamelwa gareng ga mafelomagolo a diintaseteri ka afrika borwa, ya kaonafatša phihlelelo e kaone ya mafelo a tša thomelontle le thomelokanageng ka durban gomme ya ba ya dira gore mošomo o sepele botse kgorwaneng yeo.

eng: alcohol may damage your unborn baby’s health vukuzenzele unnamed pregnant women have the responsibility to not drink because alcohol can cause a condition that affects a baby’s development.
nso: bjala bo ka ba kotsi bophelong bja ngwana yoo o mo imilego vukuzenzele unnamed basadi ba baimana ba na le maikarabelo a gore ba se nwe ka baka la gore bjala bo ka hlola bolwetši bjoo bo amago tlhabologo ya ngwana.

eng: this is according to the deputy minister of social development, hendrietta bogopanezulu, who recently launched the 999 foetal alcohol spectrum disorder (fasd) advocacy programme.
nso: se ke go ya ka motlatšatona wa tlhabollo ya leago, hendrietta bogopanezulu yoo a tsebagaditšego lenaneo la tshebotšo la 999 foetal alcohol spectrum disorder (fasd).

eng: the aim of the initiative is to encourage communities to help protect unborn babies by educating people, especially women of childbearing age, about the dangers of drinking alcohol while pregnant or breastfeeding.
nso: maikemišetšo a lesolo le ke go hlohleletša ditšhaba go thuša go šireletša masea ao a sešogo a belegwa ka go ruta batho, kudu basadi bao ba lego mengwageng ya go dira bana, ka ga dikotsi tša go nwa mola ba imile goba ba nyantšha.

eng: "it is important for all women who are pregnant and those who wish to give birth to healthy babies to avoid alcohol.
nso: "go bohlokwa gore basadi ka moka bao ba imilego mmogo le bao ba nyakago go bona ba belega bana bao ba phetšego botse ba efoge go nwa bjala.

eng: the damage caused by fasd is permanent and irreversible, and children born with this condition have physical and intellectual problems," said deputy minister bogopanezulu at the launch.
nso: kotsi yeo e hlolwago ke fasd ke ya go ya go ile ebile ga e dirolloge, gomme bana bao ba belegwa go ba na le bolwetši bjo ba ba le mathata ao a amago mmele le monagano," gwa realo motlatšatona bogopanezulu nakong ya tsebagatšo.

eng: she added that south africa is known to have a drinking problem, with the country ranking among the worst in the world for its levels of alcohol consumption.
nso: yena o tlaleleditše ka gore afrika borwa e tsebega ka go ba le bothata bja go nwa bjala kudu, gomme naga ye e gareng ga dinaga tšeo di nwago bjala gampe lefaseng.

eng: deputy minister bogopanezulu recently visited different parts of the country, educating women about the dangers of drinking alcohol while pregnant as part of the 999 fasd campaign.
nso: motlatšatona bogopanezulu o sa tšwa go etela dikarolo tšeo di fapafapanego tša naga a ruta basadi ka ga dikotsi tša go nwa ba imile, e le karolo ya lesolo la 999 fasd.

eng: when she was in boitekong in rustenburg in the north west, she told residents that the levels of alcohol abuse in the township are alarming.
nso: ge a be a le boitekong ka rustenburg ka profenseng ya leboabodikela, o boditše badudi ba fao gore maemo a tšhomišompe ya bjala ka lekeišeneng leo a a tšhoša.

eng: a fourmonth pregnant woman and resident of boitekong, basetsana tlalang (28), who attended one of the campaigns, said she stopped drinking alcohol entirely after learning she was pregnant and said she is attending antenatal and information sessions at the clinic.
nso: moimana wa kgwedi tše nne yoo gape e lego modudi wa boiketlong, basetsana tlalang (28), yoo a tsenetšego le lengwe la masolo, o rile o lesitše go nwa ka botlalo ge a se no lemoga gore o imile, gomme a be a re o tsenela disešene tša tshedimošo ya pele ga pelego kliniking.

eng: she urged other pregnant women to immediately stop drinking alcohol and doing drugs.
nso: yena o hlohleleditše baimana ba bangwe go lesa gonabjale go nwa bjala le go lesa go šomiša diokobatši.

eng: the struggle to give south africa a more human face vukuzenzele unnamed on 12 september 1977, stephen bantu biko died in police custody in pretoria central prison.
nso: go lwela go aga afrika borwa ye e laetšago tlhompho go ditokelo tša botho vukuzenzele unnamed ka la 12 lewedi 1977, stephen bantu biko o ile a hlokofala a le kgolegong ya pretoria central.

eng: human dignity, the principle at the heart of his black consciousness activism, was denied to him.
nso: seriti sa motho, e lego kokwane yeo e bego e le pelong ya bolwelatokologo bja gagwe bja phahlogo ya bathobaso, o ile a se tingwa.

eng: in the words of the family lawyer sir sydney kentridge, his was "a miserable and lonely death on a mat on a stone floor in a prison cell".
nso: ka mantšu a ramolao wa lapa, sir sydney kentridge, lehu la gagwe e bile "le sehlogo la bodutu godimo ga mmetse lebatong la leswika ka seleng ya kgolego".

eng: it remains a source of great sorrow all these years later to recall that steve biko was just 30 years old when he died.
nso: e sa dutše e le tiragalo ya masetlapelo le ka morago ga mengwaga ye ka moka ge re gopola gore steve biko o be a na le mengwaga e 30 feela ge a hlokofala.

eng: he was cut down in his prime by those who feared the power and resonance of his ideas of selfliberation and his efforts to infuse black men and women with pride and dignity.
nso: bophelo bja gagwe bo ile bja fedišwa ke bao ba bego ba tšhaba maatla le kwalakwatšo ya dikgopolo tša gagwe tša boitokollo mmogo le maitekelo a gagwe a go hlahlelela banna le basadi ba bathobaso ka boikgantšho le seriti.

eng: he never got to see in his lifetime what he called ‘the glittering prize’, the realisation of a true humanity.
nso: nakong ya go phela ga gagwe ga sa ka a bona seo a bego a se bitša ‘sefoka sa go phadima’, e lego boitemogelo bja botho bja nnete.

eng: writing about this ideal, he famously said: "in time we shall be in a position to bestow upon south africa the greatest gift possible – a more human face.
nso: ge a be a ngwala ka kgopolo ye, o ile a bolela mantšu a a go tuma: "ge nako e dumela re tlo ba seemong seo re kgonago go fa afrika borwa mpho e botsebotse ka moo go kgonegago, e lego sefa hlego sa go laetša botho.

eng: "when we won our freedom in 1994, we understood that the right to vote was just one part of our struggle for human dignity.
nso: "ge re se no thopa tokologo ka 1994, re kwešišitše gore tokelo ya go bouta ke ye nngwe ya dikarolo tša ntwa ya rena ya go lwela seriti sa motho.

eng: twentyeight years into our democracy, we are confronted with many challenges, such as poverty, unemployment and inequality.
nso: mengwaga e 28 re le ka gare ga demokrasi, re lebagane le ditlhotlo tše ntšhi tše bjalo ka bodiidi, tlhokego ya mešomo le go se lekalekane.

eng: as a result, we often lose sight of how far we have come in giving effect to the principles on which our constitution is founded and that anchored steve biko’s thought and teachings.
nso: ka baka la seo, re fela re palelwa ke go bona gore re tšwa kgole bjang ge go etla phethagatšong ya diko kwane tšeo molaotheo wa rena o theilwego go tšona gomme ebile di sepelelanago thwii le dikgopolo le dithuto tša steve biko.

eng: in 1977 a heartless regime killed one of our country’s most promising leaders by depriving him of the food, water and medical treatment he urgently needed as a result of brutal beatings by the apartheid police.
nso: ka 1977 mmušo wa pelo e mpe o bolaile yo mongwe wa batho bao ba bego ba laetša boetapele ka go mo tima dijo, meetse le kalafo yeo a bego a e hloka ka tšhoganetšo ka baka la go bethwa ošoro ke maphodisa a mmušo wa kgethollo.

eng: twenty years later, in a 1997 judgment, the constitutional court said that fulfilling the fundamental rights of every citizen and striving to achieve their socioeconomic rights is the hallmark of a democratic society aiming to salvage lost dignity.
nso: morago ga mengwaga e 20, kahlolong ya 1997, kgoro tsheko ya molaotheo e boletše gore go phethagatša ditokelo tša motheo tša modudi yo mongwe le yo mongwe gape le go lwela go fihlelela ditokelo tša bona tša leago le ikonomi ke kokwanekgolo ya setšhaba sa go phela ka demokrasi seo se nepilego go tsošološa seriti seo se se lobilego.

eng: in south africa today, we continue to work to fulfil the basic rights of every south african so that they may lead quality lives free of disease, hunger and deprivation.
nso: lehono ka mo afrika borwa re tšwela pele go šoma go phethagatša ditokelo tša motheo tša moafrika borwa yo mongwe le yo mongwe gore a kgone go phela bophelo bja boleng bja go hloka malwetši, tlala le bohloki.

eng: successive democratic administrations have implemented policies to salvage the lost dignity of this country’s majority by providing education, health care, housing and basic services.
nso: mebušo ya go latelana ya demokrasi e phethagaditše melao ya go tsošološa seriti seo se lobilwego sa bontšhi bja badudi ba ka mo nageng ka go aba thuto, tlhokomelo ya maphelo, dintlo le ditirelo tša motheo.

eng: in south africa today, a decent education is a fundamental right.
nso: lehono ka mo afrika borwa thuto ya go tšea botse ke tokelo ya motheo.

eng: the state invests in early childhood development, in supporting learning outcomes for our youngest citizens, and provides social relief through school feeding programmes to ensure young learners achieve the best outcomes possible.
nso: mmušo o beeletša ka kaonafatšong ya thuto ya digotlane e le ge o thekga dinepo tša go ithuta tša badudi ba ka nageng ba bannyanennyane, gomme ebile o fana ka kimollo ya leago ka mokgwa wa mananeo a phepo dikolong go netefatša gore barutwana ba bannyane ba fihlelela dinepo tše kaonekaone ka moo go kgonegago.

eng: through the national student financial aid scheme and various other forms of state support, thousands of young south africans from poor backgrounds have been able to become doctors, lawyers, teachers, scientists, artisans and entrepreneurs.
nso: ka sekhwama sa bosetšhaba sa thušo ya tšhelete go baithuti (nsfas) mmogo le mehuta e mengwe ya dithekgo tša go tšwa go mmušo, diketekete tša baswa ba maafrika borwa go tšwa malapeng a go ihlokela di kgonne go ba dingaka, boramolao, barutiši, borasaense, diathisene le baipereki.

eng: government supports poor and vulnerable citizens through an extensive social safety net and provides work opportunities through mass public employment programmes.
nso: mmušo o thekga badudi bao ba ihlokelago ebile ba sa bolokegago ka mananeo a polokego ya leago gomme ebile o fana ka menyetla ya mešomo ka mananeo a setšhaba a thwalo ya batho ba bantšhi.

eng: in the repressive south africa in which steve biko died, freedom of speech was curtailed and political activism attracted detention or worse.
nso: ka afrika borwa ya kgatelelo yeo steve biko a hlokofaletšego ka go yona, tokologo ya polelo e be e ileditšwe gomme bolwelatokologo bja dipolotiki bo be bo dira gore motho a golegwe goba a kwešwe bohloko le go feta fao.

eng: in south africa today, young people of the same age as steve biko was and even younger are at the forefront of activism for causes closest to them, and they are able to organise free of harassment or banishment.
nso: lehono ka mo afrika borwa baswa bao ba lego mengwageng yeo steve a bego a le go yona, le ba mengwaga ya ka tlase ga yeo, ba di goga pele tšweletšongpele ya merero yeo e lego kgauswi le pelo tša bona, gomme ba kgona go kopana ntle le go tlaišwa goba go iletšwa.

eng: freedom of speech and association, the right to protest and the right to equality before the law is upheld for all.
nso: tokologo ya polelo le ya gore motho a be karolo ya seo a se ratago, tokelo ya go gwanta mmogo le tokelo ya tekatekano pele ga molao di ama bohle.

eng: as a country, we have come a long way towards the fulfilment of human dignity, the principle that steve biko so cherished.
nso: bjalo ka naga, re tšwa kgole ge go etla phethagatšong ya seriti sa motho, e lego kokwane yeo steve biko a bego a e rata kudu.

eng: yet, we still have so much further to go.
nso: le ge go le bjalo, re sa na le leeto le letelele leo re tlo le tšeago.

eng: without a job, without a house, electricity or running water, without land, without skills or opportunities, millions of south africans are still deprived of the lives they seek and deserve.
nso: go hloka mošomo, go hloka ntlo, mohlagase, meetse a pompi, go hloka naga, go hloka mabokgoni goba menyetla, go dira gore dimilione tša maafrika borwa di palelwe ke go fihlelela maphelo ao ba a nyakago ebile a ba swanelago.

eng: that is why government is working with social partners to build an inclusive economy, create employment, enable businesses to thrive and tackle poverty and hunger.
nso: ke ka fao mmušo o šomago le bašomišanimmogo go tša leago go aga ikonomi yeo e akaretšago, go hlola mešomo, go kgontšha di kgwebo go gola, gape le go lwa le bodiidi le tlala.

eng: no quick fix for load shedding but real progress is being made vukuzenzele unnamed for every person living in this country, the past weeks of load shedding have been extremely frustrating and challenging.
nso: ga go na seo se ka dirwago ka lebelo go lokiša taba ya go kgaotšwa ga mohlagase eupša go na le tšwelopele ye kgolo vukuzenzele unnamed go motho yo mongwe le yo mongwe yo a dulago ka mo nageng, dibeke tša go feta tša go kgaotšwa ga mohla gase e bile tša ditšhitišo le ditlhohlo.

eng: the widespread public anger is wholly justified.
nso: go befelwa ga setšhaba ka kakaretšo go a kwešišega.

eng: with eskom forced to once more implement load shedding to protect the national grid, individuals, households and businesses have had to contend with power interruptions for up to four hours at a time.
nso: ge eskom e gapeletšega go kgaotša mohlagase go šireletša lenaneo la mohla gase la setšhaba, batho, malapa le dikgwebo ba swa nela ke go swara bothata bja go hloka mohlagase sebaka sa go fihla diiri tše nne ka nako ye tee.

eng: it has dire consequences for nearly every part of our society from education to public safety to the provision of health services.
nso: go na le ditlamorago tša go se kgahliše go karolo ye nngwe le ye nngwe ya setšhaba sa rena go tloga go thuto go ya go polokego ya setšhaba go ya go kabo ya ditirelo tša maphelo.

eng: large and small businesses alike are losing money and the energy crisis is endangering investment and our economic recovery.
nso: dikgwebo tše di kgolo le tše dinnyane ka moka di lahlegelwa ke tšhelete gomme mathata a mohlagase a tšhošetša peeletšo le tsošološo ya ekonomi.

eng: there is a sense of despair that the situation does not seem to be improving and that there appears to be no end in sight to this crisis.
nso: ga go na tshepo ya gore maemo a tla fetoga goba gona go kaonafala gomme ga go bontšhe mathata a a tla fela.

eng: yet, even in the darkness of load shedding there is and must be an end in sight to our electricity crisis.
nso: le ge go le bjalo, le nakong ya leswiswi la kgaotšo ya mohlagase go swanetše go ba le tharollo ya mathata a mohlagase.

eng: we are making progress in the implementation of the additional actions i announced in july, even though the effects may not be immediately felt.
nso: re na le tšwelopele mo phethagatšong ya magato a tlaleletšo ao ke a tsebišitšego ka mosegamanye, le ge dipoelo di ka se kwagale goba gona go bonala ka bjako.

eng: given the unpredictable performance of eskom’s fleet of coalfired power stations, we will not be able to eliminate load shedding in the short term.
nso: ge re lebeletše phethagatšo ya go se laolege ya diteišene tša mohlagase tša eskom, re ka se kgone go fediša kgaotšo ya mohlagase ka nako ye kopana.

eng: this is the unfortunate reality of our situation, which has had a long history.
nso: se ke nnete ya go se thabiše, yeo e bilego le histori ye telele.

eng: our goal in the immediate term however is to reduce the frequency and severity of load shedding by addressing power station breakdowns.
nso: nepo ya rena mo nakong ya gonabjale ke go fokotša ditiragalo le mathata a kgaotšo ya mohlagase ka go šogana le go senyega ga diteišene tša mohlagase.

eng: this is a significant challenge given the average age of power stations, and that in the past critical maintenance was not undertaken at the necessary intervals.
nso: ye ke tlhohlo ye kgolo go lebeletšwe palogare ya mengwaga ya ditiešene tša mohlagase, le gore nakong ya go feta tlhokomelo ye kgolo ga se ya dirwa mo dinakong tšeo seo se bego se hlokega.

eng: eskom is urgently implementing measures to improve plant performance, which is a priority until new generation power projects are brought online.
nso: eskom e phethagatša magato ka bjako go kaonafatša tshepetšo ya mafelo a go fehla mohlagase, seo se lego bohlokwa go fihla diprotšeke tša go fehla mohlagase wo mofsa di phethagatšwa.

eng: it is addressing the critical issue of coal supply, including working with transnet on the transportation of coal and monitoring the consistency of the supply from collieries to stations.
nso: e šogana le ditaba tše bohlokwa tša kabo ya malahla, go akaretša go šoma le transnet mo go sepetšeng malahla le go lekola gore malahla a sa le seemong sa wona sa go swana le ge a tloga meepong ya malahla go ya diteišeneng tša mohlagase.

eng: eskom is also addressing the poor quality of coal, which often leads to plant breakdowns.
nso: eskom e šogana gape le boleng bja go fokola bja malahla, moo gantši a dirago gore mafelo a go fehla mohlagase ka malahla a senyege.

eng: people with experience in running power stations are being brought back to help with plant operation, management and mentorship.
nso: batho ba go ba le maitemogelo a go sepetša diteišene tša mohla gase ba kgopetšwe go boa go thuša ka tshepetšo ya mafelo a go fehla mohlagase, taolo le tlhahlo.

eng: to ensure that critical maintenance is undertaken without delays, discussions are underway to ease local content requirements for spare parts and to use the equipment manufacturers to undertake maintenance.
nso: go kgonthiša gore go dirwa ditokišo tše dikgolo ntle le titelego, dipoledišano di tšwela pele go fokotša dinyakwa tša diteng tša gae go dikarolwana tša tlaleletšo le go šomiša badiri ba didirišwa go di hlokomela.

eng: to address the immediate energy shortfall, eskom has since july worked on procuring emergency power, and in the last week launched power purchase programmes for 1 000 megawatts of emergency capacity from companies with existing generation capacity and to secure imports from neighbouring countries.
nso: go šogana le hlaelelo ya mohlagase ka bjako, go tloga ka mosegamanye eskom e šomane le go hwetša mohla gase wa tšhoganetšo, gomme mo bekeng ya go feta e thakgotše mananeo a go reka mohlagase wa dimekawate (mw) tše 1 000 wa bokgoni bja tšhoganetšo go tšwa dikhamphaning tšeo di nago le mohlagase le go hwetša mohlagase wa ka ntle go dinaga tša baagišane.

eng: government is giving close attention to the skills, experience and capabilities of the eskom leadership to ensure that the company has the best people at all levels of the organisation.
nso: mmušo o lebeletše kudu mabokgoni, maitemogelo le bokgoni bja baetapele ba eskom go kgonthiša gore khamphani e na le batho ba bokgoni go feta ka moka magatong ka moka a mo kgatlo.

eng: these interventions will help to reduce the severity and frequency of load shedding as we are bringing new power onto the grid over the medium term to increase energy supply.
nso: ditsenogare tše di tla thuša go fokotša bošoro le kgaotšo ya mohlagase kgafetšakgafetša ka ge re tliša mohlagase wo mofsa mo lenaneong la mohlagase nakong ya magareng go oketša kabo ya mohlagase.

eng: recently, government signed power purchase agreements for 420 mw with the first three preferred bidders under bid window 5 of the renewable energy programme.
nso: gonabjale, mmušo e saenne ditumelelano tša go reka mohlagase wa 420 mw le baabi ba maleba ba bararo ka fase ga nako ya maiteko a bo 5 a lenaneo la mohlagase wa go mpshafatšwa.

eng: the three projects are expected to connect to the grid in october 2024, and preparations are underway to sign with the remaining 22 preferred bidders.
nso: go letetšwe gore diprotšeke tše tharo di tla kgokagana le lenaneo la mohlagase ka diphalane 2024, gomme dipeakanyo di thomile tša go saena le baabi ba maleba ba 22 bao ba šetšego.

eng: the amount of generation capacity to be procured from bid window 6 will increase 2 600 mw to 4 200 mw.
nso: bogolo bja tšweletšo ya mohlagase wo o rekwago go tšwa go nako ya maiteko a bo 6 e tla oketšega go tloga go 2 600 mw go fihla go 4 200 mw.

eng: the national electricity crisis committee i appointed in july is attending to the legislative and policy reforms that will establish a more efficient, competitive electricity sector.
nso: komiti ya mathata a mohlagase wa setšhaba yeo ke e thwetšego ka mose gamanye e lebeletše molao le dipholisi tšeo di tla thomago lekala la mohlagase wa go šoma gabotse gape wa go rekega.

eng: we have published for public comment the amendment that removes the licensing threshold for private generation projects.
nso: re phatlaladitše gore setšhaba se swayeswaye dimpshafatšo tšeo di tlošago legato la laesense go diprotšeke tša tšweletšo tša praebete.

eng: this will pave the way for investment in larger, utilityscale projects that will rapidly add new generation capacity to the grid.
nso: se se tla bula tsela ya peeletšo go diprotšeke tša sekala sa mohola tše dikgolo, tšeo di tla oketšago ka lebelo bokgoni bja tšweletšo ye mpsha go lenaneo la mohla gase.

eng: the need for environmental authorisations has been waived for transmission infrastructure in strategic corridors where risk to the environment is low.
nso: tlhokego ya ditumelelo tša tikologo e beetšwe thoko go infrastraktšha ya phatlalatšo mo go ditsela tša peakanyo moo kotsi ya tikologo e lego fase.

eng: the timeframes for energy projects receiving land use authorisations and grid connection approvals has been substantially reduced, as has the national energy regulator’s registration process for generation facilities.
nso: nako yeo e bego e šomišwa ya go kgopelela diprotšeke tša mohlagase ditumelelo tša go šomiša naga moo di ka agwago gona e fokotšegile kudu ka moka le ya ditumelelo tša go kgokaganya mohlagase wa diprojeke tša mohuta o mo lenaneong la mohlagase wa naga, ka moka le yona nako ya tshepetšo ya go ngwadiša go ba mohlagiši wa mohla gase mo lenaneong la setheo sa taolo ya mohlagase wa setšhaba.

eng: while we work to increase the supply of electricity, we must increase efforts to reduce demand, particularly at peak times.
nso: mola re šoma go godiša kabo ya mohlagase, re swanetše go godiša maitapišo a go fokotša nya kego, kudu ka dinako tšeo mohlagase o šomago kudu.

eng: we must come together as citizens to alleviate the pressure on the national grid.
nso: re swanetše go kopana bjalo ka badudi go fokotša kgatelelo ya lenaneo la mohlagase la setšhaba.

eng: this means using electricity sparingly, reporting illegal connections and paying for the electricity we use.
nso: se se ra gore go šomiša mohlagase ka tsheketšo, go swariša batho bao ba ikgogelago mohlagase le go lefela mohlagase woo re o šomišago.

eng: businesses, households and government departments that owe eskom must pay up so that eskom is better able to undertake the critical maintenance that is needed to keep the lights.
nso: dikgwebo, malapa le dikgoro tša mmušo tšeo di kolotago eskom di swanetše go lefa gore eskom e kgone go hlokomela mananeo a yona ao a nyakegago gore mabone a dule a tuka.

eng: as we continue to experience load shedding, there is a great tempation to give up hope that we will ever solve this problem.
nso: ge re tšwela pele go itemogela kgaotšo ya mohla gase, go na le kganyogo ya go lahlegelwa ke tshepo ya gore re tla tsoga re rarollotše bothata bjo.

eng: stem cell donation is a painless way to help save lives kgaogelo letsebe mfundo mxolisi ngwenya (30) from durban, kwazulunatal, is one of the few black stem cell donors in the country.
nso: kabo ya disele tša steme ke mokgwa wa go se be bohloko wa go thuša go boloka maphelo kgaogelo letsebe mfundo mxolisi ngwenya (30) go tšwa durban, kwazulunatal ke yo mongwe wa bathobaso ba mmalwa bao ba abago disele tša steme ka nageng.

eng: the south african bone marrow registry (sabmr) says more people of colour need to register as donors because a patient has the best chance of finding a match in their ethnic grouping.
nso: south african bone marrow registry (sanmr) e bolela gore batho ba bantši bammala ba hloka go ngwadiša bjalo ka baabi ka gore molwetši o na le sebaka se sebotse sa go hwetša disele tša go lebana mo morafeng wa bona.

eng: according to the registry, only 10% of the 78 000 registered donors are black, while 9.9% are indian/asian and 67% are white.
nso: go ya ka ofisi ya ngwadišo, go 78 000 ya batho bao ba ngwadišitšwego, ke fela 10% ya bathobaso, mola 9.9% e le maindia gomme 67% ke bathobašweu.

eng: the sabmr says most donors donate through a process called peripheral blood stem cell collection.
nso: sabmr e bolela gore baabi ba bantši ba aba ka tshepetšo ye e bitšwago disele tša steme tša madi tša ka ntle.

eng: it says the same stem cells found in your bone marrow are also found in your circulating blood.
nso: e bolela gore disele tša steme tšeo di hwetšwago mo ditlhaleng tša marapo le tšona di hwetšwa mading a gago ao a elago.

eng: a nonsurgical, outpatient procedure is done to collect these cells.
nso: tshepedišo yeo e dirwago o se wa robatšwa bookelong, gape o sa dirwe karo e a dirwa go hwetša disele tše.

eng: blood is removed through a needle in one arm, passed through a machine that collects stem cells and returned through a needle in your other arm.
nso: madi a tšewa ka nalete mo letsogong le tee, a fetišwa motšheneng woo o kgoboketšago disele tša steme gomme a bušwa ka nalete ka letsogong la gago le lengwe.

eng: stem cells are important to cure blood diseases such as leukaemia, marrow failure or aplasia.
nso: disele tša steme di bohlokwa go fodiša malwetši a madi a go swana le kankere ya madi, go palelwa ga marapo le go palelwa ke go šoma ga ditho tša mmele.

eng: ngwenya, a sports manager at the durban university of technology, says he first learnt about stem cell donation in 2012 when the sabmr held a roadshow at a local complex.
nso: ngwenya, molaodi wa dipapadi mo yunibesithing ya theknolotši ya durban, o bolela gore o thomile go ithuta ka kabo ya disele tša steme ka 2012 ge sabmr e na le lesolo la temošo mo mabenkeleng a gae.

eng: "i have always donated blood and am always eager to help, so i went for it.
nso: "nako le nako ke be ke aba madi gomme nako le nako ke ikemišeditše go thuša, ka gona ke ile ka ya go aba.

eng: it was really easy because they just took a swab in the mouth and said i should expect a call."
nso: go be go le bonolo kudu ka gore ba no tšea sešupo ka ganong gomme ba re ke emele mogala.

eng: the sample taken from a potential donor’s mouth is tested and their details are stored so that they can be contacted if they become a match for someone in need of stem cells.
nso: "go dirwa diteko ka sešupo seo se tšerwego molo mong wa baabi gomme tshedimošo ya bona ya bolokwa gore ge go ka ba le molwetši yo a nago le tshedimošo ya diteko ya go swana le ya bona yo a hlokago disele tša steme go kgokaganwe le bona.

eng: "last year, i received a call that they had found a perfect match.
nso: "ngwaga wa go feta, ke amogetše mogala wa go ntsebiša gore ba hweditše motho yo disele tša ka di sepelelanago le tša gagwe.

eng: the process to donate is quite lengthy and involves about 13 different tests, ranging from a physical [to check overall health] to blood tests.
nso: tshepetšo ya go aba ke ye telele gomme e na le diteko tše 13, go tloga go diteko tša go lekola mmele [go lekola ge motho a se na malwetši] go feletša ka tša go dira diteko tša madi.

eng: i also had to inject myself on a daily basis," he says.
nso: ke be ke swanela ke go ihlaba ka nalete ya gona letšatši le lengwe le le lengwe," a realo.

eng: victim empowerment programme restores hope owen mngadi the thohoyandou victim empowerment programme (tvep) strives to restore hope and confidence in the justice system through its intensive initiatives aimed at assisting survivors of genderbased violence (gbv) and rape by providing them with psychosocial services.
nso: lenaneo la matlafatšo le buša kholofelo owen mngadi lenaneo la matlafatšo ya batšwasehlabelo la thohoyandou (tvep) le lwela go bušetša kholofelo le boitshepo ka gare ga lenaneo la toka ka mananeo a lona a go tsenelela ao maikemišetšo a ona e lego go thuša baphologi ba dikgaruru tša go thewa godimo ga bong (gbv) le ba go katwa ka go ba fa ditirelo tša monagano le tša leago.

eng: founded in limpopo over 20 years ago, the tvep operates in tshilidzini and donald fraser hospitals under the thulamela local municipality.
nso: tvep e thomile ka limpopo mengwaga ya ka godimo ga ye 20, gomme e šomela ka dipetlele tša donald fraser le tshilidzini ka fase ga mmasepala wa selegae wa thulamela.

eng: its acting director fhatuwani manthada says the programme aims to instil a zerotolerance attitude towards sexual assault, gbv and child abuse among thohoyandou residents, given the fact that these cases are prevalent in the area.
nso: molaodimogolo wa tvep wa motšwaoswere, fhatuwani manthada, o re maikemišetšo a yona ke go hlohleletša maikutlo a go se amogele tlaišo ya thobalano, ya gbv le tlaišo ya bana magareng a badudi ba thohoyandou, ka lebaka la gore ditiragalo tše ke tše ntši kudu ka tikologong ye.

eng: he says in the past, crime statistics indicated that there were many rape cases in thohoyandou, but the tvep has made great strides in raising awareness and providing trauma counselling services to curb the scourge.
nso: o re mo nakong ye e fetilego, dipalopalo tša bosenyi di be di tle di laetše gore go na le melato ye mentši ya go katwa ka thohoyandou, eupša tvep e tšeere magato a mantši mo go oketšeng temošo le go fa ditirelo tša thobamatswalo ya letšhogo go thibela thogako ye.

eng: as the world will be observing the 16 days of activism for no violence against women and children from 25 november to 10 december, manthada says the programme is satisfied with the progress made with encouraging residents to understand their rights and report crimes.
nso: ka ge lefase le tla be le keteka lesolo la ntwa ya matšatši a 16 a tlhokego ya dintwa kgahlanong le basadi le bana go tloga ka 25 dibatsela go fihla go 10 manthole, mathanda o re lenaneo le kgotsofaditše kgatelopele ye e dirilwego ka go hlohleletša badudi go kwešiša ditokelo tša bona le go bega bosenyi.

eng: "the tvep receives between 80 and 100 victims of domestic violence every month, while 45 to 50 rape cases are reported monthly," says manthada.
nso: "tvep e amogela batšwasehlabelo ba dikgaruru tša ka malapeng ba palo ya gare ga 80 le 100 kgwedi ye nngwe le ye nngwe, mola melato ya go katwa ye 45 go fihla go 50 e begwa kgwedi ye nngwe le ye nngwe," go bolela manthada.

eng: the programme’s onestop centres offer a wide range of services to victims, including access to legal assistance, protection of victims against perpetrators, court case monitoring, counselling and empowerment through skills development, thus giving the victims a fresh start.
nso: disenthara tša ditirelo ka moka tša lenaneo di fa batšwasehlabelo ditirelo tša go fapanafapana, go akaretšwa go fihlelela thušo ya semolao, tšhireletšo ya batšwasehlabelo kgahlanong le batshwenyi, tlhokomelo ya melato ya kgorotsheko, thobamatswalo le matlafatšo ka tlhabollo ya bokgoni, bjalo se se fa batšwasehlabelo sebaka sa go thoma ka boswa.

eng: manthada states that the tvep works closely with the south african police service, department of health and department of social development to prevent secondary traumatisation of victims in the process of opening a case.
nso: manthada o bolela gore tvep e šomišana kudu le tirelo ya afrika borwa ya sephodisa, kgoro ya maphelo le kgoro ya tlhabollo ya leago go thibela letšhogo la morago ga tlaišo la batšwasehlabelo ba ba swaraganego le go bula molato.

eng: "in rape cases, healthcare workers and the police come to the tvep centres to assist victims to open criminal cases against the perpetrators and also provide counselling services," he says.
nso: "mo melatong ya go katwa, bašomi ba tlhokomelo ya maphelo le maphodisa ba tla disenthareng tša tvep go thuša batšwasehlabelo gore ba bule melato ya bosenyi kgahlanong le batshwenyi gomme gape, go fa ditirelo tša thobamatswalo," a realo.

eng: the tvep accommodates victims for up to 14 days, however, the arrangement could be extended in cases that involve the whole family or children.
nso: tvep e amogela batšwasehlabelo ba go fihla go matšatši a 14, efela, peakanyo e ka katološwa mo go melato yeo e akaretšago bana le lapa ka moka.

eng: "we have empowerment unity that conducts public dialogues and educates people about their rights.
nso: "re na le masolo a go hlahlelela badudi ka tsebo ao ka ona re boledišanago le setšhaba le go ruta batho ka ditokelo tša bona.

eng: we serve more than one million residents from thohoyandou and surrounding areas.
nso: re thuša badudi ba go feta milione ba thohoyandou le ba metse ye mengwe ya kgauswi.

eng: we have managed to restore hope and people now have trust in the criminal justice [system] through our relationship with the police," he says.
nso: re kgonne go bušetša kholofelo gomme bjale batho ba na le tshepo mo go lenaneo la toka ka lebaka la ka fao re amanago ka gona le maphodisa," a realo.

eng: the tvep has also created employment for 44 people who serve in various departments such as finance, human resources and evaluation.
nso: tvep gape e hlotše mešomo ya batho ba 44 setheong sa yona bao ba šomelago dikgo ro tša yona tša go fapana go swana le ya ditšhelete, ya merero ya bašomi le ya tekolo.

eng: despite receiving continuous funding of r90 000 quarterly from the limpopo department of social development, the tvep was affected by covid19 as many funders pulled out, thus negatively affecting the organisation’s operational processes.
nso: ka ntle le go amogela thekgo ya ditšhelete ye e tšwelago pele ya r90 000 ka kotara go tšwa go kgoro ya tlhabollo ya leago ya limpopo, tvep e amilwe ke covid19 ka ge bathekgi ka ditšhelete ba bantši ba ikgogetše morago, bjalo se se amile gampe ditshepedišo tša mošomo tša mokgatlo.

eng: however, the genderbased violence and femicide (gbvf) response fund, which was launched by president cyril ramaphosa, together with the international women’s forum of south africa and social partners have assisted the programme.
nso: bjalo, sekhwama sa karabo sa dikgaruru tša go thewa godimo ga bong le polao ya basadi, seo se thakgotšwego ke mopresidente cyril ramaphosa, gotee le foramo ya boditšhabatšhaba ya basadi ya afrika borwa le balekani ba leago ka dibokwane ngwaga wo, se thušitše lenaneo le.

eng: the tvep was among the first batch of the organisations, that fight against gbvf, to receive funding.
nso: tvep e magareng a sehlopha sa mathomo sa mekgatlo yeo e lwantšhago gbvf, go amogela thekgo ya ditšhelete.

eng: with the sum of r128 million that was raised through contributions by the private sector, multisectoral fund, the gbvf fund will assist and support the implementation of the national strategic plan on gbvf.
nso: ka palomoka ya r128 milione yeo e kgobokeditšwego ka dithušo tša lekala la poraebete, sekhwama sa makala a mantši, sekhwama sa gbvf se tla thuša le go thekga phethagatšo ya leanotiro la bosetšhaba la gbvf.

eng: the tvep has been allocated r250 000 for the current year and will receive more funding for 2023. manthada says the funds have enabled the tvep to reach out to more victims and keep the organisation running.
nso: tvep e abetšwe r250 000 ngwaga wo gomme e tla amogela thekgo ye nngwe ya ditšhelete ya 2023. manthada o re ditšhelete tša thekgo di kgontšhitše tvep go fihlelela batšwasehlabelo ba bantši le go dira gore mo kgatlo o tšwelepele go šoma.

eng: murendeni vhengani (26) is a survivor who was rescued by the tvep from her abusive exboyfriend.
nso: murendeni vhengani (26) ke mophologi yoo a phološitšwego ke tvep lesoganeng leo a bego a ratana le lona leo le bego le mo tshwenya.

eng: she spent 46 months months at the centre, with her fouryearold daughter.
nso: yena le ngwana wa gagwe wa mengwaga ye mene ba dutše sebaka sa dikgwedi tše 46 mo senthareng ya tvep .

eng: the centre assisted her to open charges against him and to file a protection order.
nso: senthara ye e mo thušitše go bula melato kgahlanong le lesogana le gape le go le bulela taelo ya tšhireletšo.

eng: "they welcomed me with warm hands after many years of suffering.
nso: "ba nkamogetše ka diatla tše borutho ka morago ga mengwaga ye mentši ya go tshwenywa.

eng: i felt safe.
nso: ke kwele ke bolokegile.

eng: i have regained my confidence," she says.
nso: ke hweditše boi tshepho bja ka gape," o boletše bjalo.

eng: the gbvf fund chairperson, dr judy dlamini, says funding for 108 organisations whose applications have been successful are being processed.
nso: modulasetulo wa sekhwama sa gbvf, ngaka judy dlamini, o rile thekgo ya ditšhelete ya mekgatlo ye 108 yeo dikgopelo tša tšona di atlegilego di a šongwa.

eng: information regarding the next round of applications will soon be available on the gbvf fund website: https://gbvf.
nso: tshedimošo mabapi le sebaka se se latelago sa dikgopelo e tla bulelwa mo nakong ya go se fetše pelo mo go weposaete ya sekhwama sa gbvf: https://gbvf.

eng: nsfas 2023 applications open vukuzenzele unnamed the national stu dent financial aid scheme (nsfas) 2023 application cycle has opened.
nso: dikgopelo tša nsfas tša 2023 di buletšwe vukuzenzele unnamed saekele ya dikgopelo ya 2023 ya sekema sa bosetšhaba sa thušo ya ditšhelete (nsfas) e buletšwe.

eng: higher education, science and innovation minister dr blade nzimande made the announcement recently during a media briefing.
nso: tona ya kgoro ya thuto ya godingwana, saense le boithomelo, ngaka blade nzimande, o tsebišitše malobanyana ka nako ya kopano ya bobegaditaba.

eng: minister nzimande says the scheme resolved to open the application cycle early, as opposed to the previous year, in order to give prospective applicants enough time to submit their applications and supporting documents.
nso: tona nzimande o re sekema se tšeere sephetho sa go bulela nako ya dikgopelo ka pela, ge go bapetšwa le ngwagola, go fa bakgopedi ba ka moso nako ye e lekanego ya go romela dikgo pelo tša bona le ditokomane tša thekgo.

eng: giving an update report on nsfas funding for the 2022 academic year, minister nzimande says a budget of r43 billion was allocated to the scheme towards the beneficiaries’ tuition fees, including food and travelling allowance, and study material.
nso: ge a e fa pego ya bjalebjale mabapi le thekgo ya ditšhelete ya ngwaga wa ditšhelete wa 2022 wa nsfas, tona nzimande o re tekanetšo ya r43 milione e abetšwe sekema go lefa ditefišo tša baholegi ba thuto, go akaretšwa dijo le putseletšo ya senamelwa, le dimatheriale tša thuto.

eng: he says 985 672 applications were received with 140 636 application unsuccessful.
nso: o re dikgopelo tše 985 672 di amogetšwe gomme go tšwa go tšona tše 140 636 ga se tša atlega.

eng: of the applications received, 739 526 applications were provisionally approved for funding pending registration from respective institutions.
nso: go dikgopelo tše di amogetšwego, tše 739 526 di amogetšwe nakwana go thekga ka ditšhelete boingwadišo bjo bo sa letetšwego gore bo feleletšwe go tšwa diinstitšhušeneng tša go fapana.

eng: "[the] majority of unsuccessful applicants failed to provide sufficient evidence to support their applications for funding; exceeded the financial eligibility threshold; already achieved the highest level of qualification that nsfas funds and being noncompliant to the academic pathways of the tvet college sector," minister nzimande explains.
nso: "bontši bja bakgopedi ba ba sego ba atlega ba šitilwe go fa bohlatse bjo bo lekanego bja thekgo ya ditšhelete; ba bangwe ba feta magomo a maswanedi; ge ba bangwe bona ba šetše ba fihleletše maemo a godimodimo a lengwalo la thuto ao nsfas e a thekgago ka ditšhelete gomme maemo a bona ga a sa ba kgontšha go latela dinyakwa tša go ka tsenela thuto ya lekala la kholetše ya tvet," tona nzimande o a hlalosa.

eng: according to information on the nsfas website, as of the 2021 academic year, nsfas no longer provides funding for postgraduate courses.
nso: go ya ka tshedimošo ye e lego weposaeteng ya nsfas, go tloga ka ngwaga wa thuto wa 2021, nsfas ga e sa thekga dithuto tša thuto ya morago ga tikrii ya mathomo ka ditšhelete.

eng: this includes postgraduate certificates, postgraduate diplomas, honours degrees, masters and phd degrees.
nso: se se akaretša ditifikeiti tša thuto ya morago ga tikrii ya mathomo, didiploma tša thuto ya morago ga tikrii ya mathomo, ditikrii tša honase, ditikrii tša mastase le phd.

eng: this means the highest qualification that the scheme funds is a bachelor’s degree.
nso: se se ra gore lengwalo la thuto la godimodimo leo sekema se le thekgago ka ditšhelete ke tikrii ya mathomo.

eng: improving the application systemin a bid to improve its appli cation system and process to simplify it for prospective applicants, minister nzimande says this year, nsfas has implemented a number of enhancements to the system to ensure a seamless application experience.
nso: go kaonafatša mokgwa wa dikgopeloka maiteko a go kaonafatša mokgwa wa yona wa go dira dikgopelo le tshepedišo ya tšona go dira gore e be wo mokaonekaone go šomišwa ke bakgopedi bao ba nyakago go dira dikgopelo, tona nzimande o re ngwaga wo, nsfas e dirile diphetogo tše mmalwa tša go kaonafatša mokgwa wo go kgonthišiša gore badiradikgopelo ba se itemogele mathata.

eng: he says the nsfas online application portal was redesigned to be more user friendly and closer to other platforms that prospective applicants are accustomed to such as whatsapp, twitter, facebook and instagram.
nso: o re weposaete ya go dira dikgopelo ka inthanete ya nsfas e bopilwe leswa gore e šomišege botse go feta peleng le go dira gore e nyake go swana le dipolatefomo tše dingwe tšeo bakgopedi bao ba nyakago go dira dikgopelo ba di tlwaetšego go swana le whatsapp, twitter, facebook le instagram.

eng: "the application process itself has been simplified and the questions asked are easier to understand by the public.
nso: "tshepedišo ya dikgopelo ka boyona e nolofaditšwe gomme dipotšišo tše di botšišitšwego di bonolonyana gore di kwešišwe ke setšhaba.

eng: additionally, applicants can pause the process and continue at a later stage without restarting from scratch, something that was not possible in previous cycles, he says.
nso: go tlaleletša, bakgo pedi ba ka kgaotša tshepedišo ya dikgopelo gomme ba tšwela pele ka morago ga sebaka ka ntle le go thoma ka leswa, selo seo se bego se sa kgonege mo dinakong tša go feta, o realo.

eng: "over and above the enhancements, nsfas developed additional channels of application to cater for applicants from diverse backgrounds, also keeping in mind that most of the prospective applicants are young people who embrace the digital way of doing things," minister nzimande adds.
nso: "ka godimo ga dikaonafatšo tše di dirilwego, nsfas e okeditše mekgwa ya theknolotši ya go dira dikgopelo go dira gore badiradikgopelo ka go fapana ga bona ba kgone go dira dikgopelo, gape re be re lebeletše gore bontši bja batho bao ba tlago dira dikgopelo ke baswa bao ba ratago go dira dilo ka theknolotši," tona nzimande a tlaleletša.

eng: a million work and livelihood opportunities, and counting vukuzenzele unnamed less than two years ago, we launched the presidential employment stimulus to create jobs and support livelihoods as part of supporting the economic recovery from the covid19 pandemic.
nso: mešomo le menyetla ya mekgwa ya boiphedi milione, gomme palo ye e sa tšwela pele go gola vukuzenzele unnamed ka fase ga mengwaga ye mebedi ya go feta, re thakgotše lenaneo la tlhohleletšo ya mešomo ya mopresidente go hlola mešomo le go thekga mekgwa ya boiphedišo bjalo ka karolo ya go thekga tsošološo ya ikonomi go tšwa go leuba la covid19.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus has just reached the milestone of one million participants since its inception.
nso: lenaneo la tlhohleletšo ya mešomo ya mopresidente le sa tšwa go atlega go fihlelela bakgathatema ba milione o tee go tloga mola le hlomilwego.

eng: this achievement is the result of a collaborative effort across government and the wider society, including the private sector, communitybased organisations and many others.
nso: phihlelelo ye ke ka lebaka la maiteko a tšhomišano mmušong ka moka le setšhabeng ka bophara, go akaretšwa lekala la poraebete, mekgatlo ye e theilwego gare ga setšhaba le ye mengwe ye mentši.

eng: the programme is contributing to employment creation while the economy takes time to recover and create jobs at the scale we need.
nso: lenaneo le na le seabe mo go tlholo ya mešomo mola ikonomi e tšea nako go kaonafala le go hlola mešomo ka palo ye re e nyakago.

eng: as we pursue economic growth to deliver decent and sustainable employment at a much larger scale, we will continue to build on the success of the presidential employment stimulus and expand its reach.
nso: ge re šogana le kgolo ya ikonomi go hlola mešomo ya seriti le ya go swarelela nako ye telele ka palo ye kgolwane, re tla tšwela pele go kaonafatša katlego, lenaneo la tlhohleletšo ya mešomo ya mopresidente le go dira gore e oketšega go feta pele.

eng: it is still very much needed to complement recovery of the job market.
nso: go sa nyakega kudu gore go tlaleletšwe tsošološo ya mmaraka wa mešomo.

eng: it also supports economic recovery in important ways.
nso: gape e thekga tsošološo ya ikonomi ka ditsela tše bohlokwa.

eng: in a context where a lack of work experience is a major barrier to finding work, these programmes are providing highquality work experiences.
nso: go maemo ao e lego gore tlhokego ya bokgoni ke lepheko le legolo mo go khwetšo ya mošomo, mananeo a a fa maitemogelo a mošomo a boleng bja godimo.

eng: in the largest programme supported by the stimulus, for example, nearly 600 000 young people have been placed as school assistants in over 22 000 schools in every corner of the country.
nso: ka gare ga lenaneo le legologolo la go thekgwa ke tlhohleletšo, mohlala, baswa ba go batamela go ba 600 000 ba thwetšwe bjalo ka bathušibadikolo ka dikolong tša ka godimo ga tše 22 000 khutlong ye nngwe le ye nngwe ya naga.

eng: school management, teachers and other stakeholders all agree that the contribution of the school assistants has improved the learning environment in schools.
nso: bolaodi bja sekolo, barutiši le bakgathatema ba bangwe ka moka ba dumela gore seabe sa bathušibadikolo se kaonafaditše tikologo ya go ithuta ka dikolong.

eng: many selfemployed people found their livelihoods disrupted by the pandemic.
nso: batho ba bantši ba ba itšhomelago ba hweditše mekgwa ya bona ya boiphedišo e tsenwe bogare ke leuba.

eng: the creative sector was particularly badly affected.
nso: lekala la bokgabo lona le amilwe gampe gagolo.

eng: in this sector, support was provided to people to create jobs for themselves and others.
nso: ka gare ga lekala le, thekgo e filwe batho gore ba ihlolele mešomo gomme ba hlolele le ba bangwe.

eng: the movies, music and plays produced are now able to generate further income from the sale of rights, tickets and royalties.
nso: difilimi, mmino le dipapadi tše di tšweleditšwego bjale di kgona go dira letseno le lengwe go tšwa go thekišo ya ditokelo, ditekete le diroyalethi.

eng: all of this has been contributing to the growth of the sector.
nso: tše ka moka di bile le seabe kgolong ya lekala.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus has also supported sustainable livelihoods.
nso: lenaneo la tlhohleletšo ya mešomo ya mopresidente gape le thekgile mekgwa ya boiphedišo ya nako ye telele.

eng: over 140 000 subsistence farmers have received production input vouchers to assist them to resume and expand production after the disruptions of covid19.
nso: balemelaboiphedišo ba ka godimo ga 140 000 ba amogetše dibaotšha tša thušo ya tšweletšo go ba thuša go thoma le go oketša tšweletšo ka morago ga go tsenwa bogare ke covid19.

eng: one such beneficiary is 36yearold phindile ngcoya from richmond in kwazulunatal.
nso: moholegi wo mongwe wo bjalo ke phindile ngcoya wa mengwaga ye 36 go tšwa richmond go la kwazulunatal.

eng: she is one of ten members of a family farming cooperative and says the voucher she received helped the new cooperative survive and become profitable.
nso: ke o tee wa maloko a lesome a kgwebo ya temo ya lapa gomme o re baotšha ye a e amogetšego e thušitše kgwebo ye mpsha go tšwelapele le go dira poelo.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus is also supporting graduates, with opportunities provided to nurses, science graduates, artisans and others.
nso: lenaneo la tlhohleletšo ya mešomo ya mopresidente gape le thekga dialoga, ka menyetla ya go fiwa baoki, dialoga tša saense, batsebi ba mešomo ya diatla le ba bangwe.

eng: twenty six universities are helping to place unemployed graduates in work relevant to their qualifications.
nso: diyunibesithi tše masomepeditshela di thuša go thwala dialoga tše di se nago mešomo mo mešomong ye e sepelelanago le mangwalo a bona a thuto.

eng: the department of science and innovation has introduced a range of innovative citizen science programmes, such as the duzi umngeni conservation trust, which employs local youth as envirochamps to empower communities to rehabilitate local water sources.
nso: kgoro ya saense le boithomelo e tsebišitše mananeo a saense a badudi a boithomelo a go fapana, go swana le duzi umngeni conservation trust, ye e thwalago baswa ba tikologo bjalo ka dithwadi tša tikologo (envirochamps) go matlafatša ditšhaba gore di tsošološe methopo ya tikologo ya meetse.

eng: another programme by the department helps entrepreneurs to develop business proposals in the green economy.
nso: lenaneo le lengwe ka kgoro le thuša borakgwebo go hlabolla ditšhišinyo tša kgwebo ka go ikonomi ya pabalelatikologo.

eng: public employment programmes also have a direct positive impact on communities because they create work for the common good.
nso: mananeo a mešomo ya setšhaba gape a na le khuetšo ye botse ye e lebanego mo go ditšhaba gobane a hlola mošomo go dira setho.

eng: in the case of the presidential employment stimulus, this includes improving learning in schools, upgrading informal settlements, supporting survivors of genderbased violence, environmental conservation and innovating in wasterecycling.
nso: ge go bolelwa ka lenaneo la tlhohleletšo ya mešomo la mopresidente, se se akaretša go kaonafatša go ithuta ka dikolong, go kaonafatša metsemekutwana, go thekga baphologi ba dikgaruru tša go thewa godimo ga bong, pabalelo ya tikologo le go tšweletša mekgwa ye meswa ya go resaekela matlakala.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus was launched in response to the unemployment crisis that was deepened by the covid19 pandemic.
nso: lenaneo la tlhohleletšo ya mešomo la mopresidente le thakgotšwe go rarolla bothata bja tlhokego ya mešomo bjo bo gakaditšwego ke leuba la covid19.

eng: although the pandemic may have abated, unemployment has not.
nso: le ge e le gore leuba le ka ba le fedile, tlhoke go ya mešomo ga se e fele.

eng: the incomes earned in presidential employment stimulus programmes have been an economic boost to small enterprises and informal businesses in local economies across the country.
nso: letseno le le amogetšwego mananeong a lenaneo la tlhohleletšo ya mešomo la mopresidente le bile matlafatšo ya ikonomi go di kgwebo tše nnyane le dikgwe bo tše e sego tša semmušo ka diikonoming tša tikologo go kgabaganya naga.

eng: school assistants employed in umgungundlovu are spending their wages in umgungundlovu.
nso: bathušibadikolo ba ba thwetšwego ka umgungundlovu ba šomiša meputso ya bona ka umgu ngundlovu.

eng: the same in putsonderwater.
nso: go bjalo le ka putsonderwater.

eng: instead of the ‘trickle down’ effect, money is being put directly into the hands of communities that need it most.
nso: sebakeng sa go ba le lenaneo la gore ‘batho bao ba hlokago ba tla holega ge bao ba humilego ba huma le go feta’, tšhelete e tsenywa thwii ka gare ga diatla tša ditšhaba tšeo di e hlokago kudu.

eng: that money then circulates locally and ‘trickles up’ into the wider economy.
nso: tšhelete yeo morago e dikologa mo tulong ya bona gomme morago e ‘boele e tsene go ikonomi ka bophara’.

eng: that is why we call it a stimulus, because the entire economy benefits along with society.
nso: ke ka lebaka leo re bitšago lenaneo le gore ke la tlhohleletšo, gobane ikonomi ka moka e a holega gotee le setšhaba.

eng: through the presidential employment stimulus, we have unlocked energy, commitment, creativity, innovation and opportunities.
nso: ka lenaneo la tlhohleletšo ya mešomo la mopresidente, re buletše enetši, boikgafo, bohlami, boithomelo le menyetla.

eng: in the process, we are building a society that works.
nso: mo tshepedišong, re aga setšhaba seo se šomago.

eng: over one million people have benefited directly.
nso: batho ba go feta milione o tee ba holegile thwii.

eng: many more people, in the families and communities of participants, have felt the impact of the stimulus.
nso: batho ba bangwe ba bantši, ka malapeng le ka ditšhabeng tša bakgathatema, ba kwele khuetšo ya tlhohleletšo.

eng: our task now is to expand and deepen the impact of this work.
nso: mošomo wa rena bjale ke go oketša le go tseneletša khuetšo ya mošomo wo.

eng: as a result of the presidential employment stimulus, we now have hundreds of thousands of people with valuable work experience.
nso: ke lebaka la lenaneo la tlhohleletšo ya mešomo la mopresidente, bjale re na le makgolokgolo a diketekete tša batho ba go ba le boitemogelo bja mošomo bja mohola.

eng: most of these people are easy to find through the sayouth.
nso: bontši bja batho ba go bonolo go ba hwetša ka sayouth.

eng: early childhood development holds the key to our future vukuzenzele unnamed there are few pre sidential activities more fulfilling than spending a morning in the company of small children.
nso: bokamoso bja rena bo laolwa ke go hlalefišwa ga bopapimpana vukuzenzele unnamed go nale ditiragalo tše mmalwa tša kantoro ya mopresidente tša go uša pelo go feta go iketla le bana mesong.

eng: i recently attended the opening of the little flower early childhood development (ecd) centre in bizana in the eastern cape, where i got to spend time with some of the future leaders of our country, reading to them and listening to them.
nso: malobanyana mo ke tšwa pulong ya senthara ya tlhalefišo ya bomapimpana ya little flower (ecd) gola bizana kua kapa bohlabela fao ke ilego ka iketla le ba bangwe ba baetapele ba kamoso ba naga ya gaborena, ke ba balela le go ba theeletša.

eng: the centre was recently built by the development organisation impande south africa through the support of the nelson mandela foundation.
nso: senthara ye e satšo agwa ke mokgatlo wa tlhabollo wa impande wa ka mo afrika borwa ka thekgo ya setheo sa nelson mandela.

eng: i was deeply touched by the dedication of the centre’s staff to supporting the community and its children.
nso: ke kgwathile maikutlo ke boikgafo bja bašomedi ba senthara ye ge ba thekga setšhaba le bana ba go tsena go yona.

eng: they told me how in the centre’s earliest days, staff struggled to get paid and yet still came to work.
nso: ba mpoditše tša mehleng ya ge senthara ye e thomišwa, ka fao bašomedi ba bego ba sokolela go hwetša meputso ya bona eupša ba tšwelapele go tla mošomong.

eng: they also told me that even if families are not able to pay the r20 fee for their child, the children are not turned away.
nso: ba mpoditše gape le gore le ge e le gore batswadi ba be ba sa kgone go lefela bana ba bona tefo ya r20, bana ba be ba sa gomišetšwe morago.

eng: the commitment of the ecd centre staff is so important because early childhood development centres play a pivotal role in our nation’s development.
nso: boikgafo bja bašomedi ba senthara ye ya ecd bo bohlokwa kudu ka gobane disenthara tša tlhalefišo ya bomapimpana di kgatha tema ye bohlokwa kudu tlhabollong ya setšhaba sa gaborena.

eng: these centres can be found in every village, town and city in the country.
nso: tšona disenthara tše di hwetšagala motsaneng wo mongwe le wo mongwe, toropong efe goba efe le ditoropong ka moka tše kgolo ka mo nageng.

eng: most were started by women in the community to support parents who need their children to be cared for when they are at work.
nso: bontši bja tšona di thomilwe ke basadi mo setšhabeng bao ba bego ba sala ba hlokomela bana ge batswadi ba bona ba ile mešomong.

eng: many of these centres began as creches and daycare facilities.
nso: bontši bja tšona disenthara tše di thomile e le dikretšhe goba dise nthara tša go hlokomela bana mosegare.

eng: many have subsequently grown and expanded to incorporate a basic learning curriculum into their services.
nso: tše ntši tša tšona di godile mme gabjale di akaretša lenaneothuto la motheo la dithuto tša mehleng ka gare ga ditirelo tša tšona.

eng: as government, we have taken up the task to improve the standards of care and make resources available for ecd centres to run suitable activities for young children to prepare them for formal education.
nso: bjalo ka mmušo, re tšeere mošomo wa go kaonafatša maemo a tlhokomelo le go dira gore didirišwa di be gona gore disenthara tša ecd di kgone go sepediša ditiragalo tše maleba tša bana go ba lokišetša dithuto tše dumeletšwego ke mmušo.

eng: in april 2022, we completed the move of the ecd function from the department of social development to the department of basic education.
nso: ka moranang 2022, re kgonne go šutiša ka botlalo tirelo ya ecd go tšwa go kgoro ya tlhabollo ya leago go ya go kgoro ya thuto ya motheo.

eng: this is to link early childhood development to the formal school curriculum and to provide training, education and development to staff in ecd centres around the country.
nso: tšhutišo ye e diretšwe go amanya tlhalefišo ya bomapimpana le lenaneothuto la dithuto tše dumeletšwego dikolong kamoka le go aba tlhahlo, thuto le tlhabollo go bašomedi disenthareng tša ecd go potologa naga.

eng: because this foundational learning is key to a child’s success in later years, the basic education laws amendment bill that is currently before parliament proposes that it be compulsory for all children to receive two years of ecd before they enter grade 1. it is at this stage that children should be taught, learn through play and receive at least one meal a day.
nso: ka baka la gore dithuto tše tša motheo tša bomapimpana di le bohlokwa katlegong ya ngwana morago ga mengwaga ngwaga, molaophetošwa wa melao ya thuto ya motheo wo gabjale o lego pele ga palamente o šišinya gore e be kgapeletšo go bana ka moka gore ba tsene disenthareng tša ecd tekano ya mengwaga ye mebedi pele ba thoma kreiti 1 goba wona mphato wa pele.

eng: early childhood development centres don’t just prepare our country’s youngest citizens to succeed in school; they are also an important source of entrepreneurship and job creation.
nso: mohola wa disenthara tša go hlalefiša bomapimpa na ga se fela go thuša go lokišetša bana ba naga ya gaborena go atlega dikolong; gape di bohlokwa mo go ithomeleng kgwebo le mo go tlhomeng mešomo.

eng: these centres are an important part of the care economy.
nso: disenthara tše ke karolo ye bohlokwa ya go hlohleletša ikonomi ya go kgathalelana.

eng: they sustain livelihoods, especially for women, which contributes to job creation in many communities.
nso: di thuša go tšwetšapele mekgwa ye batho ba iphedišago ka yona, kudududu basading, gomme se sa thuša go hloma mešomo ditšhabeng tše ntši.

eng: when the covid19 pandemic struck, ecd centres were hard hit.
nso: nakong ya ge leuba la covid19 le aparela naga, disenthara tša ecd di ile tša amega gampe.

eng: facilities that rely on school fees to keep running were unable to pay their staff and many parents who lost their jobs were unable to keep their children enrolled.
nso: dise nthara tšeo di tshepetšego ditefong tša dikolo gore di šome di ile tša šitwa ke go lefela bašomedi ba tšona ebile batswadi ba bantši bao ba lahlegetšwego ke mešomo ba ile ba palelwa ke go ngwadiša bana ba bona.

eng: in response, government established the ecd employment stimulus relief fund to help ecd centres that had lost income as a result of the pandemic and to enable them to recover.
nso: go rarolla seemo se, mmušo o ile wa hloma se khwama sa ecd sa kimollo le sa tlhomo ya mešomo go thuša disenthara tša ecd tšeo di lahlegetšwego ke meputso ka baka la leuba la covid19 go di kgontšha go kaonafala.

eng: preparing our youngest citizens with the tools they need to succeed in life is a responsibility we must collectively shoulder.
nso: go tlabela bana bao e lego badudi ba naga ye ka tsebo le mabokgoni ao ba a hlokago gore ba kgone go atlega bophelong ke maikarabelo ao ka moka ga rena re swanetšego go a šikara magetleng a rena.

eng: we must continue to do all we can, as government, the private sector and development organisations, to support early childhood development.
nso: re swanetše go tšwelapele go dira ka fao re ka kgonang ka gona, bjalo ka mmušo, lefapha la praebete le mekgatlo ya go hlabolla setšhaba, go thekga tlhalefišo ya bomapimpana.

eng: with the many valuable services it provides, whether it is educating our children, providing childcare for working parents or creating opportunities for entrepreneurs, ecd makes a huge contribution to the achievement of many of our developmental goals.
nso: ka ditirelo tša yona tše bohlokwa tše e di abago, go sa kgathale gore e ruta bana ba rena, e hlokomelela ba tswadi bao ba šomago bana goba e hloma mešomo go bahlomi ba dikgwebo, ecd e nale seabe se segolo kudu gore re kgone go fihlelela tše ntši tša dinepo tša rena tša tlhabollo.

eng: since the care economy is mainly driven by women, such support goes a long way towards helping women, especially in disadvantaged communities, to become financially secure and independent.
nso: ka baka la gore gantši ikonomi ya go kgathalelana e šušumetšwa ke basadi, thekgo ye e nale mohola wa go fihla kgojana go lebeletšwe go thuša basadi, kudukudu batho bao kgale ba bego ba phaetšwe thoko setšhabeng, gore le bona ba kgone go ema gabotse ditšheleteng le go kgona go ikema.

eng: how to save water more matshediso the reliability of water supply by municipalities to households across south africa is only at 68%, despite the strides made by the department of water and sanitation to eradicate water supply backlogs over the years.
nso: ka fao o ka seketšago meetse ka gona more matshediso le ge kgoro ya meetse le tlhwekišo mengwa geng ya go feta e lekile ka maatla go fediša mošomo wo o bego o saletše morago wa go tsentšhetša badudi meetse, mo nageng ya afrika borwa ka bophara malapa, ao mebasepala e kgonnego go a tsentšhetša meetse a fihla go 68%.

eng: water and sanitation deputy minister david mahlobo says this is due to old infrastructure, lack of operation and maintenance on water schemes, and the poor integration between housing programmes and current infrastructure development projects.
