nso: motlatšatona wa meetse le tlhwekišo david mahlobo o bolela gore lebakakgolo la go hlola se ke mananeo kgoparara ao a tšofetšego, go hloka tlhokomelo le tokišo ya kgafetšakgafetša ditlamong tša meetse, le tlemagano ya go fokola magareng ga mananeo a dintlo le diprotšeke tša bjale tša tlhabollo ya mananeo kgoparara.

eng: "it is a major concern that the provision of reliable supply water is showing signs of decline," he says.
nso: "e tloga e le hlobaboroko ye kgolo gore kabo ya go botega ya meetse e laetša dika tša phuhlamo," a realo.

eng: as a water scarce country, south africa ranks among 30 driest countries in the world.
nso: bjalo ka naga ya go hlaelela meetse, afrika borwa ke karolo ya dinaga tše 30 tša komelelo lefaseng ka bophara.

eng: most of the country’s water comes from rainfall, but with the recorded average rainfall that is 40% less than the annual world average, the country is often affected by drought.
nso: bontši bja meetse a naga ye a tšwa dupuleng, eupša ka palo moka ye e kgonthišišitšwego ya dipula tšeo di lego fase ga 40% ge di bapetšwa le palomoka ya ngwaga ka ngwaga ya lefase ka bophara, naga ye e fela e angwa gampe ke komelelo.

eng: however, the department has water saving tips for you.
nso: le ge go le bjalo, kgoro e nale dikeletšo tše o ka di šomišago go seketša meetse.

eng: saving water in your home or business turn the tap off¬ between washing your face, brushing your teeth or shaving.
nso: go seketša meetse ka legaeng la gago goba ka kgwebong ya gago tswalela pompi ya meetse ge o hlapa sefahlego, o hlapa meno goba o kera ditedu.

eng: taking a fiveminute shower a day instead of a bath will use a third of the water used bathing in a bath tub, saving up to 400 litres a week.
nso: go hlapa ka šawara tekano ya metsotso ye mehlano ka letšatši legatong la go hlapela ka pafong go šomiša fela kotara ya meetse ao a šomišwago ge o hlapela ka pafong, gomme o ka seketša dilithara tša go fihla 400 ka beke.

eng: showering can use up to 20 litres of water per minute, whereas taking a bath can use between 80 and 150 litres of water per bath.
nso: go hlapa ka šawara go šomiša dilithara tša go fihla tše 20 tša meetse ka motsotso, mola ge o hlapela ka pafong o ka šomiša dili thara tše magareng ga 80 le 150 tša meetse ka pafo ye tee.

eng: if you prefer to bath, do not fill up the bathtub.
nso: ge o rata go hlapela ka pafong, o seke wa e tlatša ka mariba.

eng: avoid flushing the toilet unnecessarily.
nso: efoga go folaša thwaelete fao go sego maleba.

eng: dispose of tissues, insects and other waste in the trash rather than the toilet.
nso: lahlela dithišu, dikhunkhwane le dilahlwa tše dingwe ka gare ga setšhelo sa ditlakala e sego ka thwaelete.

eng: every time you flush the toilet, 12 litres of water is used.
nso: nako le nako ge o folaša, o šomiša meetse a go lekana dilithara tše 12. lokiša thwaelete ya go rothiša meetse go sego bjalo e tla senya meetse a go lekana dilithara tše 100 000 ka ngwaga.

eng: fix a leaking toilet otherwise it can waste up to 100 000 litres of water in one year.
nso: šomiša meetse ao a šomišitšwego – meetse ao a šomileng go tšwa dipafong, metšheneng ya go hlatswa le methopong ye mengwe ya go bolokega go folaša thwaelete.

eng: use "grey water" — used water from baths, washing machines and other safe sources to flush your toilet.
nso: o seke wa tlatša letamo la boruthelo go feta tekano goba wa le hlwekiša ka go falatša meetse ka moka go feta tekano.

eng: kettles should not be filled to the brim but with just enough water for your needs.
nso: diketlele ga se tša swanela go tlatšwa ka meetse go feta tekano eupša di swanetše go tšhelwa fela meetse ao a lekanego gore o kgone go a šomiša.

eng: this will reduce your electricity bill too.
nso: se se tla theoša gape le tšhomišo ya gago ya mohlagase.

eng: use a bucket rather than a hose to wash your car.
nso: šomiša pakete go hlatswa koloi legatong la go šomiša phaephe.

eng: if you have to use a hose, use a sprayer that can be turned off¬ inbetween spraying the car.
nso: ge e ba o gapeletšega go šomiša phaephe, diriša hlogwana ya go šašetša meetse yeo o ka kgonang go e tswalela ge o le gare o šašetša koloi ka yona.

eng: using a garden hose could use as much as 30 litres of water per minute.
nso: ge o šomiša phaephe o ka diriša meetse a mantši a go fihla dilithara tše 30 ka motsotso.

eng: farmers must ensure that they keep toxic insecticides away from water sources and streams.
nso: balemi ba swanetše go netefatša gore ba beela kgole difotheladikhu khwane tše nago le mpholo kgole le methopo le meela ya meetse.

eng: people living in rural areas should be careful not to use the river or riverbank as a toilet.
nso: batho ba swanetše go bale tlhokomelo ye kgolo mafe long ao ba dulago go ona gore ba se tšhilafatše dinoka goba mariba a tšona.

eng: in the garden always water your plants during the early morning hours or in the evening, when temperatures are cooler.
nso: go seketša meetse ka tšhengwaneng dula o nošetša dimela tša gago mesong goba mathapama, ge dithemphereitšha di fodile.

eng: every time you boil an egg, save the cooled water for your houseplants.
nso: nako le nako ge o fufutša mae, o se tšholle meetse ao gomme o a beye gore a fole o tle o nošetše ka ona.

eng: they will benefit from the nutrients released from the shell.
nso: dimela tša gago di tla godišwa ke menontšha ya go tšwa dikgepetleng tša mae.

eng: prep can prevent hiv allison cooper as south africa comme morates world aids day on 1 december and 16 days of activism against genderbased violence (gbv), from 25 november to 10 december, vuk’uzenzele explores the relationship between gbv and hiv/aids.
nso: prep e ka kgona go thibela hiv vukuzenzele unnamed ge afrika borwa e tla be e gopola letšatši la lefase la aids ka la 1 manthole mmogo le matšatši a 16 a kgahlanong le dikgaruru tša bong (gbv) go tloga ka la 25 dibatsela go fihla ka la 10 manthole, vuk’uzenzele e lebelela kamano gareng ga gbv le hiv/aids.

eng: the genderbased vio lence and femicide (gbvf) response fund strives to ensure that south africa is free from gbvf against women; children; and the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer/questioning, asexual and more (lgbtqia+) community.
nso: sekhwama sa karabelo sa dikgaruru tša bong le polao ya basadi (gbvf) se nepile go netefatša gore afrika borwa ga e na dipolao tša basadi; bana; le batho ba go wela ka sehlopheng sa batho ba go ratana ka bong botee (lgbtqia+).

eng: the fund was launched by president cyril ramaphosa in february 2021, to support the implementation of the national strategic plan on gbvf.
nso: sekhwama se tsebagaditšwe ke mopresidente cyril ramaphosa ka dibokwane 2022 go thekga phethagatšo ya leanotharollo la bosetšhaba go gbvf.

eng: according to the fund’s website, it plays a critical role in making change happen, based on research, awareness and practical support to organisations actively engaged in the fight against gbvf.
nso: go ya le ka websaete ya sekhwama, sekhwama se se bapala karolo e bohlokwa ka go tlišeng phetogo, se itheile go dinyakišišo, ditemošo le thekgo go mekgatlo yeo e lwantšhanago le gbvf.

eng: one of the organisations supported by the fund is the kwazulunatal based gugu dlamini foundation, which received r250 000 from the gbvf in 2022. executive director of the gugu dlamini foundation, mandisa mabaso, established the foundation in 2010 after her mother – the late gugu dlamini – was stoned to death in 1998 in durban for disclosing her hivpositive status.
nso: wo mongwe wa mekgatlo yeo e thekgwago ke sekhwama se ke gugu dlamini foundation ya ka kwazulunatal yeo ka ngwaga wa 2022 e filwego r250 000 ke sekhwama sa kara belo ya gbvf.

eng: "the foundation aims to strengthen local governance to improve the gbvf response, which is essential to achieving hiv epidemic control in south africa," says mabaso.
nso: molaodiphethiši wa gugu dlamini foundation, mandisa mabaso, o hlomile mokgatlo wo ka 2010 morago ga gore mmagwe – mohu gugu dla mini – a bolawe ka go kgatlwa ka maswika ka 1998 ka durban morago ga go bolela gore o na le hiv .

eng: "it also aims to reduce hiv/aids infections, increase access to care and improve health outcomes for females and males infected and affected by hiv/aids," she adds.
nso: "mokgatlo o ikemišeditše go matlafatša pušo ya selegae go kaonafatša karabelo ya gbvf, e lego sona selo se lego bohlokwa sa go tlo thuša go kgona go laola leuba la hiv ka afrika borwa," gwa realo mabaso.

eng: the funding that the foundation receives assists 522 255 women and girls and 900 men and boys from families affected by gbv and domestic violence; abused persons living with disabilities; and the lgbtqia+ community, says mabaso.
nso: "e tlo re thuša gape go fokotša diphetetšo tša hiv , go oketša phihlelelego ya go hwetša tlho komelo gape le go kaonafatša dipoelo tša maphelo bakeng sa basadi le banna bao ba fetetšwego ebile ba amilwego ke hiv/aids," a tlaleletša ka go realo.

eng: according to unaids, in areas of high hiv burden, women who are victims of gbv face up to a 50% higher chance of acquiring hiv .
nso: mašeleng ao mokgatlo o a fiwago a thuša basadi le basetsana ba 522 255 le banna le bašemane ba 900 go tšwa mala peng ao a amilwego ke gbv le dikgaruru tša ka malapeng; batho ba go phela ka bogolofadi bao ba tlaišitšwego; le batho ba lgbtqia+, gwa realo mabaso.

eng: one of the ways to prevent hiv infection is by taking preexposure prophylaxis (prep), which is a medicine taken daily by hivnegative people who are at high risk of being exposed to hiv , through sexual contact or injection drug use.
nso: go ya ka unaids, ka mafelong ao hiv e tletšego kudu, basadi bao e lego batšwasehlabelo ba gbv ba lebagane le kgonagalo ya 50% ya gore ba tsenwe ke hiv .

eng: "a person on prep does not have to take it for the rest of their lives, they can choose to take it every time they are at risk of being infected with hiv .
nso: ye nngwe ya ditsela tša go thibela phetetšo ya hiv ke go nwa preexposure prophylaxis (prep), e lego moriana woo o nwewago tšatši ka tšatši ke batho bao ba se nago hiv bao ba lego kotsing ya go fetelwa ka tsela ya thobalano goba go ihlabela ka diokobatši.

eng: what hiv positive breastfeeding moms should know vukuzenzele unnamed with south africa observing world aids day on the 1st of december, the kwazulunatal department of health has advised hiv positive mothers to consider breastfeeding their babies exclusively for six months.
nso: seo bommagobana bao ba nago le hiv gomme ba nyantshago ba swanetsego go se tseba vukuzenzele unnamed ge afrika borwa e tla be e dira segopotšo sa letšatši la lefase la aids ka la 1 manthole, kgoro ya maphelo ka kwazulunatal e eleditše bommagobana bao ba nago le hiv gore ba fepe masea a bona ka go a nyantšha feela tekano ya dikgwedi tše tshela.

eng: according to the depart ment, if you are an hiv positive breastfeeding mother, it is important to discuss feeding choices with your hiv counsellor.
nso: go ya ka kgoro, ge eba o mosadi yoo a nyantšhago gomme ebile o na le hiv , go bohlokwa gore o boledišane le mothobamatswalo wa gago wa tša hiv ka mehuta ya go fepa.

eng: if you choose to breast feed, be sure to breastfeed exclusively for the first six months.
nso: ge e ba o kgetha go nyantšha, netefatša gore o fepa ngwana ka go mo nyantšha feela tekano ya dikgwedi tše tshela tša mathomo.

eng: research has shown that the baby has very little chance of getting hiv from breastmilk if the mother exclusively breastfeeds.
nso: diphatišišo di bontšhitše gore go na le kgonagalo e nnyane kudu ya gore ngwana a fetelwe ke hiv go tšwa matutung a letswele ge eba mmagwe a mo fepa ka go mo nyantšha feela.

eng: during the months that you are pregnant, and breastfeeding, be sure to use a condom during sexual intercourse to prevent any new infection.
nso: mo dikgweding tšeo o tla bego o imile, le ge o tla be o nyantšha, netefatša gore o šomiša khondomo ge o tsenela tša thobalano gore o thibele diphetetšo tše diswa.

eng: if you have any problems such a painful nipples or breasts, be sure to go the clinic early for help.
nso: ge eba o na le mathata afe goba afe a bjalo ka ditlhoko tše bohloko goba matswele a bohloko, netefatša gore o ya kliniking e sa le ka pela go yo hwetša thušo.

eng: the department strongly recommends exclusive breastfeeding because it helps the baby develop a stronger immune system, and a stronger bond between mother and baby.
nso: kgoro e tloga e gatelela taba ya go fepa ka go nyantšha feela ka ge e thuša ngwana gore a be le mašole a mmele a tiilego, gape le go hlama kgokagano e tiilego gareng ga mma le ngwana.

eng: breastfeeding also reduces the mother’s risks of developing breast cancer.
nso: go nyantšha go fokotša gape le dikotsi tša go tsenwa ke kankere ya letswele.

eng: breastfeeding myths and facts there are several myths associated with breastfeeding, the department debunked these myths by answering the following frequently asked questions by mothers who are hiv positive and those who are not hiv positive.
nso: dikakanyo tša maaka le dinnete mabapi le go nyantšha go na le dikakanyo tša maaka tše ntšhi tša mabapi le go nyantšha.

eng: question: my neighbour said that i should get some medicine to clean my baby's stomach.
nso: potšišo: moagišane wa ka o rile ke swanetše ke hwetše moriana wa go hlwekiša teng ya ngwanaka.

eng: is this important?
nso: naa se se bohlokwa?

eng: answer: colostrum, which is the first form of breastmilk that is released by the mammary glands after giving birth, cleans the meconium from the stomach.
nso: karabo: matutu a mathomo, ao a tšweletšwago ke dithaka tša maswi morago ga pelego, a hlwekiša ditšhila go tšwa mpeng ya ngwana.

eng: you will not need any medicines for further cleaning as breastmilk is clean, and actually lines the stomach, protecting it from bacteriaquestion: in the first few days, if i do not have enough milk, can i give water or other milk as well?
nso: ga o hloke meriana go hlwekiša ngwana ka teng ka ge maswi a letswele a hlwekile gomme ebile a kgona go šireletša teng ga ngwana.

eng: answer: the colostrum is all the baby needs.
nso: karabo: matutu a mathomo ke sona feela seo ngwana a se hlokago.

eng: you just need to feed the baby often so that the milk will come in you make lots of milk that way.
nso: o hloka go nyantšha ngwana kgafetšakgafetša gore matutu a mangwe a tšweletšwe – ke ka moo o kgonago go tšweletša matutu a mantšhi ka gona.

eng: ask the midwife to give you your baby within the first half hour after birth, so you can put the baby to the breast.
nso: kgopela mmelegiši go go fa ngwana wa gago seripagare sa iri o sa tšwa go mmelega gore o kgone go mo nyantšha.

eng: the baby will learn quickly how to suckle and this will help you to make more milk.
nso: ngwana o tla kgona go ithuta go nyanya ka pela gomme se se tla go thuša gore o dire matutu a mantšhi.

eng: question: i am giving breastmilk, but the baby is not satisfied.
nso: potšišo: ke a nyantšha, efela ngwana ga a khore.

eng: the more the baby suckles, the more milk is made.
nso: ge o tšwela pele o nyantšha ngwana kgafetšakgafetša ke mo o dirago matutu a mantšhi.

eng: question: my baby wants to feed so often maybe i don't have enough milk?
nso: lesa ngwana a nyanye go fihlela a kgotsofala letsweleng le tee gore a hwetše matutu a moseo.

eng: answer: maybe the baby is growing quickly, and so needs more milk.
nso: ge ngwana a tšwela pele a nyanya, matutu le ona a tšwela pele go dirwa.

eng: by feeding often, you can make enough milk for their needs.
nso: ka go nyantšha kgafetšakgafetša, o ka kgona go dira matutu a mantšhi ao ngwana a a hlokago.

eng: the milk will not run out.
nso: matutu a ka se ke a fela.

eng: allow extra time for the baby to suckle don't pull the baby off the breast.
nso: lesa ngwana a nyanye nako e teletšana.

eng: if a baby has more than six wet nappies every day, is being fed often (at least 812 times every day), and the baby is gaining at least 500g every month, then you are making enough milk.
nso: ge ngwana a ka thapiša maleiri a go feta a tshela tšatši ka tšatši, a nyantšhwa kgafetšakgafetša (makga a 8 go ya go 12 tšatši ka tšatši), a gola ka digerama tše 500 kgwed i ka kgwedi, gona o tšweletša matutu a lekanego.

eng: question: if my baby cries often, what do i do?
nso: potšišo: naa nka dira eng ge ngwana a phela a lla?

eng: answer: comfort your baby by putting them to the breast more often.
nso: karabo: homotša ngwana wa gago ka go mmea letsweleng kgafetšakgafetša.

eng: babies need to be close to their mothers.
nso: bana ba hloka go ba kgauswi le bo mmabona.

eng: mothers and babies sharing the same room will encourage this.
nso: se se tla kgona gala ge bomma le bana ba robala ka phapošing e tee.

eng: if your baby is hungry, thirsty or upset, suckling at the breast will satisfy them.
nso: ge eba ngwana wa gago o swerwe ke tlala, o nyorilwe goba o selekegile, go nyanya letswele go tla mo kgotsofatša.

eng: it is unlikely that you will overfeed your baby when giving breastmilk only.
nso: kgonagalo ke ye nnyane kudu ya gore o ka nyantšha ngwana go feta tekano ge a phela ka maswi a letswele feela.

eng: question: is it good to give other drinks?
nso: potšišo: naa go lokile go fa ngwana dino tše dingwe?

eng: answer: no, adding other drinks means that the baby is more likely to get diseases like diarrhoea and pneumonia.
nso: go fa ngwana dino tše dingwe go ka dira gore ngwana a be le kgona galo e ntšhi ya go tsenwa ke malwetši a bjalo ka letšhologo le nyumonia.

eng: also, if the baby has other drinks, they won't suckle as often and you won't make enough milk.
nso: se sengwe gape, ge eba ngwana o nwa dino tše dingwe, a ka se nyanye gantšhi, gomme le wena o ka se kgone go dira matutu a lekanego.

eng: question: doesn't the baby need water when it is hot?
nso: potšišo: naa ngwana ga a hloke meetse ge go fiša?

eng: jobs figures show our economyis on the road to recovery vukuzenzele unnamed over the last few years, south africans have had to contend with slow growth and rising unemployment.
nso: dipalopalo tša mešomo di laetša gore ikonomi ya rena e leetong la go tsoga vukuzenzele unnamed mo me ngwageng e se mekae yeo e fetilego, maafrika borwa a ile a swanelwa ke go tlwaela kgolo ya ikonomi ya go nanya mmogo le koketšego ya tlhokego ya mešomo.

eng: this has been worsened by a devastating pandemic, an attempted insurrection unrest in july 2021, and, earlier this year, severe floods in parts of kwazulunatal, eastern cape and north west.
nso: se se ile sa gakatšwa kudu ke leuba la masetlapelo la covid19, di kgaruru tša mosegamanye 2021 le, mathomong a ngwaga wo, mafula a šoro ka dika rolong tša kwazulunatal, kapa bohlabela le leboa bodikela.

eng: amidst all this, the energy crisis has loomed large, causing damage to the economy and hardship for households and businesses.
nso: gareng ga tše ka moka, mathata a mohlagase a oketšegile, gomme a hlola tshenyo go ikonomi le ma tshwenyego go malapa le dikgwebo.

eng: yet, even amidst these formidable challenges, our society and economy has proven to be resilient.
nso: efela, le ka gare ga dihlotlo tše tše kgolo tše, setšhaba sa borena mmogo le ikonomi ba itaeditše gore ba a kgo tlelela, gomme go na le ditaetšo tša gore ikonomi ya rena e bontšha dika tša go kgahliša tša go tsoga.

eng: and indications are that our economy is showing encouraging signs of recovery.
nso: dipalopalo tša gabjale, kudu tša mešomo, di re fa kholofelo.

eng: statistics south africa recorded a decline in the unemployment rate for the second quarter of 2021. significantly, their measurement shows that the actual number of people employed rose from 14.5 million people in the fourth quarter of 2021 to 15.5 million in the second quarter of 2022. this is an encouraging increase of muchneeded jobs over the first half of this year.
nso: ba statistics south africa ba laeditše gore go bile le phokotšego ya tlhokego ya mešomo ka kotareng ya bobedi ya 2021. dipalopalo tša bona di bontšhitše gore – e lego seo se lego bohlokwa – palo ya batho bao ba šomago e oketšegile go tloga go dimilione tše 14.5 ka kotareng ya bone ya 2021 go ya go dimilione tše 15.5 ka kotareng ya bobedi ya 2022. ye ke koketšego ya go kgahliša ya mešomo yeo e lego gore e a hlokwa nakong ya seripa sa mathomo sa ngwaga wo.

eng: these jobs were mainly created in sectors such as community and social services, trade, finance and, notably, construction.
nso: mešomo ye e ile ya hlolwa kudu ka makaleng a bjalo ka ditirelo tša setšhaba le leago, dikgwebišano, ditšhelete le, kudukudu, tša boagi.

eng: of course, much more needs to be done if we are to make a significant dent in our country’s high unemployment rate.
nso: ee, mošomo o montšhi o sa dutše o hloka go dirwa ge eba re nyaka go fokotša tlhokego ya mešomo ka nageng ya rena ka palo ya go bonala.

eng: at the same time, these figures indicate that the priority areas of the economic reconstruction and recovery plan – such as mass public employment, economic reform and infrastructure development – are having an impact on job creation.
nso: ka nako e tee, dipalopalo tše di laetša gore makala a bohlokwa a leano la kago leswa le tsošološo ya ikonomi, a bjalo ka go thwalwa ga batho ka bontšhi, mpshafatšo ya ikonomi le tlhabollo ya mana neokgoparara, a na le seabe ge go etla tlholong ya mešomo.

eng: with infrastructure development and investment being one of the key priorities of our recovery plan, the growth in jobs in the construction area is particularly encouraging.
nso: ka tlhabollo le peeletšo ka mananeokgoparara e le ye nngwe ya ditlapele tše bohlokwa tša leano la rena la tsošološo, kgolo ya mešomo ka lekaleng la tša boagi e tloga e kgahliša.

eng: the february 2022 budget outlined a 30% increase in spending on public infrastructure over the next three years to r812 billion, compared to r627 billion over the past three years.
nso: ka dibokwane 2022, tekanyetšo ya matlotlo e laeditše koketšego ya 30% ya tšhomišo ya mašeleng go mananeokgoparara a setšhaba mo mengwageng e meraro yeo e latelago go fihla go r812 bilione, ge e bapetšwa le r627 bilione mo mengwageng e meraro yeo e fetilego.

eng: the construction industry development board recently noted that there has been an increase in infrastructure projects driven by stateowned enterprises like transnet and eskom, but also in the metros and through the department of public works and infrastructure.
nso: boto ya tlhabollo ya intaseteri ya tša boagi e sa tšwa go lemoga gore go bile le koketšego ya diprotšeke tša mananeokgoparara tšeo di sepetšwago ke dikgwebo tša mmušo tše bjalo ka transnet le eskom, le mebasepala ya setoropo le kgoro ya mešomo ya setšhaba le mananeokgoparara.

eng: in june, this year we saw our economy return to prepandemic growth levels owing to a fairly positive gdp outcome in the first quarter of the year.
nso: ka phupu ngwageng wo re bone ikonomi ya rena e boela maemong a kgolo ya pele ga ge leuba le thoma, gomme se se hlotšwe ke dipoelo tše botse ka kotareng ya mathomo ya ngwaga.

eng: naturally the objective is to move significantly off this low base, which is why we are continuing with our focus on structural reforms that drive growth.
nso: ka tlhago poelo ya se ke go tloga mo maemong a tlase, e lego lona lebaka leo le dirago gore re tšwele pele ka nepo ya rena ya dimpshafatšo tša mananeo tšeo di tlo tlišago kgolo.

eng: government recently published a proposed amendment to remove the licensing threshold for electricity generation facilities and encourage investment in larger, utility scale projects to rapidly add new generation capacity to the grid.
nso: mmušo o sa tšwa go phatlalatša phetošo yeo e šišintšwego go tloša senyakwa sa laesense ya go hlotla mohla gase gomme o hlohleletša gore go be le peeletšo e kgolo ka diprotšeke tše kgolo go oketša maatla a mohlagase ka lebelo.

eng: this represents a major milestone in our efforts to transform the country’s energy landscape, a critical prerequisite for economic growth and attracting investment.
nso: se se laetša phihlelelo e kgolo ka maitekelong a rena a go mpshafatša seemo sa mohlagase ka nageng, e lego sona senyakwasegolo go kgolo ya ikonomi le go goketša dipeeletšo.

eng: since the national energy plan was announced in july this year, we have been working as government in partnership with various stakeholders on implementation and policy reform.
nso: e sa le go tloga mola leano la bosetšhaba la enetši le tsebišwago ka mosegamanye ngwageng wo, re be re le gare re šoma bjalo ka mmušo ka tšhomišano le batšeakarolo ba go fapafapana ge go etla phethagatšong le mpshafatšong ya dipholisi.

eng: since we raised the licensing threshold to 100 megawatts in june 2021, more than 500 mw of private renewable power generation projects have been registered, with a pipeline of over 6,000 mw of projects at various stages of development.
nso: e sa le go tloga mola re tlošago senyakwa sa dilaesense go fihla go dimekawate tše 100 ka phupu 2021, dimekawate tša go feta tše 500 tša maatla a mohlagase ao a tšweletšwago ke diprotšeke tša lekala la praefete di šetše di ngwadišitšwe, ka dimekawate tše 6 000 tšeo di letetšwego go tšweletšwa ke diprotšeke tše magatong a go fapafapana a tlhabollo.

eng: the structural reform process continues to register progress in support of economic growth and attracting investment.
nso: tshepedišo ya mpshafatšo ya mananeo e tšwela pele go laetša tšwelopele ka thekgo ya kgolo ya ikonomi le go goketša dipeeletšo.

eng: economic growth cannot be realised and jobs cannot be created without undertaking the difficult but necessary structural reforms that will improve the business and investment climate.
nso: kgolo ya ikonomi e ka se kgone go phethagala gomme le mešomo e ka se kgone go hlolwa ntle le go dira dimpshafatšo tša mananeo tša maleba tšeo di tlo kaonafatšago seemo sa kgwebo le dipeeletšo.
